TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the principal article in the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday headed 'Secret talks as Liberals split on tax' and to today's article in the Melbourne Age suggesting that former employees of the Prime Minister are involved in lobbying with respect to tax avoidance. I ask: Is it true that threats have been made that funds will be withheld from the Liberal Party if certain tax avoidance legislation goes ahead? If so, does this conflict with repeated claims by Liberal Party Ministers, including Senator Sir John Carrick, here and elsewhere that there is no connection between funding for the Liberal Party and Government policy and that there is no access for Liberal Party donors to Government members? Having regard to the different attitude taken by the New South Wales Liberal Party about public funding, I ask: Will the Government now accept the arguments put forward by the Australian Labor Party and me in this place on the question of election funding to guarantee complete propriety in the matter of the funding of elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may take the second part of the question first, there is no suggestion that those who accept public funding, for example, the Wran Government, will not supplement that public funding by private contributions. Public funding in no way delimits the rights of political parties to receive moneys from individuals. I see no connection at all. I know of no threats at all by anybody with regard to the withholding of donations. I can only refer to the principles as I have known them and applied them over the years-and I believe them to be applied; that is, that in the Liberal Party any raising of funds is done by finance committees, which do not include members of parliament-
—By tax cheats like Denis Horgan.

—I repeat that money is raised by finance committees which are themselves instructed in a code requiring that they should receive donations from individuals without any strings attached at all. Any suggestion of a threat or an implied withholding of funds would be taken as a threat to the integrity of the organisation.
—Integrity? You must be joking.
—Order! I ask the Minister to be seated for a moment. I suggest to Senator Walsh that I will apply Standing Order 438 if he continues this type of interjection.

—The question is important and it demands a detailed answer. The fact is that the aim is that there should never be any link between a donation to the political party and any implied threat or any implied promise. That, as I understand it, has always been strongly upheld.
—You keep them secret. So how can you tell?

—I know of no secret talks. I am aware that there are some who have said that the prospective legislation and approach to the collection of tax from what are called wet Slutzkin schemes-the wet, or wetter, bottom-of-the-harbour schemes-is wrong and should not be pursued. The legislation will be before the Parliament, including the Senate. It will be for honourable senators to look at its details and see whether it is equitable. I fully understand that there are campaigns which suggest that our attempts will embody retrospectivity and that retrospectivity is bad. That is a matter for judgment when the legislation comes before the Senate. There are people who are alleging that what we are proposing to do cuts across the principle of retrospectivity but I know of no secret talks in that matter; I know of no threats. I want to make it abundantly clear that no one will threaten with impunity any section of the Liberal Party; that no one will use the device of giving to, or withholding funds from, that political party in return for any favour.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that the article written by John Short in last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald is not true? The article stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Threats have also been made that if the Government goes ahead with the legislation-
That is, the retrospective tax legislation--
funds will be withheld from the Liberal Party. This was confirmed yesterday by Government back benchers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said was that I know of no such threats. For example, I am aware of threats being made in a previous Federal election campaign to the Federal branch of the Australian Labor Party by major left-wing trade unions that they would withhold funds unless the Labor Party did certain things. I have read of those threats and they have never been denied. I have said that I know of no such threats and that any threat that would be made would have no capacity to be implemented because, unlike the Labor Party-which is so susceptible to pressures from its big trade unions-there is within the Liberal Party no connection between the giving of money and any implementation of policies.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENERGY RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION GRANTS: WIND GENERATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to his Press statement of 18 August 1982 indicating that in 1982-83 amounts of money will be provided for energy research, development and demonstration grants. I also draw to his attention information that I provided to him on a self-starting aerofoil section wind generator which is being developed by Solar and Allied Power in Caloundra, Queensland. I have visited the company's small factory there . The use of this aerofoil section for wind generation is a completely new concept. I ask: Can the Minister advise whether this sort of work would be considered for favourable treatment by his Department in the awarding of these grants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any suggestion or technical device that can add to the capacity for renewable energy sources, be it solar, wind or biomass, must be examined carefully by the Government because the non-renewables, as their name suggests, have a limited term of life. I have been very interested in the suggestions made by Senator Collard in the past and have asked my Department to have a look at them. Basically, the proposals that he mentions address technically interesting areas in relation to the use of renewable energy resources. The first proposes a method of overcoming the starting problems at low wind speed, which are associated with some wind generators. It is a vital concept and, if there is a breakthrough on it, that will be important. The second concept relates to storing solar energy and the third to the efficient conversion of direct current to alternating current. They concern three frontier kinds of problems in this field. The third concept is necessary when using solar collectors such as photo-voltaic cells if the energy is to be used for standard appliances.

ANSWER.PARA: Because the proposals embrace technical matters the information provided has been forwarded to the relevant National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council technical standing committee for evaluation and comment. I stress that the Government welcomes any device that will add to the ability of renewable energy sources to increase their efficiency. On the face of it, the device referred to by Senator Collard is an attractive proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer . Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Sunday Mail of 15 August 1982 which describes Queensland as the nation's company tax haven? How has the Federal Government allowed this situation to develop? Has any investigation been made of the tax dodging schemes outlined in the Sunday Mail article? If so, has any action been taken against these schemes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the particular article in the Sunday Mail relating to Queensland, but I think we have had a fair amount of discussion on what is occurring with regard to tax avoidance schemes in any State of Australia. The matters that were outlined by me yesterday in the Senate 's debate on a matter of public importance and that were outlined in the other place the day before illustrated the list of legislation which has been introduced and passed, or contemplated. Also many statements have been made relating to stamping out tax avoidance or evasion to the greatest degree possible. I will have the Treasurer look at the article referred to by Senator Colston and see whether he wishes to make any further comment on the matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I am sure he will be aware of the extent to which our Aboriginal community has been disadvantaged by a lack of educational opportunities. Is the Minister aware also of the significant increase in the costs incurred by hostels that accommodate Aboriginal students? If so, what steps have been taken by the Government to help meet these additional costs? In particular, what additional benefits can Aboriginal students hope to receive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware of the role which Senator Bonner has played in regard to Aboriginal hostels over a number of years, and I think continuously since Aboriginal Hostels Ltd was formed to provide hostel places for Aboriginals across Australia. I welcome his question, although it goes really to hostels provided specifically in association with schools. It was possible to announce in the Budget increases in Aboriginal secondary grants allowances for students and also increases in the boarding allowances, so that straight away a greater amount of money will be provided for boarding support for Aboriginals who have to be away from home.

ANSWER.PARA: But there is a particular matter which we have been able to pick up in the Budget to the benefit of Aboriginal Australians. A number of hostels in country towns have been the sole source of boarding for Aboriginal students. Because some of these hostels were not associated with a school, in a physical sense, they did not qualify as school boarding houses. The Government has decided that they will now so qualify and the boarding allowance will be paid to Aboriginal students in certain approved hostels, even if they are situated slightly away from the schools. It does represent an increased capacity for Aboriginal people to obtain the secondary education which all Australians would like to see made available to them, for very obvious educational reasons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In order for it to receive an adequate reply it ought also to be responded to by the Leader of the Opposition. I leave it to you, Mr President, to say whether that kind of response is possible. The subject of the question is the new and permanent Parliament House, which I visited with some of my colleagues earlier this week. To be actually on the site brings home much more forcibly than the plans ever could the truly monumental nature of the extravagance and financial overkill being perpetrated on Capital Hill. I ask the Leader of the Government initially: Is it a fact that the estimated cost of the new and permanent Parliament House has already well over doubled from the figure of $151m when the project was announced in 1978 to $370m in March this year? Is it likely that the cost on present plans, if they are persisted with, may well reach $1 billion before the project is completed? In view of the grave shortage of public housing in Australia and the necessity for tens of thousands of age pensioners to live in conditions inferior to those in many of our prisons-I have seen them in Sydney; it is a fact-how can the Government and, for that matter, the Australian Labor Party stomach the extent of spending being lavished on this edifice? Since the building is well commenced, it would be naive to suggest that it be abandoned at this stage. However, I ask whether a genuine effort can be made now--

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will repeat that statement, Mr President, as there was a little background noise. When the noise has stopped I shall proceed. This is a rather important point. I should like to feel that I had an audience.
—Order !

—Thank you, Mr President. I ask that a genuine effort be made now to undertake a revision of the design so that the massive and rising cost of this building to the nation can be significantly reduced. Relevant to that, I ask why it has seemed necessary to provide suites for members and senators which are five times the size of those that we have now. I should have thought that twice the size or three times the size would be enough; but they are five times as large. Why is solar heating and cooling not being considered for the building ?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest, Senator Mason, that you ask your question as quickly as possible. I do not want to be seen to be inhibiting you in any way from the chair on this subject.

—I have only two more parts to the question, Mr President. Why is solar heating and cooling not being considered for a building which would seem ideally suited for it? Can we eliminate as much as possible frivolities such as the giant two-level pool bisected by waterfalls above the public parking area and the vast areas of concourses and things of that kind?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My clear understanding is that at all stages, from the original decision on the site and the building, the determination to build Parliament House has been totally bipartisan in both chambers of this Parliament . Therefore, it is a quite extraordinary situation that Senator Mason should ask this question today-it is not extraordinary that the Australian Democrats should be changing policy-the Democrats having in fact let it be known by their actions of the past that they accepted the bipartisan situation. It is doubly extraordinary because at all times the provisions have been available for the Democrats to go to the various authorities and state their views. Why is it that the Democrats, if they think that the plans are wrong, have not been to the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House? Why is it that years have gone by and they have suddenly discovered, because they went to the site the other day, the layout of the Parliament House? Are not the people who are recreant to their duty the very people who are now raising this matter? Why have they not been to the Standing Committee? I invite them to go to it. I invite them to go to their peers, members of both Houses, and explain to them why they have not inspected the plans before, why they have not come before their peers and told them their views before, and why each time the amount for the new Parliament House has been tabled in Parliament they have not risen in their places to dispute it in any way. It is extraordinary that with the fear of elections in their minds they are suddenly grabbing for things.

ANSWER.PARA: With the fear of elections in the Democrats' minds-Senator Reid and Senator Ryan may have some acute sensitivities about this-I hope that their views on this matter are made known to every elector in the Australian Capital Territory, because the Australian Capital Territory has as the basis for its building construction industry at present the construction of the new Parliament House. I take it that the purpose of this question is to reduce the amount of work that is available. Incidentally, the management, the cost control and the quality control exercised by Sir Bernard Callinan and his committee make this one of the most tightly controlled and highly efficient undertakings in Australia today. I also pay tribute to the quality and the progress of the work that has been done on the site. I invite honourable senators to go there and see the progress that has been made.

Some honourable senators may know that I originally opposed the building of the new Parliament House, but I have come to accept that it is not only necessary but also a wonderful concept of imaginative creation and efficiency. I want to pay tribute to all those who are associated with this undertaking. I spoke to the Authority the other day, and my understanding is that the cost control is very good. Let me repeat that anyone who, in the past year, had reservations about this matter had recourse to the Presiding Officers, the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House and Cabinet Ministers to express his views . Senator Mason has not done so and his comments today can be judged for what they are-that is, running scared and looking for cheap issues, which will backfire, and nowhere more loudly than in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, but first I ask Senator Sir John Carrick, after he has his staff look at the 1979 Hansards, to make a statement in this place tomorrow withdrawing certain comments which he has made. I made a major speech on this matter. I will send his staff a copy of it. I think that he should recall what is set out in Hansard before he makes allegations against other senators. My supplementary question, which is the main question, is this: Will a genuine effort now be made to undertake a revision of the design of this building so that the massive and rising costs to the nation can be significantly reduced? Is the answer yes or no?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Mason wishes to go before the Standing Committee of this Parliament and argue his case before it, he has the opportunity to do so. He has always had this opportunity. Why is it that he has now suddenly discovered the nature of the design?
—That is not so. Have a look at Hansard.

—If he knew it before, why was he so silent over the months and years? Why did he not come forward to tell us of these now articulated extravagances? If he wants to press this matter, let him go before his peers. They will make very good judgments about his arguments and his reasons.

—I must also respond from the chair to the question asked by Senator Mason. It was directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He also stated that he would give an opportunity to the Leader of the Opposition in this place to respond if he so desired. I want to make the point very clearly in this chamber that the decision to build a new Parliament House was a decision of the Parliament. It was a decision of both chambers of this Parliament and of all parties within it.
—No, that is absolutely untrue. I beg your pardon, but that is not so.

—The Australian Democrats have objected. I also make it clear that a committee has been dealing with the design and construction of the new and permanent Parliament House for many years. It is an all party-Government and Opposition-committee. Members of both chambers are on it. I can only say from my position as President of this chamber that I commend the parliamentarians for the way, in the initial stages, they agreed as parliamentarians, without any party politics whatsoever. This is the first time ever, when the new Parliament House has been discussed, that this has happended. I emphasise again that the correct decision to build this new Parliament House was made by the Parliament of Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, although it may also have some implications for him as Attorney-General. Has the Minister seen an article in the 16 August 1982 issue of the Newsweek magazine headed 'The Mail Order Brides' which refers to the growing number-1,500 in 1981-of marriages between Philippine women and Australian men arranged through marriage agencies? I am sure all honourable senators have seen these agencies' advertisements in major Australian newspapers. Does the Minister share my concern at the allegations in the article that Philippine women reportedly have been beaten, have been given little or no money, and have been kept virtual prisoners in their husbands' houses? In view of the particular nature of this section of the marriage industry that is specific to the Philippine women, will the Government consider legislating to require that these women be given, in advance of migrating to Australia, a full description of their legal rights in Australia after marriage?

—I am not familiar with the article in Newsweek of 16 August referred to by Senator Martin. I will refer the question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and ask him to provide me with an early answer for her.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. On the best estimates available to the Minister from his Department, whether it be in his representative capacity or as Minister for Social Security, what does the Minister believe will be the average level of unemployment benefit recipients for the year 1982-83?
—I do not have any advice from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations or from the Minister on that question. I will seek it and give the honourable senator a reply.
—Haven't you read the Budget? It is in the Budget, isn't it?

—The estimate given in the Budget is the one that was raised yesterday. As I understand it, the honourable senator is asking for an estimate from a particular department of state or from a particular Minister of state.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. In view of the Government's undertaking to provide $3,650m for roads over a five-year period to 1984-85 and the additional undertaking given in the Treasurer's Budget Speech to set up an Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program which will make a further $2, 500m available for roads by 1988-89, can the Minister state whether the road building programs which will ensue will be developed in close consultation with the Department of Defence? Is the Minister aware that many of the new roads which are being built as part of the national highway program and State and local government road programs are of insufficient design specifications to meet the requirements of Australia's defence forces, especially in the remote north and north-west of Western Australia? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Department of Defence will consult with the road building authorities in all three levels of government to ensure that this weakness in our defence preparedness is quickly and effectively eradicated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable senator that the Department of Defence officers are consulted as a matter of course as to defence requirements when both standards and priorities for national roads are being formulated. I am not particularly aware that many of the new roads under the national highway program are of insufficient design specification to meet the requirements of Australia's defence forces. In fact a defence officer was a member of the Commonwealth-State joint study group which examined the Broome-Darwin road link recently. The Department of Defence made a definite input into the standards for that road and accepted the standard that was eventually agreed.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the last matter referred to by the honourable senator, I repeat that the Commonwealth consults as a matter of course with the Department of Defence; but, as regards State-funded roads, arterial roads, local roads, and roads of that kind, there would be a need to refer to the State authorities. I will undertake to refer that part of the honourable senator's question to the Minister and see whether he may be able to use his good offices to influence State authorities in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President, and refers to a topic which has already been mentioned today but is asked for a different reason. The Senate has been provided with an updated building budget for the new Parliament House but no report on the progress of the construction to date. Could you, sir, arrange for a brief report on the present situation to be provided to the Senate and, if possible, arrange for a guided tour of the site for those many senators who would be interested in seeing at first hand what has been achieved to date and what is planned for the immediate future?

—I would be pleased to arrange for all honourable senators to visit the site. I have had the opportunity to visit it on two occassions and I have been delighted with the progress that is taking place. It is certainly a major undertaking of a project that will be one of the highlights of any building in this country. I hope that I will have a report for honourable senators early next week. I will try to arrange the visit as soon as possible and I will discuss it with the respective Whips of the parties to make the necessary arrangements.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Education, refers to the Budget announcement of a 48 per cent increase in the value of a post-graduate award and the introduction of 100 new post-graduate awards. I also refer to the 20 per cent increase in tertiary and secondary allowances. I ask the Minister about the lack of any Press or other publicity for these very welcome decisions. I urge the Minister to communicate the details of all the new student allowances to all parts of Australia. What steps has the Minister taken to do this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising, with a Budget that did so much for families and for Australians generally, that particular items may not have been publicised. I take it that the point of the honourable senator's question is that there is a group of beneficiaries for whom this information is important. I agree with the honourable senator that there is not much point in increasing benefits for secondary, tertiary or post-graduate students, particularly since the increases are significant, unless they know about them and know how to apply for them and use them at the appropriate time. We, accordingly, will be quite active on campus, for example, to make sure that through the student Press students at least will know what the Government is offering and will know the details of a proposed student loans scheme, which will be an option in addition to the student assistance schemes which have been announced. It is important that the information on post-graduate awards be passed on because they were introduced as a result of representations from post-graduate groups and the order of the increase is sufficient to make these awards most attractive once again.

ANSWER.PARA: In order that proper communication did take place it was possible to meet the peak groups associated with tertiary education in Parliament House on Budget night. We met the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations, the Australian Union of Students, and a number of other groups such as the Federation of Australian University Staffing Associations and the Federation of College Academics-the staff groups-and were able to discuss with them what increases had been made and to make sure that they understood the details.

The honourable senator is correct; it will be necessary to make sure that both in schools and in the community, for those with children in the higher levels of secondary school, and on campus the very real benefits which this Budget has conferred on students be made properly known so that they can gain maximum benefit from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am in a quandary because, with the abolition by the Fraser Government of the ministry of housing, I do not know to whom to direct a question concerning housing.
—Senator Chaney.

—Thank you. Will Senator Chaney explain how the imposing of a new 7 1/2 per cent sales tax on construction equipment used by builders and a new 7 1/ 2 per cent sales tax on soft furnishings, curtains, sheets, blankets and towels purchased on the setting up of a home will help Australians trying to obtain a house and make it a home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has asked a question which I find a little surprising coming from him because he picks a very narrow area of disadvantage to the housing industry, knowing that in this Budget a very significant step has been taken to assist the housing industry and knowing that last May a series of measures was announced by the Government to assist that industry. I find the selectivity of his question surprising, coming as it does from someone who does not usually indulge in that sort of activity in this place.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that one of the major changes announced in the Budget was the concession on interest rates over 10 per cent which are being paid by all home purchasers. That, I think, is a far more significant contribution to reducing the cost to the user of housing than the relatively minor impost which has been referred to by the honourable senator. I remind him that in May of this year we announced a package of proposals which affect and help first home buyers . This included the housing deposit assistance scheme, which was introduced and under which a large number of payments have already been made. I really think that the honourable senator has picked out a very small factor when so many positives have been introduced either in the last housing package or in this Budget.

The general move towards a heavy reliance on indirect tax is one that the Government and the Treasurer have explained. I believe it is a move which is in the interests of the Australian economy and Australian people. I believe that the fewer exceptions to that move the better because it ensures that the tax can be spread as evenly as possible. I believe that the housing industry, like all industries, will benefit in the end from tax changes of the sort which have been promoted in this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. If in fact the tax on ordinary household items such as blankets, sheets, towels, curtains and soft furnishings is such a minor impost, why is it that the Government has delayed its imposition until 1 January? Has it anything to do with the prospect of an early election in this half of the financial year?

—Order! Before the Minister answers the question I remind honourable senators that more supplementary questions have been asked at the beginning of this session than has been the case in the past. I ask honourable senators to make sure that supplementary questions are really supplementary to the first question. I will allow that question to be answered but it really is another question.

—The reason for that delay is administrative and not the sort of reason that was suggested by the honourable senator in his question. It does involve some new provision in the law and for administrative reasons it could not be introduced immediately. If I may I will point to programs in my own Department. In common with the practice we have followed in the past, new programs are being introduced at a later date for the simple reason that they involve new systems and the establishment of changes which are not necessary when one is merely making adjustments to rates. So there is that form of staggering which will be found, not only in taxation provisions but also in things such as the welfare provisions, because there are administrative implications in many of the decisions which are taken.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to the announcement made on Tuesday night in respect of the proposed student loans scheme. Can the Minister tell the Senate what steps the Government has taken to ensure that the proposed scheme will benefit the most needy students? What provision has been made for those students who cannot gain employment on graduation and who will not be able to repay the loan debt at that time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The loans scheme which was announced on Tuesday night has a number of features. The most attractive feature for students will be one not mentioned by Senator Lajovic and that, of course, is that the interest rate will be subsidised by the Government to the extent of 5 per cent. So whatever the market rate of interest is, students will be asked to pay 5 per cent less on any money they borrow. That is a very real and most attractive benefit for those who wish to take up that loans option. The honourable senator asked a question specifically about those who are in need. The Government took a decision that it was proper to concentrate access to the loans scheme to those in need. Accordingly, there will be a means test to qualify people for a loan under the scheme. Meeting the means test which applies to all the student benefits at present would also qualify people for the loans scheme. In addition, there is an extra slightly more liberal means test which might allow other students to qualify.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the other part of Senator Lajovic's question about those who may be unemployed at graduation or may have difficulty getting employment, I think that would apply also to those who take some time to settle into a post-graduate lifestyle; maybe they have been married and have establishment expenses. The Government has decided that there will be a two-year repayment holiday. That is to say, people will not have to start repaying the loan until two years after graduation. That, of course, also means two years after discontinuation if they do not complete their course. Therefore, with those features, the loans scheme that has been proposed represents a real gain to students. It is an addition to and alongside the present Student Assistance Scheme. It has a significant interest subsidy and a two-year holiday from repayment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his answer to my Question on Notice No. 2192 in respect of the use of VIP jets, or the Royal Australian Air Force special purpose aircraft. I refer the Leader to that part of his answer which indicated that the Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, flew by VIP jet from Sydney to Armidale on 8 April 1982 at a cost to the taxpayer of $2,014.54, and that he flew without staff or government officials.

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Leader know that East-West Airlines Ltd flew four flights on this same route on that day, at 7.30 a.m., 2.30 p.m., 6.15 p.m. and 9.40 p.m., one of which should have been suitable to the Minister's timetable and that East-West Airlines charges a mere $68.50 for the trip, which takes one hour and 15 minutes ? Does the Leader also know that Mr Sinclair's indulgence in luxury at the taxpayers' expense has cost the taxpayers an extra $1,946.04? Can the Minister explain how this further instance of freeloading by the National Country Party conforms to the Prime Minister's hollow calls to the community for restraint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the specific question and its details, of course I cannot respond today because they relate to a particular flight apparently in April or thereabouts. I will refer to the responsible Minister the substance of the further inquiry by Senator Bolkus relating to the availability of commercial aircraft to see whether there is any additional information that should be made available. I have no doubt at all that had a commercial flight been available the Minister would have used it.

ANSWER.PARA: I make a point in general terms as to the use of VIP aircraft and the quoting of costs. It is a common matter-both sides of the Parliament do it- to quote a cost for a particular flight. The fact is that those aircraft belong to the RAAF . The RAAF has an allocation of flying time over the year and if there were no passengers on the aircraft at all, as is often the case day by day by day, they would be flying with their crews. For example, the Hawker Siddeleys are part of the navigation training scheme and the transportation of Ministers and others is used as part of that training scheme. So there is a certain amount of inbuilt illusion about the thought that it is an extra cost. I simply add that to put in perspective the cost of VIP flights.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In view of the declaration this week by the Queensland Government that unionism is not compulsory, which is in line with a decision of a former Chief Justice, Sir Mostyn Hanger, of some 15 years ago, will the Commonwealth make a similar response and affirm that unionism is not compulsory in Australia? Will the Commonwealth apply this decision rigorously in respect of employees of the Commonwealth and not covertly encourage its employees to join unions, as it has done in the past, but make it an act of free choice and also desist from collecting union fees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a strict sense I do not think unionism is compulsory in any part of Australia in the sense that I think under the various State and Commonwealth Acts which govern industrial relations in this country there are at least exemptions for conscientious objection. In other words, those people who in a positive sense have an objection in conscience to membership of a union can obtain some form of exemption. There are varying levels of compulsion apart from that. It would be well known to the honourable senator that legislation affecting this aspect of Commonwealth industrial relations was introduced earlier this year. It was sent off by the Senate to a Senate committee. We are awaiting the Senate committee's report on the inquiries that it has made into that legislation. The Government would not wish to revise its stance on this or any related question until it has seen the findings of that Senate committee report and has responded to them in the way that it is committed to do.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter raised by the honourable senator is one of some contention. He is probably aware of the recent incidents in Western Australia which relate to the attempts of the State Government of Western Australia to ensure that there is genuine freedom on the part of people in various industries not to join a union . He is probably aware of the actions which have been taken, including the removal of contracts in situations where employers have been co-operating with unions to achieve a closed shop. The matter is a difficult one. I will refer the question and the statements that it contains to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, for his consideration. I do point to the fact that in that strict sense a person who has a conscientious objection must escape from having to join a union but there are certainly plenty of elements in Australia, in both the unions, and among employers, who are prepared to promote a situation where there is very little choice for a person who wishes to be a member of a union. My understanding of the Commonwealth's own broad position in relation to the collection of union dues is that it has co-operated with a number of unions in providing deduction of union fees from salaries. That privilege has been removed in a number of cases where the behaviour of the union has been such that it has been thought that there has not been a properly co-operative approach to industrial relations. As I understand it, decisions are made on the basis of individual cases. As far as I know, no general policy is applied. I will check that point and let the honourable senator have a supplementary reply if it is necessary.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS: SURVEYS OF FOREIGN OWNERSHIP IN AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a Press release by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on 20 January 1982, in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I am requesting the Australian Bureau of Statistics to reintroduce the surveys measuring the extent of foreign ownership and control in sectors of the Australian economy that were discontinued in 1978.

Is it correct that now, eight months after that statement was made, these surveys have not been reintroduced? Is it correct that the Australian Bureau of Statistics has in fact not even received any instructions to reintroduce them? I ask the Minister whether the Treasurer intends to keep to his public undertaking ? If so, when does he propose to take appropriate action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of any circumstances surrounding the matters that were raised by Senator Siddons. If the statement were made publicly in January 1982 by the Treasurer that he was reintroducing these statistics on foreign ownership, I would assume that that information would flow to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. However, I will ask the Minister whether he wants to make some explanation about it. If any further information is available I will see that the Senate is advised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELECTROLYTIC ZINC CO. OF AUSTRALASIA LTD: EMPLOYMENT OFFER

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of an advertisement which appeared in a Swedish mining company's staff newspaper offering good earnings, paid air passages for workers and their families from Sweden to Australia and interest-free housing loans by the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australasia Ltd? This has been admitted by management as correct. What provision has been made for retrenched workers in Tasmania to be relocated and/ or retrained to fill other positions in the mining industry instead of importing labour at a time of high unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the advertisement referred to by the honourable senator. I am having a lot of trouble reading even one or two Australian newspapers a day without being able to refer to a Swedish publication. Nobody had drawn my attention to it prior to Senator Hearn's question. It does seem peculiar in the present employment situation in Australia to hear of the sort of advertisement to which the honourable senator has referred. I suppose that its existence reflects the odd fact that notwithstanding a level of unemployment that none of us finds satisfactory there are areas of shortage where particular skills are required. Of course, our current immigration program reflects that with a very heavy emphasis on the admission of people who have scarce skills. From the point of view of those who are unemployed, the availability of people with the requisite skills is very important. Very often the employment of less skilled labour is dependent upon the availability of the more skilled, so shortages in that field can have an unfortunate multiplier effect on those who are less equipped for skilled work but none the less are fit and ready for employment. Therefore, we do not wish to discourage people from seeking skilled labour overseas if it is not available in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I understand the point underlying the honourable senator's question. Obviously, we should be concerned to see that Australian labour is trained and able to take up the employment which is available. In that regard I point to the emphasis that has been put on training in the programs that are the responsibility of Mr Macphee's Department whose numbers have been increased considerably. I point also to the attempts which have been made within the portfolio responsibilities of Senator Peter Baume to improve the employability of people who are at work. The honourable senator raises issues which are of real complexity and also affect the trade union movement in its attitude to skilled training, apprenticeships and so on. I can merely say that I will refer the matter to Mr Macphee and ask him to give the honourable senator a considered reply to the points she has raised. However, I point to the various activities which have been undertaken by the Government, and are currently being undertaken by it, in an attempt to ensure that those Australians who have a skill gap are given an opportunity to bridge it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen an article on page 3 of today's Australian which cites comments by Justice Lusink relating to family law? I ask the Attorney whether he noted that Justice Lusink is reported as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The Family Court system at its best is a 'compromise' and at its worst a 'Band- Aid job' . . .
. . . the Family Law Court system was achieving only the 'tip of the iceberg' in success.
The article also reported Justice Lusink as saying:

. . . since the enactment of the Family Law Act and the establishment of the Family Court in 1976, judges had had to unlearn the meanings of innocence and guilt and administer a law which gives legal recognition to the colloquialism ' it takes two to tango'.
I also ask whether the Attorney saw this reported comment by the learned judge:
. . . the Family Law Act catapulted counsellors and lawyers into a 'brave new world', where they rapidly found their professions expanded beyond the traditional ambit of their training.
Did not the judge also, according to the report, suggest a need for a ministry of family affairs?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, are you getting to the end of your question?

—Yes, Mr President. Does the Attorney-General agree with these conclusions and, if so, will he consider holding off his amendments on family law until the Government has had a good look at them? Will he consider, in particular, the proposal that there be a ministry of family affairs? This is meant to indicate to the Senate that I am not abashed by Senator Missen's caning of last evening.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of Question Time today I saw a copy of the article referred to by Senator Martyr. I have not had an opportunity of reading it, but noted that Justice Lusink made some comments along those lines. I saw only some general comments about the Family Law Act being a compromise or perhaps a band-aid measure and so on. I would be very interested in studying what she has said and also perhaps getting some further explanations from her, or others, as to what this actually means, translated into concrete reform of the Family Law Act or the Family Court. I do not think that anybody has ever pretended that the Family Law Act is perfect, by any means, or that it is a panacea. Personally, I believe, and I think most people engaged in family law practice would believe, that people should think very carefully before they see divorce and the establishment of new relationships as providing an answer to problems.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the major objectives of the Family Law Act is to provide people with advice and help in the form of counsellors, so that they can be professionally assisted with their problems and so that we do not have the confrontationist adversary system of the old Matrimonial Causes Act. That is a personal view; no doubt other people had higher hopes for reform. Nevertheless, there is obviously a major problem in the community, in that there have been changes in moral and religious values. Probably large numbers of people do not agree with my views, or certainly with the views of Senator Martyr, and they require methods by which these questions that arise in relation to the custody of children, maintenance settlements and so on can be resolved. The Family Law Act and the Family Court were designed to meet those very clear problems. As I said, nobody is suggesting that the system is perfect. Indeed, the whole object of setting up a parliamentary committee, of which Senator Martyr was a member, was to address those problems. It presented a very valuable report and made a number of suggestions for reform of the law, many of which are incorporated in the Family Law Bill before the Parliament. I certainly have no intention of withdrawing that Bill simply because there has been some criticism of it by Senator Martyr or a few other people, even including Family Court judges.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I would hope that they would use it wisely and for the benefit of the people they represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time the Leader of the Government in the Senate answered a question which I put to him concerning the new and permanent Parliament House by, in effect, asking why I had not raised this matter before, saying that I had never raised it before, and saying that the Australian Democrats had always approved of the project. SPEECH.PARA: I regret in more ways than one that it falls to the lot of the Australian Democrats to be the sole dissenting voice in this matter.
