DEBATE.TITLE: INQUIRY INTO THE LONG TERM FUTURE OF CHRISTMAS ISLAND

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the inquiry into the long term future of Christmas Island is a very important report. It follows the determination of the last Labor Government to establish on Christmas Island a form of self-determination-a determination in which you, Mr Deputy President, played a very significant part-as a part of the process for the ultimate survival of the island in the new circumstances in which it found itself in the post-phosphate era. The report was commissioned by the Government with a view to looking at the long term future of Christmas Island. It is a very complex issue because of the long period of colonial administration and the distrust that inevitably follows Western influence. The inhabitants of Christmas Island were badly treated and were the subject of a form of personal feudal rule for a considerable period. The residual effect of that feudal rule is a distrust of the Australian Government. Probably that would be there regardless of the politics of the Australian Government, although it has to be conceded that certainly a lot more compassion and understanding would have been shown early in the post-colonial era by a Labor administration in Australia.

What comes out of this report, of course, is the environment and conditions which the residents of Christmas Island will face when the period of phosphate mining winds down and finally comes to an end. That poses a number of very difficult problems, not only for the Administration, which is still in the hands of the Australian and New Zealand Governments, but also for the residents of the Island, having regard to their ethnic problems and their ethnic composition. As the report indicates, the Union of Christmas Island Workers is a very important organisation. In fact, very little can take place in respect of the present and future government of the Island without the active approval of that organisation , which represents practically the entire work force on the Island. Although I find in the report some laudatory comments about the Union of Christmas Island Workers and its dedication to public interest on the Island, nevertheless I believe that there is a failure in the report to evaluate properly the role that that organisation can play. I do not believe that the changes can take place without the approval of that organisation because it does, in every sense, represent the views of the members of the organisation who comprise the great bulk of the work force.

The inquiry sees the future of Christmas Island in terms of some broad based economic and social development. That cannot be disputed. Clearly other forms of development have to take place on the Island in the post-phosphate era. We believe that the exploitation of the phosphate deposits should be managed so that they are productive for as long as possible. Phosphate is the source of income and prosperity. It is the source of income which provides increasingly high living standards. The recommendations contained in this report, whilst they have certain theoretical objectives, nevertheless will change the whole of the conditions, incomes and work environment if they are to be put into effect. I just wonder how, in 10 minutes, one can deal with all of the complexities of the problems which are raised in the report. The alternative industries suggested in the report include market gardening, fruit orchards, spices, pig farming, poultry farming, fishing, tourism, mariculture, coconut processing and liqueur production and flowers, which are entirely different from the environment in which the phosphate organisation has existed since it came into contact with the Western world a couple of centuries ago and which, of course, is the basis upon which the current culture and commercial enterprises operate. This development will be accompanied by considerable changes in the social life of the Island, including changing job prospects and life- style. Therefore, the transfer of some of the administrative functions to residents and the encouragement of long term residency seem to my party to be important features and have to be recognised by the Australian Government.

The inquiry has recommended that the Island community be given representation in the Australian Parliament through attachment to one of the electorates in the Australian Capital Territory. That is a recommendation that could at least give the community a voice in this place, one which at the moment is lacking except on occasions such as this when reports are considered. The problems involved in implementing these recommendations, and they are very varied and different and difficult, should not be underestimated. They involve a considerable upheaval in the lives of the Islanders, both from the point of view of employment and lifestyle. Of course, Western culture is beginning to have an influence upon the hitherto perhaps more romantic and isolated lifestyle that existed in the old days under the sort of feudal influence of paternalism.

The feasibility of many of the industries recommended is equally far from tested, nor is their success ensured. The inclusion of the Island electorally in the Australian Capital Territory raises many questions, not the least of which is the relevance of such a move to the Island's residents, having regard to the background of the 3,000 people who make up the population. The recommendation will probably also run into opposition from the Union of Christmas Island Workers, which quite rightly and properly seeks to protect the income, working conditions and future prospects of its members. There is clearly a great deal of conflict about the short and long term problems.

Nevertheless, this Parliament must recognise the increased significance of the Island to Australia, both strategically and morally. Whilst there is no threat to the Island's status at this time, there can of course be no guarantee that the situation in the Indian Ocean region will always remain as it is, having regard to the difficult international times that exist. So Australia's treatment of Christmas Island and its residents may well be central to any future territorial arrangements that could take place, having regard to its closeness to the whole of the South East Asian region.

The recommendations in the report do not hold out much encouragement for a large scale population permanently settling on the Island. There is evidence to show that people are moving in and out of the Island fairly regularly. Those industries envisaged will probably provide only for home consumption and do little to raise or maintain the living standards of the existing population. It is obvious that a considerable amount of further involvement by Australia in the Island's future will be of paramount importance if we are to fulfil our responsibilities in the post-colonial era and in the post-phosphate era. It has been a sheltered society, it has been an exploited society, and it has been a society with a style of living entirely different from that in Western culture. Therefore we do have a very big responsibility to look very closely at the development in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to talk about Christmas Island without making some reference to fertilisers, which we discussed last night. The point I wish to raise is that in the debate last night on the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1982 I questioned the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on the Government's attitude to the report entitled: Inquiry into the long-term future of Christmas Island. The Government has not yet determined its attitude. I wish to raise some points about the economy of the Island, which was dealt with in the report and which seem to me to be extremely important. I believe that the Government must eventually recognise that the legislation surrounding Christmas Island is ineffective and inefficient and that there should be an immediate review of all legislation concerning Christmas Island to enable that territory to enjoy at least some prospect of economic security.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt has already referred to the parts of the report suggesting alternative industries and the question marks which must be placed over those. I certainly agree with Senator Gietzelt that the proposed recommendations for new industries leave one very much with a question mark. I cannot see in any of the suggestions that have come forward any chance of the Island becoming an economic entity. The odd thing about it is that the transfer of Christmas Island from the control of Singapore in 1958 was carried out at the behest of farmers in Australia because they were concerned that they might lose a secure source of fertiliser. It would be ironic if the same group was eventually responsible for the destruction of the source of fertiliser.

Christmas Island, as a dependency of Australia, is in a somewhat difficult position in that a number of Australian Acts apply to it and a number do not. I will give the Senate an example. In 1973 the Navigation Act was extended to apply to Christmas Island. This means that phosphate on Christmas Island must be carried on Australian National Line ships. ANL currently is charging $27.65 per tonne of rock carried from Christmas Island to Australia. According to the Shipping News, a ship carrying 25,000 tonnes of rock will be arriving from Jordan on 4 or 5 September. The freight rate applying to that ship is $10.75 per tonne. In other words, there is a problem in relation to applying that Act to Christmas Island because it puts an impost on Christmas Island rock and makes it uncompetitive. That was a decision of this Parliament to make a part of Australia's territory uncompetitive.

The Minister for Social Security in response to a query I raised last night said that in fact steps could be taken to implement the provisions of the Customs tariff anti-dumping legislation or the Customs tariff countervailing duties which passed through the Senate last night. It so happens that that legislation does not apply to Christmas Island. This means that Christmas Island , as an Australian territory, is not able to take action under that legislation. What might Christmas Island do? It could be entitled to third party status under Article 12 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade anti-dumping code. That may be a way out. For example, if New Zealand runs into difficulty it could apply to Australia in relation to something which is coming into Australia from, say, Singapore. Unfortunately for Christmas Island any move to seek entitlement under Article 12 of GATT must be agreed to by the Government. In this case the Government technically happens to be the Administrator and the Administrator is in a Ministry run by a National Country Party Minister. So the Administrator has to go to a Minister wearing one hat and ask him, while wearing his other hat, to do something that he has already agreed not to do. I think the Customs legislation which has just been passed by the Senate raises a problem of legislative concern to the Senate in that not only Christmas Island but also many other Australian territories suffer from the fact that some legislation applies to them, often to their disadvantage, whereas other legislation, some of which would be to their advantage, does not apply to them. I believe the Government has an obligation in this regard to carry out a complete review of all legislation which affects our territories to make sure that this invidious situation is not allowed to continue.

The inquiry raised some other matters in relation to the economy, particularly the long term viability of the Island when the phosphate supply has run down. It suggests a movement towards farming and other agricultural development. We have to look much more imaginatively at the development of the Territories of Australia, not in terms of traditional economic development but in terms of innovative development. Christmas Island, for example, would be a place to look at, as we have done with the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, with a view to assisting Australia and the Territory itself in the provision of a government resource which could become crucial to the economy of the Territory and could provide a stabilising element, because it is Government funded and will continue to operate because of the benefit that it will provide to the people of Australia. I believe that is one area that again falls within the Government's purview and indeed Government actions. I believe that suggestions that farming or any other activity may start up smacks a little of crossing one's fingers and hoping that something will occur.

Finally, I believe the whole of Australia has an obligation, a very important obligation, to the people of Christmas Island to make sure that the island remains an economic entity. We have derived vast benefits from Christmas Island for our agricultural industry over a considerable period. I believe it would be only just that, whatever happens to the economy of Christmas Island, the Australian nation does not look at it purely in economic terms. We should look at it also in terms of justice, in terms of what we owe to the island, what we have taken out of it and the products that we have been able to use, often at extremely low prices and often produced with by adopting certain labour practices which could only be described as verging on slavery. We have indeed benefitted enormously at the expense of other people. I believe that ought to weigh heavily with the Government when it is looking at this report. We hope that in the very near future it may give us its definitive view, which will be imaginative, innovative and just.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Initially I would like to endorse the remarks of Senator Macklin. I congratulate him on his very explicit and useful references to the anomalies and inconsistencies which have bedevilled Christmas Island for many decades. I find the report that is before us at the moment, the second report of the Sweetland Commission of Inquiry into the Viability of the Christmas Island Phosphate Industry, very interesting, mostly constructive and, as far as I am aware, tolerably accurate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly on just two or three aspects of the report. I am not able to indicate whether the new industries which are being suggested for Christmas Island, particularly primary industries, are feasible but I do have the experience which leads me to believe that it would be a delightful place to develop in respect of tourism. From my experience it is one of the few places in the world where one can really get away from it all, and quite literally too because there is only one plane a fortnight out of Perth to Christmas Island. One can get there a little more easily via Singapore. Christmas Island is distinct from other tropical paradises of which we know and which have their own industrial and social problems. It has certainly had its problems over the years . We have seen more recently the workers getting on top of those problems. The problems are beginning to be resolved.

I can assure honourable senators that it is a most cheering experience to witness the improvements that have been achieved over the last few years principally, almost solely, as a result of the industrial action that has been taken by the Union of Christmas Island Workers since its inception in 1975. Some of Mr Sweetland's remarks might be construed as being a little critical of the Union of Christmas Island Workers. I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the first Sweetland report, which drew, with no doubt whatsoever, the picture of the previous administration as 'colonial, outmoded and repugnant'. When the Union of Christmas Island Workers began taking action to improve the living standards of the workers on that island, to improve their wages and to bring them up to parity with Australian workers, it was a new world for the people living there, who previously, as Senator Macklin indicated, had been treated as veritable slaves. The low wages, poor working conditions and shocking class distinctions on the island had to be seen to be believed. It is really only since 1980 that there have been marked changes. Prior to that the situation was, as Mr Sweetland remarked, repugnant in the extreme.

I think perhaps some credit should be given also to the West Australian Trades and Labour Council which has provided industrial and social support not just for the unionists on the island but also for the unionists who come to Western Australia on leave or who ultimately settle there. Mr Sweetland commented that the Union of Christmas Island Workers speaks with one voice for the wages employees on any issue it chooses. I see no objection to that. The previous situation was that the British Phosphate Commission spoke with its most appallingly class-ridden and dictatorial voice on behalf of the shareholders, certainly not on behalf of the workers or their families on Christmas Island. Mr Sweetland does admit that the leadership of the Union of Christmas Island Workers has shown commendable public spirit in many of its campaigns. For example, $26,000 was raised by members to pay for a spectrometer for the Royal Perth Hospital. The Union recently launched a campaign to raise funds for renovations to the present community hall. One could add to that countless instances of workers and their families being assisted by the Union of Christmas Island Workers. I am disappointed that I do not have time in which to fill out the picture a little more fully. However, this inquiry made a recommendation in relation to Federal representation for workers on Christmas Island. The recommendation states:

That Christmas Island residents who are Australian citizens be permitted to vote in Federal elections by attaching Christmas Island to one of the Australian Capital Territory . . . electorates (Canberra or Fraser).

There may be good reasons for this recommendation. But in view of the fact that the majority of workers on Christmas Island identify very closely with Western Australia; in view of the fact that Western Australian politicians now make representations on behalf of Christmas Island workers and their families; and in view of the fact that the majority of them eventually will become constituents of Western Australia, it seems to me a little more thought should be given to deciding whether Christmas Island should be part of a Western Australian electorate. In the short term that would certainly have the effect of making Christmas Island a little more accessible to Western Australian politicians who currently are able to use their international travelling privileges to get to Christmas Island but who otherwise must use their own resources. The political and administrative structures of Christmas Island is described in the report. The recommendation relating to this states:
. . . political activity on Christmas Island should be structured at three levels:
Federally, through inclusion in a Canberra electorate;
Territorially, through a Territorial advisory body charged with advising the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment . . .
locally, through an established local government authority with normal local government powers and authority.

In view of the fact that the Union of Christmas Island Workers has been the de facto and, might I add, elected local government authority for some years now it seems to me that at the very least the Union should be involved closely in any plans for subsequent restructuring of the Island's political and administrative bodies. I urge that this be the case.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY MEDICINE PROGRAM COMMITTEE OF REVIEW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Family Medicine Program is one about which there has been some considerable controversy in recent months. It is a program about which a lot of people have felt very strongly. It has been opposed by some sections of the community and vigorously supported by others. People have maintained that it would be done away with completely and others believe that it is not even offering enough in what it attempts to do. Traditional medicine programs, certainly since they were taken over by men, have tended to be directed to preparing doctors to fight diseases, to curing people's physiological ills and to doing what little we can do at the moment for basic psychological ills.

Traditional medicine programs too have tended to be rather elitist with at least some faculty members in the departments of medicine in some universities in this country tending to foster an attitude of superiority amongst medical undergraduates. Indeed, I had regaled to me recently a story of the head of one medical faculty-I will not mention the university concerned-who traditionally begins his lecture to first year medical undergraduates by pointing out that they are indeed the creme de la creme of the university, should regard themselves as such and never forget it. One can only imagine what that does to the psyche of the students hearing it. Fortunately for most patients in the community there has been an increasing demand in the community lately for medicine and medical training to become more attuned to the patient as a person rather than as a set of symptoms or a bunch of organs which may or may not be operating efficiently. The family medicine program was one scheme designed to achieve this.

I am pleased to note from the report that something like 65 per cent of doctors entering general practice in recent years have had some family medicine training . However, funding has been limited and is seen by many as grossly insufficient. The Family Medicine Program, as the introduction to this report says, is a post- graduate vocational training program directed essentially, but not exclusively, to doctors making an initial entry into general practice. It was established in 1973, and is funded by the Australian Government through the Commonwealth Department of Health. It is based, of course, on the premise that vocational training in family health should be received by doctors who are going into general practice because they are the sorts of problems that they are likely to be confronted with in the main. I see it and a lot of other people see it as a trend leading away from an unfortunate tendency that has developed in this country and overseas countries recently of doctors tending to specialise partly because there is more money involved in specialist work-hence, it is more prestigious-and, partly, because knowing more and more about less and less has become the norm these days. Therefore, it is pleasing to note that this review-I hope the last in a long line-has come out with conclusions and recommendations that are strongly in favour of the retention of the Family Medicine Program. In particular, I refer to the conclusions and recommendations on page 62, under item 4.7. Point 1 states quite categorically:
Family Medicine Program

There is a need for vocational training for medical practitioners entering general practice. This conclusion was the virtually unanimous view of all individuals and organisations which responded to this term of reference. This opinion was also expressed by the Seminar on Intern Training in New South Wales held in 1979 and the First Australian Conference on Post Graduate Medical Education (1960). It is also the view of the Australian Medical Association, The British Medical Association Working Party of 1976 and The General Medical Council of Great Britain. It is also the view of all State Health Commissions or Health Departments.

One wonders then why we must have another review to see whether the Family Medicine Program is worth while and needs to be maintained when there seems to be an overwhelming body of opinion, both in this country and internationally, that it is a 'good thing'. Point 2 states:
The need will continue to exist because:
(i) Universities do not see their role as implying any obligation to produce a competent doctor at the point of graduation.

That is a rather astonishing, but unfortunately also accurate, remark by the committee about some university medical departments. It certainly confirms the point I made earlier when I referred to that anecdote. Point 2 continues:

(ii) In consonance with this view undergraduate education in Medicine is structured to provide a corpus of scientific and clinical knowledge, on which further vocational training towards competence can be based. It is very doubtful if this attitude will change in the foreseeable future, as it reflects current tertiary education philosophy.
Point 3 states:
The Committee agrees with these views and recommends that such vocational training should be available to all graduates after their intern year who wish to enter general practice.

In conclusion, we certainly support these recommendations by the Committee of Review of the Family Medicine Program. They are certainly in line with the policy of the Australian Democrats on health, which maintains that community health relating to human beings as human beings, and not as symptoms, is an important element. We support wholeheartedly the comments, conclusions and recommendations made in the review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I refer the Senate to a couple of items of the report which deal with the nature and function of the Services Canteen Trust Fund. I also wish to point to one of the impending measures announced by the Government, a measure that will hamper seriously the activities of the fund. The fund was established from the profits and assets of the Navy, Army and Air Force Canteen Services as they operated during the Second World War. These, with other subsidiary funds, totalled at the end of the war a considerable amount of money. They are administered by a volunteer trust fund, which disburses, from accumulated capital, welfare services of various kinds. In particular, it provides for men, women and dependants in needy circumstances. It also provides educational assistance for children, particularly those suffering from serious afflictions.

In other words, money which came from servicemen during that war was put into a fund to assist people after the war. The trustees of the fund have drawn attention to the problem that the fund spends the vast bulk of its money on recently bereaved widows and orphans, particularly those in need of immediate cash and grants towards funeral expenses-something that I believe would have the total support of the community. The problem is that the fund will run out of money in the foreseeable future, yet that need will continue to exist and will not reach its peak until 1990. Therefore, the fund would presumably have the support of all honourable senators.

A resolution taken at the recent Returned Services League Ex-Service Organisations' Conference points to what I believe is an aspect of penny- pinching which must be condemned by all honourable senators. It stated:

This Conference notes with great concern the intention of the Auditor-General's Department to levy charges for the annual audit of accounts of the Services Canteen Trust Fund. Indications are that the scale of charges is excessive in relation to the task involved. Furthermore, the resources of the Fund are diminishing at a time when the demand on its resources from recently bereaved widows and orphans is increasing.

In other words, the Government intends to require a fund that consists solely of moneys provided by ex-servicemen during the war and is being used to benefit widows and orphans to meet the cost-an excessive cost at that-of auditing the accounts, basically a relatively simple proposition. Although I cannot give honourable senators the exact amounts involved, the estimates that I have seen strike me as being at a level that would get a private practitioner into serious trouble with his profession.

I wonder whether the Government, in its excessive zeal to make users pay, has really thought about the nature and function of this particular fund. In the report, the trustees of the fund point to a need which will go beyond the period of its existence. I believe that, rather than penalise the operation of such a fund, which is philanthropic in nature, which has no costs of administration- many people devote an enormous amount of time, work and energy to helping past comrades of the Second World War-and whose activity is directed at widows and orphans of ex-servicemen, the Government should certainly have announced its intention not only of meeting that need but also of looking at ways and means of continuing the operation of the fund until at least after its peak demand point in 1990. In other words, it would seek to put renewed amounts into that fund to allow it at least to go into the year 2000 to provide for those immediate cash needs of widows and orphans. Instead, we find a penny-pinching operation, the type of thing that Scrooge would certainly have been very pleased to engage in, in an area where people cannot fight back, in an area where a lot of other people are putting in their time and their energies. I would have thought that the Government at least could have matched in a reasonable way those types of voluntary activities carried out by so many people in the community instead of seeking by a back-door method to penalise voluntary activity, to penalise ex- servicemen yet again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF CRIMINAL INTELLIGENCE AGREEMENT 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
At the outset, I seek leave to have the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence Agreement incorporated in Hansard. I understand I have the approval of the Government.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
An Agreement made the sixth day of February 1981.
Between: The Commonwealth of Australia (in this Agreement called ''the Commonwealth'') of the first part,
The State of New South Wales of the second part,
The State of Victoria of the third part,
The State of Queensland of the fourth part,
The State of South Australia of the fifth part,
The State of Western Australia of the sixth part,

The State of Tasmania of the seventh part, (each of the parties of the second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh parts being in this Agreement referred to as a ''State'' and, except where the context otherwise indicates, the expression ''the States'' herinafter used shall mean all of such parties), and the Northern Territory of Australia (in this Agreement called the ''Territory'') of the eighth part whereby it is agreed as follows-
Definitions
1. In this Agreement subject to the context-
''ABCI'' means the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence formed pursuant to Clause 2 hereof;
''organised crime'' means the activities of any group of persons or organisations involved or suspected of being involved in a criminal conspiracy;
''criminal intelligence'' means information with respect to organised crime or persons who may be involved in organised criminal activity.
Establishment of ABCI
2. (1) The parties hereto hereby join together to form an organisation to be known as the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence.

(2) The role of the ABCI is to provide facilities for the collection, collation , analysis and dissemination of criminal intelligence with a view to providing such intelligence to the Police Forces of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territory to enable them to combat organised crime in Australia and, in particular, to assist them to combat illicit drug trafficking.
Functions of the ABCI
3. The functions of the ABCI are to:
(a) maintain a repository of criminal intelligence;
(b) research and correlate material for inclusion in criminal intelligence files and process relevant correspondece;
(c) prepare and maintain a record of and distribute criminal intelligence on the movements of selected individuals involved or suspected of being involved in organised crime;
(d) prepare, maintain and distribute a master name index;

(e) establish and maintain liaison in matters of criminal intelligence with Crime Intelligence Bureaux of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territory and units of their appropriate Government agencies and foreign law enforcement agencies;

(f) analyse intelligence reports of interest and disseminate such intelligence to the interested police forces of the Commonwealth, the State and the Territory through the intelligence organisations of such forces;

(g) identify persons, organisations, or practices which, in the national interest, require or warrant investigation and refer same to the Commissioner or Commissioners of the relevant police force or forces for appropriate operational action;
(h) make (through the Management Committee (as hereinafter defined) to the Australian Police Ministers' Council) proposals for legislative changes to combat organised crime.
Specific Intelligence Interests
4. The specific intelligence interests of the ABCI include the following major areas in so far as they have an interstate, national or international connotation:
(a) illicit drug trafficking;

(b) the places of business of known criminals and persons or organisations concerned in organised crime and the financial interests of such persons and organisations in related legitimate and/or illegitimate businesses;
(c) illicit gambling and the infiltration of criminal figures into licit gambling;
(d) pressures exercised to control or influence persons or organisations with a view to corruption or to extorting money and/or property or obtaining advantage;
(e) fraudulent dealings in shares or securities and company fraud;
(f) national and international movement of profits of organised crime;
(g) corruption in public life;
(h) counterfeiting;
(i) fraudulent bankruptcies and arson;
(j) organised theft and fraud;
(k) usurious loans ('loan sharking');
(l) prostitution within the area of organised crime;
(m) any other business interest activity with an organised crime connotation; and
(n) the movement of persons connected with organised crime to and from Australia and their activities within and without Australia.
Structure and Organisation
5. (1) The ABCI shall consist of-
(a) a Management Committee (hereinafter called ''the Management Committee'') comprised of the Commissioners of the Police Forces of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territory; and
(b) a Directorate (hereinafter called ''the Directorate'') comprising:
(i) a Director and a Deputy Director each appointed by the Management Committee and seconded from a Police Force of the Commonwealth, the States or the Territory;
(ii) police officers seconded from the Police Forces of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territory;
(iii) as appropriate, officers seconded from the Departments of Immigration and Transport and the Bureau of Customs of the Commonwealth;
(iv) permanent administrative staff provided by the Commonwealth;
(v) members co-opted from agencies of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territory as determined by the Management Committee from time to time.

(2) The Commissioners of Police of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territory shall provide operational field units within their respective organisations to respond to tasks and priorities required by the Management Committee through the Directorate. Such units may be supplemented, as necessary, by officers seconded from other police forces on a basis to be agreed by the Commissioners of Police concerned.
(3) At the discretion of the relevant Commissioner, each police force participating in the ABCI may confer special constable powers on police officers seconded to the ABCI.
Functions of the Management Committee
6. Subject to the provisions of clause 7M (1), the functions of the Management Committee are to-
(a) oversee the general administration and performance of the functions of the ABCI;
(b) determine policy, methods and procedures necessary for the effective functioning of the ABCI;

(c) subject to this Agreement and any relevant legislation, determine the numbers of officers to be seconded from Commonwealth, State and Territory police forces and other agencies to the ABCI and the terms and conditions and disciplinary arrangement of such secondments;
(d) subject to any relevant legislation, determine the duties of the Director, Deputy Director and other members of the Directorate;

(e) subject to any relevant legislation, determine the eligibility, suitability and secondment of all members and staff, including administrative staff, of the Directorate and, in its discretion, terminate any appointment of a member or to the staff thereof;
(f) consider recommendations as to persons, organisations and activities for investigation by the ABCI and select therefrom those against which operational activities should be instigated;
(g) as necessary, revise the functioning of the system;
(h) examine management control, change of procedures and other relevant matters ;
(i) make appropriate recommendations to relevant authorities to improve the effectiveness of the ABCI
(j) as soon as possible after the formation of the ABCI-

(i) in the light of any problems that may arise from seconded officers having varying requirements from their parent forces as regards communication of information, submit to the Australian Police Ministers' Council, for its approval, policy guidelines relating to the collection, maintenance, use and dissemination of information;
(ii) formulate and report to the Australian Police Ministers' Council on procedures for the security and protection of information and intelligence held by the ABCI.
Administration and Control

7. (1) It is the express intention of the parties to this agreement that ultimate responsibility for the ABCI in matters of policy shall rest with the Australian Police Ministers' Council and therefore the Australian Police Ministers' Council may in respect of the functions of the ABCI give general directions of policy including budgeting policy to the Management Committee.

(2) Further it is the express intention of the parties to this agreement that the administration and operation of the ABCI and the performance of its functions are to be independent of any one participating Government or agency. In this respect-
(a) the Directorate of the ABCI is to be located in the Australian Capital Territory;
(b) the Management Committee is to have sole direction and control of the Bureau's administration and operations;

(c) in the performance of their duties with the ABCI, all staff of the ABCI shall be responsible to the Director during the period of service with the ABCI and shall be bound to preserve confidentiality after service with the ABCI has terminated;
(d) there shall be no discrimination in the administration or operations of the ABCI in favour of, or against, any of the police forces of the Commonwealth, the States or the Territory;

(e) the police forces of the parties hereto are to have equal access to intelligence held by the ABCI. In particular, no intelligence is to be received on the basis that it is subject to any discriminatory condition in respect of its release to the police force of any party hereto;

(f) the Management Committee shall report annually to the Australian Police Minister' Council on the administration and functioning of the ABCI and, in addition, shall furnish to the said Council as and when required by it, such reports as it requests relating to the administration and functioning of the ABCI.
Proceedings of the Management Committee
8. (1) (a) There shall be a chairman of the Management Committee who shall be elected by the Management Committee.
(b) The Chairman of the committee shall rotate amongst the members in an order decided by the members.
(c) A member elected as Chairman shall hold office for a term not exceeding one year.

(d) Where the Chairman is absent from a meeting, the Management Committee shall elect another member who is present at that meeting to act temporarily as Chairman of that meeting without affecting the eligibility of such member for election as Chairman at the next succeeding election of the Chairman.

(2) Any three members of the Management Committee shall constitute a quorum of the Management Committee for the exercise of its powers at any meeting provided that a member may, at any time, appoint in writing a deputy to act in his absence, and any deputy so appointed, may, in the absence of the member, exercise all the powers and functions of the member and his presence shall be deemed the presence of the member.
(3) At a meeting of the Management Committee, each member (including the Chairman) shall have one vote. The Chairman shall not have a casting vote.
(4) The decisions of the Management Committee shall be by majority vote.
(5) The Management Committee shall meet at least once in every year.
Financial Arrangements

9. (1) In so far as legal and accounting requirements of the parties hereto permit, the ABCI is to be funded in a way which recognises its operational independence from any one participating Government or agency of a participating Government;
(2) Subject to sub-clause (3), hereof, the costs of establishing and operating the ABCI are to be shared on a basis to be agreed by the parties hereto;
(3) The following is to form the basis of the cost sharing agreement:
(a) Costs to be met by the Commonwealth:
(i) office accommodation for the Directorate in the Australian Capital Territory;
(ii) other normal establishment costs for Directorate (for example, furniture, equipment, transport);
(iii) operational costs (for example travel and allowances), where costs are directly attributable to the national operations of the ABCI;
(iv) salaries for the Director and Deputy Director;
(v) any additional salary and allowances associated with a seconded State or Territory officer's duty with the Directorate (for example rent and travel costs associated with appointment);
(vi) salaries and allowances as appropriate for permanent administrative support staff for Directorate;
(vii) salaries and allowances as appropriate for Australian Federal Police and other Commonwealth officers seconded to the Directorate; and
(viii) salaries and allowances and equipment costs of any officers of the Australian Federal Police seconded to the States and Territory.
(b) Costs to be met by the States and the Territory:
(i) any special facilities required by a State or the territory in the Directorate;
(ii) travel specifically requested by a State or the Territory;
(iii) salaries and normal allowances for State or Territory officers to the Directorate;
(iv) travel and other costs associated with meetings of the Management Committee; and
(v) all operational costs associated with State and Territory units including salaries and allowances for officers of a State or Territory.
Variation

10. The parties hereto agree that this Agreement may be varied from time to time by the members of the Australian Police Ministers' Council. A variation pursuant to this Clause shall be in writing, signed by all members of the Australian Police Ministers' Council and notice thereof shall immediately following such signatures be given to the parties hereto.
Withdrawal
11. A party hereto may by written notice to all other parties withdraw from the ABCI. Such notice shall take effect six months from the date thereof.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF this Agreement has been respectively signed for an on behalf of the parties as at the day and year first above written

TALK.START.PARA: —This agreement appears to have been tabled in response to a request made by me in this chamber as early as 8 April 1981. Subsequent correspondence I have had with the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, indicates that the Australian Police Ministers' Council, which is the Federal-State body responsible for the signing of this agreement establishing the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, did in fact resolve to have the document tabled. In doing so it responded favourably to my request to that effect. It is a very belated production of what is, on any view, an extremely important document with very far-reaching consequences for criminal law enforcement in this country. The composition of the list of signatories to the agreement, representing as it does the composition of the Police Ministers' Council at the time of its signing on 6 February 1981, is not such as to give one enormous confidence as to the content of the agreement. The signatories include Bill Hassell, then the Police Minister in Western Australia, and Russell Hinze, the then Minister for Police in Queensland, of whom it will be recalled that he describes his own qualifications for that job as 'being 20 stone, having flat feet and no brains'. I am not suggesting that the whole of this document reflects that order of competence or that order of credibility, but it is nonetheless a very superficial document touching only very lightly on many matters which must be of very grave concern to those of us in the community at large with an interest in effective law enforcement on the one hand but sensitive law enforcement on the other.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three matters to which I want to draw attention. The first is the question of political accountability for what this Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence actually does. It has been established as a joint body. The document expressly states in clause 7 that ultimate responsibility for the ABCI in matters of policy shall rest with the Australian Police Ministers' Council; that is, the seven governments represented by their police Ministers at that time. Clause 7 (2) further states that the ABCI shall be independent of any one participating government or agency-independent in every respect. So far as administrative accountability or responsibility is concerned, the only provision is for the management committee of the organisation to report annually to the Australian Police Ministers' Council. There is no provision anywhere in the agreement for any of the participating governments to report to any of the Parliaments of the various participating States. As a result there is absolutely no guarantee whatsoever that any aspect of the agency's operations will ever come to public light. The only public account of what it is all about that we have had so far is this particular document tabled in the Senate today. Apart from that, there have simply been hints and suggestions as to what is going on.

I suggest that that is simply not good enough. The track record of some of the individual governments and Ministers concerned is not such as to give one any confidence as to their effective responsibility or the effectiveness of the processes of accountability so far as just one government is concerned, but when we have seven governments participating, plus the Northern Territory thrown in for good measure, we have an enormous problem in pinning down the responsibility for anything that might prove to go wrong, either in terms of an overreach in the exercise of the powers of this body or in terms of some aspect of financial or other maladministration. The truth of the matter is, and I suppose it is a problem endemic to federalism, that accountability to everyone can so often in practice mean accountability to no one. I simply make the constructive point in this respect that, if nothing else, there should at least be agreement by the responsible governing body of this bureau-namely the Police Ministers' Council- that each one of the participating governments should table some appropriate annual report in its respective parliament to enable at least that much opportunity for scrutiny over what is going on on a regular, systematic basis.

The second point I make goes to the scope of the operations and powers of the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. The creation of the organisation arose out of a recommendation of the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. The recommendation of the Williams Royal Commission was confined to the establishment of a drug intelligence body. What we have with this organisation becomes very clear when one stops to read clause 4. The agreement has been incorporated in Hansard so I will not waste time spelling it out, but it lists a wide variety of criminal subject areas involving generally the notion of organised crime. It becomes apparent that this body has been established with a much wider purpose and with a much wider jurisdiction than simply that of matters relating to drug trafficking. I do not say that that in itself is a bad thing. I do say, however, that there has been an element of dissimulation in the way in which the establishment of this body has been justified, certainly by the Commonwealth Government and I believe by a number of the State governments as well, referring as they constantly have to this body being created in the implementation of a recommendation of the Williams Royal Commission. In fact, it goes much further than that. It will have many more functions than those simply related to the scrutiny of the illicit drug trafficking, crucial as that problem is and related as it is to other areas of other criminal activity. To that extent there ought to be a little less coyness on the part of governments in explaining what is going on. The other point I make about the powers or the scope of the Bureau's operation-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proposing to move any substantive motion in relation to the Senate indicating a view with regard to the accountability aspect?

—I was not proposing specifically to do so. I would be indebted to Senator Rae if he leapt to his feet at the conclusion of my remarks and offered something along those lines. I think it does flow naturally out of what I have said and obviously I would support any such motion. I believe others in this chamber would, too. As to the powers of the organisation, which bear upon the accountability question, to the extent that new powers are being exercised, it is obvious that the powers at the moment are limited to the compilation and dissemination of criminal intelligence data to the participating governments, but various suggestions have been made public by the Director of the Organisation, Mr Fred Sylvester, formerly of the Victoria Police, that the bureau itself ought to have powers of telephone tapping, those powers being indispensable to the effective operation of any criminal intelligence outfit and in particular indispensable to the operation of a criminal intelligence bureau in a place such as Australia, where there has been a long history of jealousies and rivalries between the various police agencies. That suggestion about wire tapping powers was made on the second day of the hearings of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking in 1981 and reported in the Press on 10 September last year. I believe suggestions of that kind do give one grave cause for concern again about what kind of an animal it is that we have here in the agency created by this agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The third and final point relates to safeguards against misuse of power by this organisation, which is a particularly important consideration given both the lack of accountability in a direct way to any particular government and the questions that I have been raising about the scope of its operations and powers. There are very limited statements of intention about creating such safeguards in the document itself. The best we have is clause 6(j), which senators can read when they see it in Hansard, suggesting that guidelines be prepared for the Police Ministers' Council. There are a number of other issues, including those raised in particular by the Law Reform Commission in its criminal investigation report in 1975 about personal access to sensitive data, the kind of machinery that should and ought to be established to produce redress in cases in which there is an abuse of the police power in relation to such dissemination.

We welcome the tabling of this document and the information that it provides, but there is an awful lot more information that needs to be supplied if this Parliament can have confidence that we do not have here a very dangerous institution indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I interjected during Senator Evans's speech to inquire whether he proposed to move a substantive motion in relation to the question of accountability in the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence agreement. As I have not yet a copy of the agreement, I find it hard to draft an appropriate provision on the run, as it were, and I would just indicate that it is something that I would like to see pursued and I propose to seek an appropriate opportunity. It seems to me that one of the problems about which the Senate has continually expressed concern is the ensuring of appropriate accountability. If, as Senator Evans has indicated, the agreement is defective in that way, I think it would not be inappropriate for the Senate to express a view about it. I would seek opportunity to have that view expressed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: CODE OF PRACTICE FOR THE SAFE TRANSPORT OF RADIOACTIVE SUBSTANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I think it is very useful and good that this code has come into being. It is something for which I have asked in this place a number of times in recent years , because there have been some incidents, including a road accident at Port Macquarie, in which it has been brought home to us most pointedly that there should be some overall supervision of the way in which radioactive materials are carried around in Australia. I am a little concerned at the statement from the Minister. It has the fault of many ministerial statements of not really giving people much information. In a complex technical matter of this type, I should have preferred to see some masterly statement by the Minister which gave the Australian people a pretty good idea of just what was going on in this area, and explaining, for instance, the reference in the prelude to the report, 'Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances':
In this Code of Practice-'radioactive substance' means a substance the radioactivity of which exceeds 74,000 becquerels per kilogram of the substance.

I have made inquiries about that, and I find that is a very low figure and one I think most people would approve of. It takes into account most radioactive materials which could be dangerous. But it would be nice to feel that ministerial statements covering these sorts of reports would at least elucidate some points rather than obscure or merely comment on the presentation of a report such as this, which is of massive importance to society, to explain it a little more.

I have had an initial look at the report. I have not had much time to look at it, and I am certainly not a physicist. Most of it is above my head. I confess that freely. I should like my remarks to be taken in that context, so that if I have made errors through lack of understanding, it has only been in the interest of raising matters which seem at first sight to be important.
I go to page 2, section 107. It is fairly straightforward. It says:

A consignment of radioactive materials which does not satisfy all the applicable requirements of these Regulations must be made only under special arrangement which requires multilateral approval. The special arrangements shall be adequate to ensure that the overall level of safety in transport is at least equivalent to that which would be provided if all the applicable requirements of the Regulations had been met.

As in so much drafting of this kind, awkward sentences are involved. These seem to say that it is perfectly okay to leave out various things which are thought important enough to be requirements in this code, and yet some other authority, which is not defined, and on a multilateral basis, which is also not defined, can say: 'No, that is okay. In our opinion the overall level of safety for the transport of this thing is okay in spite of those things being left out, and indeed, we make the independent, quite subjective assessment that the safety is the same as would have been provided if they had been met'. How inconsistent can one get? It seems a reductio ad absurdum situation when we can have a document which makes that kind of statement and it is expected to be taken seriously.

Of rather more concern is section 108 on page 2 which says something which I think will distress many people in Australia, and it certainly distressed me that it appears in a report on the safe transport of radioactive substances in Australia. That means the carrying backwards and forwards through this country of radioactive substances. In the report we have this statement:
The transport of explosive radioactive materials shall be permitted only under special arrangement.

I thought that we had had time and again in the Senate assurances from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) and others that we will not enrich uranium to explosive quality, that there is no question of that kind of material being in Australia. Why, then, has it been thought necessary to bring that provision into this code? It is something that could have been added later if necessary. The fact that it is there now worries me. Where are these explosive radioactive materials going to come from? Where are they going to go? Would they be nuclear weapons being transported around Australia? That is the only thing they could be, with the exception of materials used for making a bomb for civil purposes, perhaps for some sort of excavation work. That has been canvassed around the world in the past, but to my knowledge nobody has been silly enough actually to do it.

Explosive radioactive materials are those which are sufficiently enriched to create an explosion and are, in fact, the ingredients of bombs or part of the facilities for making the ingredients of bombs. Paragraph 121 on page 5 raises a matter of interest. It refers to uranium or thorium ores. I am glad to see that reference included. I believe it will have a relevance to honourable senators from Western Australia and others who are quite interested in monazite exports from Western Australia. It is a fact that by 1985 reactors using thorium will be in operation. I would like to feel that if the Government intends to comment on this report it will explain to us the relevance to the exporting of monazite of that reference to uranium or thorium ores in this document. As I said, I am glad to see the reference there. Presumably it is there for a reason I would think it would be there for that reason.

Pages 45, 46 and 47 of the report contain samples of stickers which have to be put on radioactive packages. I draw the stickers to the attention of honourable senators because they seem adequate until the dimensions are noted. These little stickers are 10 centimetres square, even for radioactive III, the worst type of material. How will any body know that there is a dangerous consignment if the label on the package is so small-only 10 centimetres square-that it is almost not there at all? The actual letters of the word 'radioactive' are well under a centimetre high. How will people know that the material is radioactive? Even more ridiculously, when we turn to the next page-page 48-we find a placard for vehicles of the same type and it is permissible for those placards to be only 15 centimetres square. How can a person tell that a vehicle is carrying radioactive materials in the event of an accident or something of that kind?

I go on to deal with fissile materials. The whole issue of weapons grade material is interesting. When we turn to the tables illustrated on page 81 of the Code of Practice we find some rather interesting references. I mention this in light of the fact that I have had repeated assurances from the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) that there has never been any question of uranium being enriched in this country below a certain low nuclear reactor grade. Therefore, why has it been thought necessary on page 81, under the heading 'Table XXIII. Permissible Mass of Uranium-235 per consignment' and others, to lay down in detail the permissible mass in grams per consignment of U-235 right up to an enrichment of 93 per cent or more or above U-235? The figure for uranium exceeding U-235 by 93 per cent or more, which is plainly a weapons grade material-there is no doubt about that whatsoever-is 160 grams per consignment.

Section VII of the Code of Practice deals with the testing of packaging, such as the water spray test, the free drop test and the compression test. On my initial reading of the report-here again I could be wrong-there seems to be no check or test carried out on the degree of radioactivity of the substance. It is left to the person consigning to put on labels indicating it, but there seems to be no check that that information is correct. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not present when Senator Mason started his comments. Therefore, on the earlier part of his remarks I may need to make supplementary comments. These codes were prepared by all the governments of Australia-that is, the Federal and State governments-working together and with the advantage of the advice of the best objective scientific knowledge in Australia. The Senate is looking at documents which contain expertise and which are not in any way influenced by political judgments. They are scientific judgments which are based upon good health practices. We know that under the law of this land any movement of radioactive materials of a particular kind, of a particular degree of radioactivity, must be supervised by the Australian Safeguards Office. That Office is headed by expert scientists who are objective and in no way relate--
—Senator, some scientists have not got a very good history in relation to safety in nuclear affairs.

—I do not object to interjections because I think that Senator Primmer and I would have the same goal in mind-that is, achieving the best we can and the highest degree of judgment that we can for the survival and good health of the families and generations ahead. But in this as in anything else one must go to those who have, by the judgment of the community, the best knowledge of what it is all about. That is what has happened. I remind the Senate that we have a number of major safeguards. The Australian Safeguards Office deals with the movement, handling and management of materials of high levels of radioactivity.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat a number of matters. There is no intention at all in this country of the Government seeking to enrich uranium to anything other than a non-weapons standard. Indeed, no decision has been made as at this moment with regard to uranium enrichment to that standard. If there were to be a uranium enrichment plant the level of enrichment would be well below that standard. One should put out of one's mind any thought that this Government, by overt or covert means, will initiate or allow the use of any fissile material of that nature. The code of practice for the safe transport of radioactive substances aims to work out in the State and Federal spheres how we can get a common practice for the transport of materials. We must bear in mind that the kinds of materials range from the radioactive isotopes that are used for medical and industrial purposes-some of those have half-lives of less than a day; others have longer lives-to materials which are used for university and hospital purposes. I make it clear that the governments which will be carrying out these matters are governments of all political persuasions.

I was asked about thorium. The short answer is that thorium in itself is not an explosive material. For it to become an explosive material in a weapons situation it has to be associated also with plutonium. That ought to be completely understood. In order that that matter might be cleared up I point out that, of course, it is a component of monazite, in the mineral sands type of activities. I am aware of recent Press claims that Australian thorium is being used as a nuclear fuel in the Federal Republic of Germany and in the United States of America. In fact, there are no exports of thorium from Australia. I make that perfectly clear. Thorium is a component which typically contains around 6 to 7 per cent of monazite. Monazite exports from Australia have been permitted under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations only when the stated use of the monazite is for the extraction of rare earth elements, a non- nuclear use. These rare earths are used in areas such as glass, ceramics and metal alloy technology. Thorium is contained in waste sludge after extraction of rare earths. Thorium ore such as monazite and thorium ore residue is not subject to International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards and the export of monazite from Australia is fully in accord with Australia's Non-Proliferation Treaty obligation. The IAEA Australian Safeguards Agreement would apply to thorium only if it were concentrated as a source material. I stress that thorium is not fissile but is a fertile material having the ability to capture neutrons and generate fissile U233. Thorium on its own cannot be used as a nuclear fuel. It must be mixed with fissile material such as U233, U235 or plutonium. Nuclear uses represent only a fraction of total thorium production and this situation is unlikely to change before the next century.

I should add that the countries which take the exports of monazite have their own quite vast capacities to store it and therefore it should not be considered as having the difficulties as presented. I repeat that this is not a comprehensive comment on my part because the subject is a massive one. It is necessary, in Australia, in the overview of radioactive materials, to develop a number of methodologies. Firstly, we need to get a common code throughout Australia so that all States and the Commonwealth act in a common way in the handling of radioactive substances. The States are responsible for mostly substances which are of relatively low radioactivity. Operating in conjunction with this code there is, of course, the code of mining and milling which has been established and which has been adopted as a common code. There is the code which we adopt for our Australian Safeguards Office. This code is regarded as a strong code in international terms in the supervision of highly radioactive material whether moving in and around Australia or throughout the world.

I repeat that the best evidence of the quality of these codes is that they have been developed by consultations throughout the whole of Australia. They are acceptable throughout Australia as a common code. They are acknowledged by the scientists as being the best. I give the assurance that if, in the development of the exposure of these codes, there are seen to be weaknesses, we will step in and plug the holes. I suggest that what might happen is that, if in the weeks ahead the Australian Democrats or others would like to, we could initiate a debate on the broader subject after these codes have been exposed. I commend that suggestion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that prior to the Leader of the Government in the Senate contributing to the debate, Senator Mason had sought leave to continue his remarks. I chose to ignore his application at that time in order to accommodate Senator Sir John Carrick within the debate. I now ask the Senate whether leave is granted for Senator Mason to continue his remarks at a later stage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — I take the opportunity accorded to me on the first reading of the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill 1982 to raise a matter which I have raised quite a few times before, not only in this chamber and at Estimates Committee hearings but also directly with the then Minister concerned. The matter that I again refer to is the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full- time Training scheme. The Government, in trying to persuade employers to avail themselves of money that would be available, so-called tax free, some time ago issued some brochures. One of my constituents availed himself of this offer. He has since found that it is not all that it appears to be on first examination of the brochures. I quote from the brochure headed 'Job Training-$1,000 Now Prevent Skill Shortages Later.'. This brochure contains a message to the employer, and states:

SPEECH.PARA: For each new apprentice you employ between 1 December 1979 and 30 June 1980, additional to the number you had for the same period last year, you will be paid $1,000 tax free.
The other brochure deals with the CRAFT technical education rebate. Part of that message to the employer states:
Over the apprenticeship this will be worth from $1,600 to $2,200 tax free.

An employer constituent of mine came to me after his business enterprise had availed itself of the so-called benefits mentioned in this brochure with the complaint that in fact it was not true. On 18 February, which is just six months ago, I went to the then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr N. A. Brown, and explained the situation to him. I said that I felt that there was an anomaly in the Income Tax Assessment Act. He agreed with me that there was some anomaly there. He wrote to me the next day. His letter states:
Dear Senator McLaren,
Thank you for coming to my office on Thursday, 18 February 1982 and for the representation you made-
I will leave out the company because that is a confidential matter of taxation-

on the issue of the taxable status of payments under the CRAFT scheme. I was very interested to hear the representations you made. I have taken this matter up with the Treasurer and will be pursuing the matter with him. When a conclusion has been reached about the issue I will contact you again.
On 17 February, by way of question to Senator Guilfoyle, the Minister for Finance, I again raised this matter in the Senate. In her reply, the Minister stated:
I understand that Senator McLaren has made some representations on the matter-
That is the matter to which I am now referring-

I will refer the matter to the Treasurer to see whether there is some interaction between tax losses, exempt income and things of that sort and whether there is any necessity to look again at this to uphold the undertaking if there is any departure from it. I will see whether I can get some early response from him on the issue and clarify the matter as far as possible.

Nothing is mentioned in those brochures to encourage employers to avail themselves of the offer. Nothing is mentioned about interaction between tax losses, exempt incomes and things of that sort. But when the employer finds himself in that situation then of course the Treasurer (Mr Howard) will apply the relevant section of the Act. The South Australian quarterly Small Business News of February 1982 contains an article which refers to this Government's magnificent offer to employers, repeating word for word practically what is in those brochures. I wrote to the manager of the Small Business Advisory Bureau on 31 March-because that February issue did not come out until, I think, the middle of March. Immediately I received it I wrote to the manager and pointed out to him that representation had been made to me by an employer about the problem. In reply the manager said:

In consultation with the Adelaide Office of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, we understand that there is a problem with interpretation of whether or not the rebates are tax exempt and this is being pursued by the Minister. In the meantime, all references to tax exemption have been withdrawn.
I take it they were withdrawn from the Small Business News issue, which is published quarterly. He went on to say:
We look forward to hearing the Commonwealth Treasurer's answer to your question of 17 March, 1982.

That is the question I have just referred to. I have not yet received an answer to it. On 19 April, during the hearings of Estimates Committee C, I again raised the matter with the officers of the Treasury and pointed out that I had spoken to the then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and also questioned Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I recapitulated what I had done up until that time. Mr Daly replied:
I think we will have to take it on notice and provide a reply if that is satisfactory.
Of course I agreed to that. On 11 May W. J. O'Reilly, the Commissioner of Taxation, wrote to me and said in part:
I have had the taxation assessments of the company-
That is the one I was involved with-
checked by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in South Australia and he has assured me that the assessments are in accordance with the law.

I did not dispute that but I did dispute the fact that when I approached the Minister on 18 February he admitted there was an anomaly in the law. I asked that there be some amendment to the law. I was told on various occasions that the Treasurer would look at that. That was my concern. Mr O'Reilly went on to quote in detail from the Income Tax Assessment Act as it applied at that time. On 19 May again I raised this matter in the chamber in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1981-82. Senator Peter Baume was in charge of the chamber at that time. I asked:
. . . whether the Minister can advise me as to whether the Government is taking any action to amend that Act and, if so, when we can expect the legislation to come before the Parliament.
I quote in part Senator Baume's reply. He said:
I note that the Government indicated in the response which is given there, that the matter that he has raised-
He is quoting me-

has been judged to be of sufficient importance that it is presently before the Government for decision. At the time that the report was written it was still in that situation, and to the best of my knowledge and that of my advisers it is still before the Government for a decision.
Of course, Senator Baume was quoting the report from Estimates Committee C, where I raised this matter. He continued:

Until the Government has taken a policy decision we are not really in a position to give Senator McLaren the definitive answer he requires. It will require the Government to take a position, make a judgment, and then it will be able to announce what that judgment is. I undertake to check that that is still the situation. If it should be otherwise, I shall try to advise Senator McLaren as quickly as possible.
I again entered the debate and said:

I should like to ask the Minister, further, to ascertain when making these inquiries if the Government decides to amend the Act, whether it can be amended in such a way that the persons concerned . . . will be excluded from having to pay the tax they have now been called upon by way of an assessment to pay because of the problem in the present legislation. Will consideration be given to honouring the undertaking in the brochures that were freely circulated in the Commonwealth Employment Service offices, that if employers took on extra apprentices the amount of money that they received for taking them on would be tax free?
Senator Baume replied:

I think it most appropriate that we try to make sure that this part of the Hansard record of today's discussion is placed before the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and any other Minister who would be involved in putting views to the Government. I think that that may be the best way of ensuring that Senator McLaren's concern is met.

Up until this time I have received no undertaking from the Government that it will do anything at all to amend that section of the Act, which it clearly admits contains an anomaly. To make matters worse, in a special feature article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 28 June last year headed 'Business to Business' again we find a section concerning this matter, headed 'Making apprenticeships work'. Again this brochure is quoted. The article reads as follows:
Cash incentives are offered by the Federal Government under the Craft scheme- Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentices' Full-time Training.

The article mentions the tax-free amount of $1,500. So again in June of this year, employers are told that if they avail themselves of this scheme they will qualify for that amount. But again nothing is said about anything else-about whether or not they are in a tax loss situation. The Commissioner of Taxation recently wrote to a constituent of mine because he had appealed against this decision to tax him on that amount. I will not quote from the letter or even give the name of the people involved. On 5 August Mr Kilton, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in South Australia, wrote to my constituent acknowledging receipt of the request for the decision of his objection to be referred to the board of review. In part Mr Kilton said:
However, in the circumstances of your case, provided that an amount-
I will not cite that amount-

is paid within 14 days of the date of this letter action to recover the balance of the tax payable attributable to the matters in dispute will be deferred pending a decision on the reference and additional tax accruing from the date of such payment will be remitted.

So in fact the Commissioner of Taxation is now asking that my constituent pay that money and if there is any alteration to the law that company may have the payment remitted. I think the matter has gone on quite long enough. It is six months since I drew it to the attention of Mr N. A. Brown. I raised it during the debate on the Estimates committtees. I have raised it by way of question in this Parliament and I raised it during the debate on the Appropriation Bills. As yet the Government has not come to me and said that it has looked at the Act and thinks it ought to be amended or even come to me and said that it is quite happy with the way the Act is and it is going to apply it as it is written. In the meantime my constituent has to spend money through his accountants and spend extra time with the appeal to the decision that has been made. Even though the company was not showing any magnificent profit, he saw fit to take on apprentices to try to help the unemployment situation in the area in which the company is situated. Because the company did this it now finds itself penalised because the promises made in the brochure are not being honoured.
