I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), who is in charge of the Senate at present, if he will immediately draw what I have said to the attention of the Treasurer to see if some quick action can be taken. It might well be that it is in the pipeline. I would like to have an answer as soon as practically possible so I can inform my constituent. I can assure the Attorney-General that my constituent is not very happy with the actions of the Government-particularly these promises mentioned in the brochures and repeated in business journals. But when companies try to avail themselves of the offer they find there is no benefit to them at all. As a matter of fact it could be even to their detriment because the money they receive is added to their incomes which puts them in a higher income tax bracket. Will the Attorney-General make some urgent inquiries about the matters I have raised this afternoon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly today on a subject which is of very considerable concern and interest to the people of Western Australia, the establishment of a sugar industry in the Ord River region. The matter has been very widely canvassed in the Press, particularly in Western Australia and Queensland. I will summarise the two arguments as they appear to me. The first argument is that Western Australia will not be able to sustain an economic sugar industry, that it will not be able to get it off the ground at the present time, given present market indications. The second argument is that if it does succeed it will do so at the expense of the Queensland and New South Wales industries.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to extensive research which has been carried out on an 80 -hectare commercial scale pilot farm which was established in 1977, with 17 cane varieties under examination. Seven of these have produced weighted cane yields of more than 140 tonnes per hectare, which compares favourably with production levels in any other State in Australia and in the world generally. By comparison , the average world yield is something like 60 to 65 tonnes of cane per hectare, producing between 6 and 7 tonnes of sugar, against the 20 tonnes of sugar which is being produced in the Ord area of Western Australia at the present time. In fact, the Ord yields are significantly higher than those of Queensland. As I have said, they average something like 20 tonnes a hectare against the Queensland average of between 12 and 13 tonnes a hectare. I believe this should indicate that from a technical and commercial point of view there is no difficulty in establishing a viable proposition. In fact, I suggest that that is the very real objection to the proposal for a sugar industry in Western Australia. It is not without significance to note that of the companies and the consortiums that have put forward tenders to the Western Australian Government, two are major producers in Queensland, namely CSR Limited and Bundaberg Sugar Co . Ltd. I think that clearly demonstrates their confidence in the capacity of the Ord to support a viable sugar industry.

That leads me to the second objection-that a West Australian industry will impinge on the markets of the eastern States producers. The Co-operative Sugar Millers Association went so far as to state in an article in the Australian:
Now the Western Australian Government insists that we (that is, Queensland producers) give up 5 per cent or more of our hard won market so that they can start an industry on the cheap.

With all respect to the author of that statement, that is simply not the case. The West Australian Minister for Agriculture has specifically stated that the Ord does not want assistance of any nature from the Federal Government. Western Australia believes it can sustain an industry in the Ord without assistance. The State Government takes the view that if financial assistance is required it will not require the industry. The State Government has said from the outset that it is looking to a self-sufficient industry, not one that will be started on the cheap.

The other question concerns the 5 per cent of Queensland's hard won markets, as they were described by the Millers Association. I can assume only that that figure has arisen out of a projected output of 160,000 tonnes of sugar from the Ord against last year's record Australian sugar production of 3.51 million tonnes. Last year Australia exported 3 million tonnes raw value against our basic export tonnage of 3.33 million tonnes as set by the International Sugar Council. This year, with import quotas severely restricted by the United States, that figure can naturally be expected to fall. But the point to be emphasised is that the present downturn in demand will not affect Western Australia's viability and the viability of the industry generally in the future.

The Premier of Western Australia will be announcing shortly the names of the companies or consortiums which have the most attractive development propositions for the Ord. In turn they will be invited to--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were a free marketeer?
—I am.
—You have to sell it somewhere.

—If the honourable senator listens carefully he will learn. In turn they will be invited to undertake a detailed feasibility study, which could take up to 18 months, and then proceed to the development stage. On that scenario, production from the Ord will not commence for four years. Optimistic as it may be, given the volatility of the demand and price for sugar, it is possible that production from the Ord would augment Queensland's output rather than take a share of the existing eastern States' outlets. Of course, that may be taking a fairly optimistic view of the future sugar market, but in the light of the actions of the Queensland growers, heavily financed and heavily backed by the Federal Government, it is not a view which is thoroughly unjustified.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment, construction of the Burdekin Dam and irrigation area is under way to provide part of the infrastructure necessary for a wide range of products , the most significant of which will be sugar. Surely if the medium term view is sufficiently encouraging to warrant that expenditure, and if it is sufficiently expansionist to assume that sugar markets will be able to absorb the several hundred thousand tonnes of sugar that will evantuate from the Burdekin area, it is not unreasonable for Western Australia to establish an industry of 160,000 tonnes a year given that we already have the majority of the infrastructure required.

The opponents of the sugar industry are engaged in an act of political cynicism of the highest order. They claim that a Western Australian industry, though it has already been shown that its yield per hectare will be higher than virtually anywhere else in the world, will not be able to survive on its own.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it you have not got the support of your north Queensland members there.

—I am not looking for it. Opponents of the sugar industry are claiming that there is no place for new production, but at the same time they are investing heavily in preparing a new production area which, when it is operational, will dwarf the very modest 160,000 tonnes proposed to be produced in the Ord. Their exercise has succeeded to the extent that the Federal Government has announced that it will abrogate its responsibilities by denying Western Australia access to loan funds which have previously been promised under the original Commonwealth-State agreement on the Ord River. However, Western Australia will not be put off. A sugar industry will be established in the Ord with or without the support of the Federal Government. The Western Australian Minister for Agriculture has made that quite clear and I repeat it here today.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been made clear that the Ord industry will be a crystal sugar industry and not an ethanol industry, as has been proposed. Honourable senators should understand quite clearly that an ethanol industry will require heavy government subsidisation to make it economic at the present time. As I have said , Western Australia is not seeking to establish an industry which will require a subsidy. It would be desirable if the Western Australian industry were to be incorporated in the orderly production and marketing system of the Queensland sugar producers. I fully endorse the comments of the Secretary of the Queensland Canegrowers Association, Mr MacKinnon, who acknowledged that an industry on the Ord was inevitable, when he said:
We have to have a good relationship between the two States and the two industries.

That is precisely what Western Australia wants and hopes to achieve, but the project will go ahead no matter what. The alternative would be to deny Western Australians the employment and development opportunities which this industry will bring. Sectional interest is no way to judge the future of what is potentially a major breakthrough for one of the most isolated parts of this country. I say to the Senate that this industry will go ahead. It should not be inhibited. I find it disappointing that sectional groups, for personal selfish reasons, would seek to inhibit the development of a major project in Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make one or two remarks about the housing industry and its prospects in Australia. During Question Time I was castigated by no less than the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for suggesting that the Budget imposition of a 7 1/2 per cent sales tax on construction materials, as well as on home furnishings, curtains, blankets, sheets and towels, was so savage that it might affect the ability of Australians to build a house and then make it into a home with all the furnishings and normal household goods which make a house into a place of comfort for a family. It was strange indeed that it was Senator Chaney who should answer me because when we arrived here on Tuesday morning in order to hear the Government bring down its Budget I found on my desk the new Ministerial Directory dated August 1982 and I looked in vain through that document for any indication that there was a ministry of housing. In fact it transpires that in May of this year the Mr Fraser who posed on Tuesday night as the friend of the family man, the friend of the average Australian trying to build a home and to compete-
—Friend of the children, he likes to be known as now.

—This friend of the children who, unless they are the concern of Senator Walters's committee, should live in homes with their families, this poser, abolished the ministry of housing. As I have said, one seeks in vain in the Ministerial Directory to find who has ministerial responsibility for this most important segment of our social life, namely, the housing of Australians. But I do not suppose it should come as a shock that ordinary, average Australians are so disregarded by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). After all, despite the constant pleas in this chamber from Senator McLaren for the Prime Minister to take his Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, under control in relation to the home loan mortgage of $17,964 which was granted to the Deputy Prime Minister at a fixed rate of interest of 4.75 per cent back in 1964 and of which $15,000 or so is still outstanding, the Prime Minister has failed to take up with the Deputy Prime Minister the absolute obscenity, by way of contrast, of the Deputy Prime Minister, earning $99,200 a year in salary and allowances, paying off a $17,000 mortgage at a rate of only 4.75 per cent due to Government largesse. So it is not surprising that a Prime Minister who ignores such activity on the part of his Deputy Prime Minister should fail even to establish a ministry of housing.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am really surprised about and why I continue to press the Budget provisions dealing with housing assistance is that in that Budget at page 15 we read:

The Government has decided to ask the Reserve Bank of Australia to consider making a release of one percentage point from the Statutory Reserve Deposits it holds from the major trading banks for the special purpose of lending for housing. Any such release would, of course, be additional to the amount of $400 million the major banks agreed to increase their home lending by earlier this year.

My question relates to the fulfilment by the major banks of that promise given last March to release an extra $400m into housing assistance for Australians seeking loans because it is my contention that there is no evidence whatsoever that the banks have gone one iota towards fulfilling that promise. The Senate will recall the deal. The banks were given an increase in interest rates last March in return for a promise to release an extra $400m into housing assistance. That promise has not been fulfilled. One finds, for example, comment from the Housing Industry Association whose Executive Director is Mr Bill Kirkby-Jones, normally strongly supportive of the Government's initiatives in this area. On 18 March in the immediate aftermath of the Government's announcement of its home assistance scheme Mr Kirkby-Jones said that the policy would dramatically increase home ownership opportunities for ordinary Australian families and be of immeasurable assistance to the industry. But of course by 9 August 1982 he was saying:

From a peak of 149,160 new dwelling commencements in 1980-81 it is estimated that home building activities slumped to below 130,000 commencements in 1981-82. Even taking into account the improved deposit assistance scheme, the tax rebate and the additional $400 million to be lent by the banks, we now forecast that new dwelling commencements will not be more than 117,000 in 1982-83.

So even taking into account the possibility that the banks would keep their promise, the prediction is made that new dwelling commencements will fall dramatically. Such has been the disenchantment of the Housing Industry Association. What is the cause for that disenchantment? The fact is that the Government has failed to require the banks to honour their promise. The banks claim that their inability to fulfil the promise is due to Government decisions. What has happened since March? In the month immediately succeeding the announcement of the package, that is, April, we were told that the number of home loans approved by all major housing lenders during April was the lowest in 6 1/2 years since the Australian Bureau of Statistics had kept the relevant statistics. The immediate aftermath of the Government's housing package was to see the lowest home building period in Australia's recent history, and the bankers and home lenders blamed Government decisions for bringing that about.

There are two Government decisions that are relevant. First, the banks claimed that the Government had failed to bring forward legislation reducing the amount they were required to place in deposits and government securities from 40 per cent to 15 per cent. That is directly attributable to Government failure to bring forward the legislation necessary to support its package. Secondly, the Government instituted a new series of Aussie bonds. The Government raised the interest rate in such a way, of course, that whilst it served the Government's money supply goals of taking money out of circulation in the community and geting it into Australian savings bonds the fact is that as that interest rate rose so, too, householders took their funds out of the savings banks and other home lending institutions and put them into the bonds.

As a result of two Government decisions moneys were said not to be available from the banking sector. So when the banking sector spokesman, Mr Cameron, said in the middle of June that the banks might not be able to fulfil the promise, the Prime Minister reacted extremely angrily and fiercely and said that they had to fulfil the promise. But nothing has emerged by way of Government action, whether by way of legislation to underpin the package or by way of adjusting the interest rate on Australian savings bonds to enable the banks' claims that they are unable to fulfil their part of the bargain because of Government action to be met. But whether or not the banks' claims are justifiable is something which I would like to put to one side because the fact is that the deal was done; they got their rise in the interest rate, a rise which continues to contribute to the massive profits which one finds in the banking sector.

There is no more profitable sector in Australia at the moment whether one takes the retail, the resources-based or the manufacturing sector, than the banking sector. The latest figures available in relation to 1981 profits show that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation made a $135m profit; the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd made $204m; the Bank of New South Wales made $165m; the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd made $85m; the Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Ltd made $44m; and the National Bank of Australasia Ltd made $103m. The major firms in any other sector of the Australian economy cannot claim to be as profitable as the banking sector. Yet it fails to fulfil its promise to make available an extra $400m for Australian home purchases-a firm promise made in March of this year.

What we need to obtain and what the Government must press to obtain from the banking sector is first of all an announcement of how much of the $400m extra home assistance has found its way into the economy via mortgage arrangements made to this point through the various banks right around Australia. As something like six or seven months have elapsed since the deal was made one would expect that some $200m extra would by now have reached home buyers. Has it indeed reached home buyers and then gone into the building industry with all its multiplier effects for the good of our economy? That is something which we deserve to know. In order to satisfy ourselves as to the veracity of that reply we need to know exactly how much each bank has loaned for housing in each of the immediately preceding two or three years. It is only if we know that figure that we can know whether indeed an extra $400m has been brought into the housing assistance area.

I believe that the Government has not been firm enough with the banks in not insisting that that disclosure take place. I believe that the various banks have said that to so reveal to the Government their individual home lending history over the past couple of years would affect their competitive position. It would be the disclosure of information which they regard as necessarily confidential and which they do not want disclosed. I would be surprised if some arrangement could not be reached between Mr Cameron of the Australian Bankers Association and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, or the Prime Minister himself, whereby those figures could be disclosed in a totally confidential context but one which would enable us to know whether indeed the major trading banks were fulfilling their part of the bargain. There is no doubt that an extra $400m provided for housing would be of assistance. The Parliament has the right to know whether the deal that was done, whereby this Government increased home interest rates for ordinary average Australians, has in fact been fulfilled or indeed has any prospect of being fulfilled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of this first reading debate to ask the question: How should Australia react to the likely constitutional changes recently announced by the Prime Minister of the Republic of South Africa, Mr P. W. Botha? The proposals, as outlined over the weekend of 30 and 31 July 1982 to the Sixth Federal Congress of the National Party in Bloemfonteim, are clearly the most radical changes proposed to the South African Constitution this century. Not only would they demolish the existing Westminster parliamentary system but also, for the first time, they would involve both coloured and Asians in a limited form of power sharing. The system of government in South Africa is at present, of course, in the form of a single chamber of white representatives elected by a totally white franchise. A new Prime Minister is elected by the majority party, the National Party, which has ruled South Africa for over 30 years. A nominated Presidential Council, which replaced the former nominated Senate, has a purely advisory capacity. The cornerstone of the platform of the National Party has been and still is apartheid, that is, the separate development of the races.

SPEECH.PARA: Races in South Africa are divided into whites, coloureds, Asians and blacks. The determination of race is made at birth. Ideally, from a nationalist point of view, each race should have a separate government and, if possible, even a separate national status. Thus, we see the development of the concept of independent homelands for blacks-theoretically, to return blacks to their traditional ethnic or tribal lands, to put a boundary around such lands, to set up a separate form of black government and then to offer inducements for the homelands to become independent and separate from the Republic. But the homelands may in fact be pieces of land scattered over a wide area, such as in the case of Kwazulu which consists of more than 40 different portions of land. To obtain government benefits, for example a pension, blacks must accept citizenship of these homelands, thus forfeiting status as a national of the Republic. Instead, they become a national of the independent home state nation. Ultimately and theoretically citizenship of the Republic can be limited then to non-blacks. I say 'theoretically' because it does not resolve the problem of urban blacks.

The South African Government, however, has always had a particular problem with coloureds and Asians, who cannot, of course, be easily allocated to homelands to accommodate their separate development. The Government has encouraged the development of the Coloured Council and the Indian Council. That has not, however, settled easily within the concept of apartheid and has been a thorn in the side of the Government for a long time. Further, in recent times the Indian Council in particular has become more vocal in its demands for power sharing; thus the Government has decided to move. What does the Government now propose? Basically, it proposes to establish a three-chamber parliament-a white chamber, a coloured chamber and an Asian chamber. There would be a new position of executive president, the occupant of that position being elected by means of an electoral college chamber with membership in the ratio of 50 whites, 25 coloured and 30 Asians. That would be a likely ratio based on the size of each chamber. Each chamber would be elected by the franchise of its own race. The executive president would determine his Cabinet and thus the national government. The executive president would also decide whether a legislative matter was of a nature common to all chambers, in which case, if the chambers were in dispute over the matter, it would be settled by the new president's council, which would have binding authority. The new president's council would be partly elected by the three chambers in the ratio of 20 whites, 10 coloureds and five Indians, with the president himself appointing the remaining 25 members.

What does this mean? It means the continuation of apartheid, of separate races electing their separate representatives. It means continued entrenchment of white rule in that whites will control the election of the president and the composition of the president's council. However, it does not mean that coloureds and Asians will, for the first time, have a voice in the national legislature. It means that for the first time there will be a possibility of there being coloured or Asian Cabinet Ministers. It does mean that there is just the slightest possibility that the Progressive Federal Party may, in the future, win seats at the expense of the National Party and may one day join with the coloureds and Asians to elect other than a National Party president.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your assessment, Senator? You have described it. Is it good, or still not good enough?

—I will come to that. More than 70 per cent of the population of South Africa is black. That is the critical point. How do they fare under the new package? The answer is, of course, that they do not fare at all. The National Party envisages no place for the black majority in the National Government or parliament. The National Party remains committed to government for blacks within their homelands. The only mention of the black majority in the package was that the Prime Minister would, in November, call a summit meeting of heads of government of the independent homelands to devote further attention to the principles upon which the envisaged confederation of southern African states would be based. Thus, the black states would combine with the minority coloured and Asian states in a form of federation for certain purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The development of the homelands is a fiction which has been created to further the principle of apartheid. In practice, the homelands are not limited to one tribal or ethnic group. The methods adopted to induce blacks to resettlement within the homelands have been an international disgrace. The concept of thousands of blacks being bused and trained out of the homeland every day, often literally with hours of travelling each way to work in the urban areas, is totally socially disruptive. The concept that the homelands can become truly independent is a sham. One only has to raise the subject of defence and the defence responsibilities and rights of the homelands for that to be obvious. If the homelands are a sham, the proposed confederation of independent states must be equally a sham. To Australia, the forced separation of the races is immoral. There is little in the new package which corrects that immorality. For the South African Government even to acknowledge that there should be some minimal role for coloureds and Indians in central government is a dramatic step and, therefore, I suppose some credit should be given. There is a danger if we fail to recognise small change. There have been similarly considerable moves in the integration of sport. I sometimes feel that we have erred in not acknowledging the change that has occurred.

A few weeks ago in Johannesburg I witnessed the running of the annual Nashua Johannesburg marathon, a multiracial event won by the brilliant black athlete Vincent Rakabaeli, to the wholehearted support and encouragement of many thousands of white spectators. As is often the case in sport, there was controversy, but it was about whether professionals should be allowed to run against amateurs, not whether whites should run against blacks. Change is occurring, perhaps to us ever so small, but to many in South Africa ever so great. Those who are advocating and supporting change deserve and should receive our support. A solution of the racial problems of South Africa is difficult to find. To some, such as President Comrade Mugabe in Zimbabwe and President Kaunda in Zambia, the answer is simply full adult franchise and majority rule. To white South Africans this would be seen as the destruction of their society. White government in South Africa has a major preoccupation with white security.

South Africa is a rich and powerful country. One is often reminded that the per capita income of blacks in South Africa is higher than that of blacks anywhere else on the African continent. To black nationalists this is a consequence of the immense natural resources of the country and the exploitation of cheap black labour. That is true, but there are also other countries in Africa with both natural resources and abundant cheap labour. The distinction has been that South Africa has had a white population of great determination, rigidity and a work ethic that has enabled utilisation of resources to the benefit of all. The failure has been in the inadequate distribution of the rewards, based upon a belief that the blacks are not only less advanced by white standards but also racially inferior. Fortunately, this view is changing but the concept of black majority rule terrifies the whites because of the anticipated backlash, which they believe would destroy all that they have built and achieved. Thus, whilst we must philosophically and conceptually advocate the principles of democratic majority rule for all nations, including South Africa, it may be unrealistic to expect this to happen in the Republic without offering the white minority some form of security which may be unnecessary in a society such as ours.

Some will argue that Zimbabwe is evidence of the fact that there can be a transition to black majority rule without appropriation of the property or liberty of minorities. However, there are those in Zimbabwe who argue that it is now time for the second war of liberation, to finish the job, and the somewhat moderate leadership of Robert Mugabe will have to meet a significant challenge in withstanding that pressure. Thus, perhaps we should be more vocal in supporting policies such as that advocated by the Progressive Federal Party in South Africa-calling for full adult franchise with majority rule but nevertheless an entrenched protection for minority interests. That position may offer a compromise which, during an interim period, would allow blacks to achieve reasonable aspirations yet offer the white minority adequate security to accept change. Let us not only condemn the inflexible, but also applaud the moderates and recognise change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to Senator Crichton- Browne's attempt to kick the ailing Queensland sugar industry in the teeth. In a speech camouflaged as another advocacy of States rights he also seeks to inflict further burdens on the long-suffering Western Australian taxpayers. In response to his attempt to kick the ailing Queensland sugar industry in the teeth I challenge the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) to dissociate themselves from Senator Crichton-Browne's attempt to do just that. Mr Nixon was asked in the House of Representatives today whether he supported the establishment of a sugar industry in the Kimberleys and the consequential and inevitable damage that would do to an already dangerously sick Queensland industry. He dodged the question. I challenge him again and I challenge the Prime Minister, the National Country Party Leader (Mr Anthony), the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Thomson), the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean), and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) to dissociate themselves publicly from Senator Crichton- Browne's attempt to inflict what may well be fatal injuries on sections of the Queensland sugar industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The hallmark of the Court Government of Western Australia, and of the subsequent Liberal Government of that State, with regard to the Ord River and associated problems has been their economic indiscipline and illiteracy. The product of their sloth and irresponsibility includes the sinking already of $ 200m, in 1980 dollars, into the Ord River scheme-for a continuing negative return and continuing drain on the Western Australian Treasury. I turn now to some associated matters. Only last year the Court Government threw away $3m on a bulk grain loading facility in the port of Broome to load the sorghum that was supposed to have been produced at Camballin but had not been produced or even planted. At the time the grain loading facility was built the company was going into receivership. I told the Court Government that the company that was supposed to be producing sorghum was going into receivership; yet it went ahead and inflicted an additional loss of $3m on the Western Australian taxpayers for a now redundant and useless grain loading facility. It makes a good pair with the equally redundant and equally useless grain loading facility constructed at the port of Wyndham by the Court Government three years earlier.

I will now deal with the specifics of Senator Crichton-Browne's speech-insofar as anything specific can be distilled from the sloppy and sometimes contradictory series of assertions that he made. He referred to what he euphemistically called extensive research on an 80-hectare demonstration farm run by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture and to the fact that sugar yields equivalent to 20 tonnes per hectare had been produced. That much is correct. He then accepted the glib assumption made by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture, in its so-called study of this matter that those yields-achieved under optimum conditions on a demonstration farm-would be the average commercial yields which would follow. All experience and agricultural research has shown that actual commercial yields will be in the vicinity of 70 per cent to 80 per cent of those produced under such highly favourable and optimum conditions on a demonstration farm. The glib assumption that demonstration or experimental yield will be repeated on a commercial scale was incorporated in previous sloppy submissions by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture regarding cotton production on the Ord. We know by now what happened to the Ord cotton industry and we know how accurate were those irrational and unprofessional assumptions by that Department.

The additional infrastructure cost associated with the establishment of a sugar industry in the Kimberleys as detailed in the Western Australian Department of Agriculture submission, should be viewed with at least equal suspicion. The Department's submissions have an appalling and well-earned reputation for economic incompetence. At various times it has supported assertions that sugar can be produced profitably on the Ord. Those assertions date back to 1962. It has also supported assertions that cotton, kenaf and rice could be produced profitably. Now we have come full circle and we are back to sugar.

The well-earned and well-documented reputation for incompetence of Western Australian Department of Agriculture submissions is not restricted to the Ord River. For example, in a submission delivered to the honorary royal commission on the dairy industry it argued against the negotiability of milk quotas on the novel ground that if milk quotas were negotiable the market price of the quota would rise and therefore the administered price of milk, ipso facto, must rise. Such a suggestion would be treated with the ridicule it deserved at any institution in Australia teaching agricultural economics. This came from an official submission of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture. The Western Australian Department of Agriculture is a hired gun of the Western Australian Liberal Party and no federal institution should accept any submissions it presents, on the Ord or on any other matter, without independent and competent examination. It is only a few months since the Western Australian Department of Agriculture condoned the nonsensical belief or assertion that ethanol could be economically produced in the Ord. Even the Western Australian Minister for Agriculture, Mr Old, and Senator Crichton-Browne now recognise that that is rubbish. It is a few short months since it was being condoned by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture.

Senator Crichton-Browne also mentioned CSR Ltd and Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd. He cited their professed interest in the Ord as evidence or proof of its economic viability. CSR is a monopolistic sugar marketer. Bundaberg Sugar is a major participant in the sugar industry at various levels. If any government is going to throw away money conscripted from its taxpayers on a sugar industry in the Kimberleys, CSR and Bundaberg understandably will be quite happy to take it. They will be quite happy to extend their monopolistic and oligopolistic control of the industry. The crucial point, however, is whether they would put up their own money. Are CSR and Bundaberg Sugar so confident of the economic viability of this proposal that they will put their own money into it? If they were so confident, actions of the Loan Council, actions of the Federal Government and even the pockets of the Western Australian taxpayers would be redundant and irrelevant. If CSR and Bundaberg Sugar were willing to put their money where Senator Crichton-Browne says their mouths are, there would not even be any need for the matter to be debated in this Parliament. I suggest that one does not have to be too suspicious or cynical to say that the very fact that CSR and Bundaberg Sugar will not put in any of their own money tells us what their real evaluation of the viability of the project is. These companies will no more put their own money into a Court pipe dream than that great advocate of private enterprise, Sir Charles Court, was willing to put his money into his pipe dream and into fleshing out his personal obsession. One would have thought that such a great advocate of private enterprise as Sir Charles Court would have been only too eager to pass the hat around among his Liberal Party friends in the Western Australia business community, notorious tax dodgers like Denis Horgan and Sid Corser, and get them to subscribe the capital. What has happened to the entrepreneurial spirit and entrepreneurial drive so venerated by Sir Charles Court? What did he do? Did he solicit private capital? No, he conscripted taxpayers' money because he knew that no sen- sible private enterprise would sink its money into a scheme with so little prospect-if one goes back to the construction of the dam itself, no prospect-of economic viability.

Senator Crichton-Browne referred to world sugar cycles. It is correct that over the last 20 years and probably longer there have been not entirely regular but nevertheless cyclical movements in the price of sugar associated with the expansion of the production base in various countries in response to a preceding period of abnormally high prices. Senator Crichton-Browne argued that because that was so and because there would be a four year time lag between a decision to produce sugar on the Ord and significant sugar production, there was no need for the Queensland industry to worry. As I said, although not regular those sugar cycles have been a feature of world sugar prices in the past. But there are reasons to believe that that cyclical pattern will change, if not be eradicated. For example, a new factor pointed out in a recent issue of the Queensland Sugar Journal was that for the first time the European Economic Community is producing large surpluses of beet sugar, heavily subsidised, and is dumping them at below production costs on the world market. The United States of America is producing large quantities of corn syrup, a near product and an acceptable commercial substitute for sugar for many end uses. So although it has happened in the past, especially when new and important factors or variables have entered into the question it does not necessarily follow that the sugar cycle will be repeated.

He then put the extraordinary and sloppy proposition that Western Australian competition would not hurt Queensland. That reminds me of Mr Anthony's statement a month or six weeks ago in defence of concessional interest rates for certain groups. He said that it is possible for certain groups to be granted loans and concessional rates at low interest without hurting anyone else. Of course, it is not possible for that to happen. It is possible for some people to believe it, providing they also believe in magic. Again one would not be too cynical to suggest that in Mr Anthony's case there may have been an element of self- interest in that statement, since he is the most notorious recipient of a low interest loan in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I do not object to the honourable senator stating the facts but that is an attribution of motive to another member of parliament which I believe is not consistent with Standing Order 418.

—I am happy to withdraw; I do not have much time left. I just invite Mr Anthony to show some of the restraint that the Prime Minister has been talking about and to repay that 4 3/4 per cent loan. In making the assertion that Western Australia can produce sugar to sell on world markets in competition with Queensland without hurting Queensland displays the same degree of intellectual sloth, since I am not allowed to refer to self-interest, which Mr Anthony displayed when he made his assertion six weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, before any Commonwealth money is committed to such a project the minimum demand should be that the shonky evaluations of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture be submitted to rigorous re-examination by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. In any case, to suggest at this particular time that this project should proceed is tantamount to attempting to pass a death sentence on many Queensland sugar producers and Queensland sugar producing regions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must respond to a few of the points made by Senator Walsh. I will have a close look at his speech in Hansard later and prepare a more detailed response for later presentation. The first point is that I doubt whether any of us here at present had any say in the decision to build the dam on the Ord River. But it is a fact of life. It is a magnificent dam which, at the moment, holds a volume of sweet water 23 times that of the Sydney Harbour. One of the points Senator Walsh made was in regard to what he called the wastage in building a sorghum loader in Broome. I am sure that Senator Walsh would have been the most vehement critic of the State Government if the sorghum crop had turned out as most people had anticipated and there was no facility to load the sorghum at Broome. I think that his point is totally unsustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out in his address that it would take four years to establish a sugar industry in the Ord River area. It can be demonstrated very clearly, and I am sure that Senator Walsh understands this point very well, that demands for sugar in the world change very quickly. Within that four years I am sure that there will be many ups and downs in world demand for sugar. In 1976, when my Senate Committee was conducting an inquiry into Australia's water resources, we received evidence from the Queensland sugar producers very strongly making the case for the Burdekin dam and using increased sugar production in that area as one of the justifications for that dam. The projections they made then for the increased demand for Australian sugar to the year 2000 have been fairly closely followed. There have been many ups and downs in the intervening period, but they have been generally followed.

In the last 20 years the increase in sugar production from Queensland and New South Wales has averaged about 5 per cent a year and is almost precisely what the Western Australian industry is asking for as a share of the Australian market. The 160,000 tonnes of sugar required to create a viable industry on the Ord River mentioned by Senator Crichton-Browne is equivalent to the annual increase in Australia's production over the last 20 years and is less than the best estimates in the last few years of the increase in production from now to the year 2000.

It was interesting to hear Senator Walsh today and to hear Labor Party spokesmen during the fairly recent North Province election campaign, in which all the Labor spokesmen during that campaign very strongly supported a sugar industry on the Ord River. I guess that one learns to be cynical in politics, but I think that that stretches even that evaluation. Recently John Kerin, the spokesman for the Labor Party on primary industry, condemned the attempts to develop a sugar industry on the Ord River, but it is interesting that he saved those remarks until after completion of that North Province by-election.

There is a new factor that Senator Walsh also ignored. I have heard about it, but I have not been able to substantiate it yet. I understand that West Germany, at least, and possibly the whole of the European Economic Community, have changed their attitude and policy with regard to the subsidisation of export sugar. As Senator Walsh mentioned, there are large stocks of sugar in the EEC. The EEC refuses to sign any international agreements with regard to the orderly marketing of sugar in the world, and for that it must be roundly condemned. The EEC is the largest producer of sugar in the world and it refuses consistently to sign any international sugar agreements. I have not been able to substantiate this, but I understand that the policy has changed quite substantially and that there will be far less, if any, assistance given to the export sugar industry in West Germany.

I repeat that it will take four years to establish an industry on the Ord River . It does not need the Commonwealth's agreement to the establishment of the industry and export of sugar from Western Australia. I am not a lawyer, but I believe that a reading of section 99 of the Constitution will underline that point. All that the Ord is asking for is the equivalent of the annual increase in Australia's sugar production over the last 20 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on first reading of the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill 1982 to express my concern about the growing unemployment in Australia, especially among young people, and the attitude of the Government, which is doing virtually nothing to help the situation. There is one area in which growth in employment can be achieved-the service industries. If we really settled down, we could keep many young people in continuous employment in the tourist industry. But what do we see? The Government is trying to do everything in its power to restrict those who run hotels and motels. In the Budget we have seen increases in tobacco and alcohol taxes. As we well know, charges and profits made in bars offset the cost of dining room or accommodation facilities. Travel in Australia is so costly today that it is impossible for many people to take annual leave, and there is simply no concern about that. The Government simply wants to milk the cow before it is in milk, and I think that is tragic.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no concern for people, of whatever age. It is concerned only to see that foreign investors come to Australia and bring their money. The Government does not want to take any initiatives to create jobs. Recently the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare investigated the problems of the homeless youth of Australia. I believe that every person who served on that Committee was appalled at the prevailing conditions. There should be a concerted effort to overcome the problems. There must be consultation with industry, with the tourist business, with hotels, with the transport industry, and with the trade union movement. That has not been done and there are no plans for it. We could employ many thousands more people.

Many years ago I was instrumental in bringing about a holiday service loading. This matter should be seriously examined. Many people in industry get a 17 1/2 per cent loading and some get as much as 25 per cent. Working people, indeed all people, are entitled to a holiday. There would be less disruption to families if all families were encouraged to take a holiday annually. There would be fewer family break-ups, fewer social disturbances and fewer people in hospitals. We are not looking at the unseen costs in this area. State and Federal Governments must pick up the bill when a family breaks up, and the cost of that is outrageous.

We do not seem to consider that it is important for a family to relax, to take time off, have a break from the worry of going to work and coming home, and all the hassles that occur in families. Because of economic circumstances many women do not get out of their homes for month after month. Is it any wonder that family traumas occur? Governments should seriously examine this proposition. We could create a new industry in this field.

Over 20 years ago I put up an argument that all working people should have a loading of about 100 per cent on their pay for holidays. State and Federal governments should seriously consider the possibility of setting up recreational centres all over the country for people to stay in on their annual leave. We should seriously examine the way aircraft could be chartered to fly holidaymakers from any part of Australia to other parts. With the co-operation of the tourist industry and the transport industry, we could create many thousands of new jobs, which would be well worth while. I said at that time that anyone who would not take a recognised holiday should not get the loading, and I am still of that opinion. The Government should seriously examine such a possibility.

We should be thinking about innovative ways of employing people. The disastrous effects of long periods of unemployment, especially on young people, are tragic. It is unbelievable that politicians in this country have no real concern about what is going on. We are simply destroying our people, and it is not good enough . We can do many things to overcome this. But there in not the consultation with all sections in the community to try to overcome this problem. That is what worries me. We think in the old traditional ways.

Unless we are prepared to take on innovative ideas I believe we will never get out of the problem. We are creating problems for the future which we do not comprehend. The worst thing we can possibly do is to destroy people. It is important for people to work, to feel they are wanted in the community, and to feel they have a responsibility. There is nothing worse that to not have work and to feel that one is not needed or wanted in the community. I think that is disgraceful. We can do something about it. It is a matter of the whole spectrum of people in the community, whether those people be politicians, trade unionists or business people, working together to do so. We could put this together if we really wanted to.

I must condemn this present Government for allowing unemployment to rise. The Government has now said openly that the rate of unemployment will increase alarmingly. Yet we still do nothing about it. This is a great country. Australia has a population of 15 million people, the majority of whom are well educated. Australians are healthy people. We have many natural resources at our fingertips . Yet we do not take advantage of them. Look at overseas countries which have teeming millions and immense problems. In comparison with those countries we do not have a problem at all. It is intolerable to allow the conditions which lead to the wasting of human beings to prevail.

I am concerned that wherever one goes one sees children from very good families turning to drugs and all sorts of other evil ways. It is intolerable if we cannot think more of the family structure and if we cannot plan to have a better way of life. I believe Australia should be a showpiece for the world. Years ago in times of war Australia did all the things that everyone said we could not do. We started manufacturing from nothing. Where are the innovative ideas now? Surely if we get together and put on our thinking caps we can overcome these problems. All too often we think in the old traditional ways. As I have said, we should try to overcome these problems. It will not be an easy job. There has to be co-operation for this to happen. While governments do nothing about the situation and while they overtax some of the service industries, and take too much out of--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a smoker's cough, Senator.

—That is all right, Senator. All we want is some nice fresh air in this place. This is a nice and easy way to have a laugh and so on but it is not a laughing matter for the people without jobs in the community. It does not matter whether this situation concerns the children of honourable senators, my children or anybody else's, we should be a little more sincere about. It is a disgrace to all politicians, irrespective of their political side of the fence. People are looking to us to overcome these problems. It is a great shame that a great nation such as this simply cannot provide the work and some kind of future for our children. In the past we have managed to overcome many great difficulties. What is life all about? Do we simply live for our own enjoyment or do we think something of our children? Of course we do. Life would be totally meaningless if we considered our own pleasures and our own security. If we do not consider our offspring-our children and grandchildren-great problems will occur.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no need for extremes in this country. We have not had them in the past . Unless we solve the problems we will have all the violence and the terrible wrath and the feeling of hopelessness that comes out of unemployment. I do not believe this country should accept that situation. We should be showing the lead to many other countries. We do not have the problems which face many other countries. We are well endowed. It is about time we started to pull ourselves up by our bootstraps and do a job that our forefathers did. They came to this country with very little finance and with their own efforts they started to put this country together. We are allowing it to fall apart. That is a great shame. We have to overcome the problem in a shorter term. We have accepted unemployment . That is what is worrying me-the fact that we are all starting to accept these figures. The figure of half a million unemployed is meaningless. But when one goes out into the real world and sees the great tragedy of what is happening to our people, especially young people, it is obvious that what we are not doing for them is unforgivable. I urge the Government and all politicians to do something. I believe we can take meaningful action for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity at the first reading stage of the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill to make another contribution to the debate on the sugar industry. Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Thomas and Senator Walsh have already referred to this matter. I believe it is useful to make a response. Doubtless, as a senator from Queensland, I will be considered biased in this discussion. I believe, however, that when one looks at the economic ramifications of the production of sugar in the Ord it must give us pause. We ought to be very careful about any continuing operation, development or impost of money on the Australian public to support another or a new sugar industry. I briefly outline, in distinction to what Senator Crichton-Browne said , that the sugar industry happens to be a major input into the Australian economy and not a drain on it. The industry is not supported by the Australian taxpayer. It provides the Australian taxpayer with an enormous amount of export earnings. Indeed, sugar is our fifth largest export item.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems in the industry at present arise from a world surplus of sugar. The current figures indicate that of a world production of 97 million tonnes the most rosy optimism puts world consumption at only 90 million tonnes, which leaves us with a world surplus of 7 million tonnes of sugar being produced every year. If one takes that into consideration one has to go very quietly on this notion that there are ups and downs. There have been ups and downs in the past and there will be in the future. As an economic argument that does not hold terribly much weight. Certainly in terms of any reasonable prediction at the moment it would give anyone pause. In a moment I will refer to the reason that CSR Ltd, for example, might wish to go into the Ord River region. It would be on a commercial proposition, but there are some things tied to that which compel CSR to go into the Ord, whether it likes it or not. I will come to that in a moment. With world production at 97 million tonnes, we have to look at what other recent inputs there have been to the world market that would place the Australian industry in difficulty. I think the major recent one of those is the imposition of the United States import quotas. Despite what the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) consistently says-he consistently manages to get his sums wrong in this area-probably the most that we can look at importing into the United States market while quotas are in place will be 200,000 tonnes of sugar, which leaves us, on current exports, which I admit are at record levels, some 150,000 tonnes down. That is an absolutely massive drop.

One of the other factors is that twice in the last six months, the international sugar price has gone through the floor. If we look at the London price, which is probably about the best indicator in this area, and if we look at the forward future market in this area, there is not much joy. Certainly anybody going into futures in sugar would need to be very careful at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —But some months ago it was the second highest on record. It has had its ups and downs.

—Yes, but I am talking about recent times. I want to give an indication of where we are actually going and why the ups and downs that we have had may not bottom out quite as rapidly as they did in the four years that Senator Crichton-Browne was talking about. The time span is not there.

SPEECH.PARA: Prices are about 70 to 75 per cent of what they were 18 months ago. I agree with Senator Thomas on that. Having taken those aspects into consideration though, what else is a problem in the Australian market? One of the other major problems is that the innovative person in the Queensland industry, the person who really got off his backside and worked hard in recent years, because we have had excellent, record crops, sought to expand his property. But this person has now been caught in a double pincer movement, first from lowering levels of sales and, secondly, from high interest rates. That is causing a problem.

If one travels through the Queensland sugar area one sees sugar farms on the market and advertised in real estate agencies. that is something we would not have seen last year. Traditionally, sugar farms in Queensland have not changed hands on the open market. The sale of a sugar farm in Queensland has been an in- market operation. If a sale was coming up, people in the industry knew that the farm was coming on to the market and it was bought before anyone outside the industry got to hear anything about it. But that is not the case now. Farms are advertised in the windows of real estate agencies and they are not being sold.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are coming to Western Australia.

—We will see about that. As someone remarked, what we actually need now is a disaster harvest, preferably in member countries of the European Economic Community. Quite frankly, that is about all that will get us out of our difficulties. That may account for an up- swing. At the moment I do not see it happening. Acts of God are very useful, but they do not come on call. My worry is that we do not have anywhere to go in the international sugar market and to be established and expanding a new industry at this time would undermine our credibility. It is a Commonwealth matter, precisely because the Commonwealth is a signatory to the International Sugar Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put another point. This may seem a parochial point to many people, but it weighs very heavily with the Queensland growers. The Queensland growers have been operating under quotas since 1929. They have taken less, they have planted less, for economic reasons. Those economic reasons have been in part Queensland reasons, but they have also, since 1937, been Australian reasons because of the Commonwealth-Queensland sugar agreement. There have been many occasions when the sugar industry in Queensland has had to bear the brunt, as it is doing at present, of the domestic sugar price agreement. Indeed, if we take everything into account, at the moment we are actually selling sugar in Australia at less than the cost of production. That is a cuckoo land operation and certainly cannot go on. That comes basically from a technical difficulty in the domestic sugar price agreement but I do not intend to go through that at this stage.

I say to those people who have been operating in the industry for a long time that I think there would be a certain amount of justice in their saying to somebody coming into the industry: 'How about coming in on roughly the same terms that we have been operating under? Don't just drop in on top'. I think an expansion at this point in time would make it extremely difficult to maintain the high efficiency of the sugar industry. I think it is beyond doubt-certainly nobody has thrown any doubt on this so far-that the sugar industry is one of our most efficient rural industries. It has constantly updated its technology. It has constantly sought new methods of efficient operation and production.

I turn briefly to the South Korean connection. The South Korean connection in this matter is fairly obvious and presumably anybody who knows anything about the Ord scheme certainly understands the South Korean connection.

Let me put a number of propositions which seem to me to be reasonable, although possibly sometimes difficult to substantiate, in order to paint a scenario as to why CSR, for example, cannot afford not to go into the Ord. First, if the Ord produced a couple of hundred thousand tonnes of sugar, which I believe is what is in Senator Thomas's mind in terms of what Korea might be looking at, certainly in its home market this would substitute our international sugar quota . Korea could also organise the price, of course, to make the investment in the Ord enterprise justifiable in commercial terms. A thoroughly flexible price exists in the internal market. There is no difficulty in Korea making it an economic proposition to grow sugar in the Ord area. If production there exceeded Korea's domestic requirements, there would be absolutely nothing to stop-indeed, the Commonwealth would have absolutely no legal way of stopping-the sales of excess production on the Australian market.

I disagree partly with Senator Walsh. From the technical details that I have seen I am led to believe that, in terms of efficiency and quality of sugar, the Ord scheme would probably present fairly heavy competition. However, I certainly agree with Senator Walsh that the interpolation of an experimental plot into an actual commercial operation is something that one ought never to undertake, certainly not in the way that Senator Crichton-Browne did.

Let us say that Korea's domestic requirements fell below the Ord River's production. In that event, obviously the Ord would sell into the Australian market. In a way, they would be selling cheap sugar. The sale of this cheap sugar would render CSR's domestic milling operations uneconomic. I estimate that roughly 20 per cent of CSR's milling operation could be substituted by an Ord operation. One reason CSR has to go is to protect its own investment. Secondly, the distribution of sugar moneys between millers and growers-the CSR exercise is the one I am looking at in particular-would also put South Korea in the box seat in relation to refining and possibly also would destroy CSR on its home ground. Again, on the figures that I have seen it would be an economic proposition, so why not? Again it is a very good reason why CSR should go in and protect its own patch of the market. I think that the types of argument that Senator Crichton- Browne put up by saying that these reputable companies will not go into an operation which is not commercial is very true, but one has to look behind the industry politics to see, first, why the operation would be commercial-I think I have put at least one reasonable proposition on why that would be so-and, secondly, why a company like CSR or Bundaberg Sugar or anybody else could not afford to stay out, simply because their own impetus, their own raison d'etre for existence, is to make a profit. Therefore, companies have to look ahead, trim their markets and enter into agreements to make sure that such a potential operator in a domestic area will not seriously disrupt their production levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is called free enterprise.

—Correct. I think one needs to be extremely careful in making the types of statements Senator Crichton-Browne made. This area is fraught with difficulties and dangers. Justifiable claims can be made for the industry as it operates at the moment. Justifiable claims are being made as to why those companies are in there attempting to protect their own patches. There are also justifiable claims that Australia ought to protect its export markets in the international scheme and be excessively careful not to be seen at a time of world sugar glut to be setting up a new industry in competition with our well- established industries and selling against ourselves to our ultimate detriment. I hope that when we next come to this matter the debate will be a little more enlightened than the contribution Senator Crichton-Browne made today.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Act 1955 which was the subject of an amending Bill-the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1982-which was introduced in the Senate on 11 March 1982 and which had its second reading on 28 April 1982.

The amending Bill increased to 2.5 cents per kilogram the rate of charge to be paid for the purposes of meeting the costs of operation of the Australian Tobacco Board and providing funds for research. It provided for the rate of charge to be made higher or lower by regulation.
A maximum rate of charge was not specified in the Bill. The intention was to avoid the need for further legislation at some time in the future for the sole purpose of increasing the maximum rate.
It has now been accepted that the principle of stating a maximum in the legislation, as has been done in all rural industry research legislation in the past, should be applied in this case.
This Bill will establish a maximum rate of charge of 6 cents per kilogram. It will be possible for the operative rate of 2.5 cents per kilogram to be increased up to that ceiling by regulation.
I commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of this legislation reflects badly on the administrative efficiency of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). A package of three Bills-the Tobacco Charge Bill (No. 1), the Tobacco Charge Bill (No. 2) 1982 and the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1982-one of which is being debated, was set down for debate in the Senate on 4 May. On that day I was told that amendments would be moved in the Senate and the Bills were not debated. On 5 May an altered set of Bills was introduced in the House of Representatives and, I might say, apparently drafted, debated and passed within 24 hours. This further documents the Minister's inefficiency and incompetence. These Bills increase the research levy paid by growers and manufacturers of tobacco and provides for further increases in that levy up to a maximum of 2 1/2c per kilogram to be imposed by regulation. The Opposition supports the Bills. We understand that the tobacco growers and tobacco manufacturers do likewise.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the extent and emphasis of tobacco research fortunately have changed. The current emphasis is on reducing the usage of fertilisers and chemicals both for cost production reasons and in order to ameliorate, or in the hope of ameliorating a quite serious pollution problem which has developed in some tobacco growing areas. Research is also being directed-I do not wish to provoke Senator Elstob or touch off another slanging match between him and Senator Peter Baume-towards producing strains of tobacco which will be less injurious to health. Senator Elstob is not here anyway so I will not touch off anything.

There is very strong evidence that money generally spent on agricultural research is money wisely invested. Even in the purely economic sense, although one can never be certain in advance of whether any particular research project will pay its way, the aggregate of the evidence that is available from agricultural research supports very strongly the view that money spent in that research is money wisely invested, and that at least to some extent further money spent on agricultural research will also be wisely invested. In this case, apart from the economic reasons for increasing research expenditure, which is largely funded by industry but also funded to some extent by the Commonwealth, other than purely economic objectives are being pursued and, it is hoped, can be achieved. The Opposition supports the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a slightly difficult position because I have not been able to get hold of a copy of the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill. My understanding is that the Bill we are debating is one which has replaced another Bill and one which now picks up the criticisms which the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills made in its fourth report and acknowledged in its seventh report. The original Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill permitted the making of regulations to increase charges. It was thought that removing the ceiling on amounts that could be specified in regulations might be an inappropriate delegation of legislative power to the Minister concerned. I understand-I take this on trust-that the Bill we are debating does indeed pick up the criticisms which were made in the Committee's report. In that sense I thank the Government for having noted those recommendations and having acted in accordance with them. The Bill is now at hand and I see that the regulation power is indeed different. I think it accords with the recommendations of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of this legislation. I acknowledge the comments of Senator Missen. The Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill is one of a number of Bills that have been amended following attention being drawn to certain aspects of them by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It is interesting that I have had the conduct of a number of those Bills on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon. I think he has been most receptive to the views put forward by the Committee and has agreed to amendments on, I think, four if not five occasions. I welcome the support which has been given to the Bill and commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Bills being considered together in Committee of the Whole and the questions with regard to the remaining stages for the passage of the Bills through the Senate being put in one motion at each stage.

Family Law Legislation

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1981MAINTENANCE ORDERS (COMMONWEALTH OFFICERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Martyr had moved by way of amendment:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn to enable a new Bill to be drafted which consolidates the provisions of the Family Law Act 1975 and the Marriage Act 1961 to govern the making, subsistence and, if necessary, dissolution of marriage, and which provides for-
(a) the establishment within the institution of marriage of the principle of preparation for, permanence of, and commitment to, marriage, including marriage contracts;

(b) abolition of the Family Court of Australia, with original jurisdiction being vested in a State Court exercising Federal jurisdiction, and a Family Division of the Federal Court exercising appellate jurisdiction;

(c) the 'no-fault' provision of the existing law to be replaced by 'just cause' and annulment provisions and the twelve month period of separation within the existing law to be extended to two years, except for annulments, and all marriage dissolution matters to be heard at once before decree nisi; and
(d) the abolition of the Family Law Council and the Institute of Family Studies '.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this rather piecemeal approach to family law reform, I understand that I have five minutes to talk before the Senate by agreement will move to other business. Last night I reached the stage, also after a very short period, of looking at the matrimonial offences which existed under the old Matrimonial Causes Act as grounds for divorce. I commented upon the fact that grounds have been extended to cover separation. Whatever matrimonial offence was used as the ground for divorce, the status of the parties nevertheless came to be separation because of the fact that the offence could not be condoned if the action for dissolution was to be successful. It was therefore to me a small step to remove ''matrimonial offence'' and to look solely to separation as evidence of the destruction of the fabric of marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: As a practitioner under the old Matrimonial Causes Act and a witness of the bitterness, the hatred and the hunt to prove guilt, with the public record of matrimonial misbehaviour, and the apparent detrimental effect upon parties and children, I have little doubt that the changed legislation was the correct road to take. The question remained, however, as to what period of separation was necessary to show irreconcilable breakdown. The Parliament could have decided on a period of two years as is the case in Great Britain and which is still advocated by some sections of the community. I recognise, however, that there are some cases which involve a totally innocent spouse who should have every entitlement to terminate the legal tie of what has been an intolerable marriage. I do not see why that spouse should have to wait two years to take action. In Britain such a party would, of course, be covered by the additional matrimonial fault provisions but I would be equally disappointed to see a backward step in that direction. There are few professionals who would say that there is a reasonable chance of reconciliation after a period of separation of one year and I therefore believe that the Parliament of Australia earlier reached the right conclusion. I am pleased that this Bill does not propose to alter that situation .

It is impossible to evaluate with certainty the effect of the changes to the 1975 Act. I recognise that on its face it is the innocent who appear to have been aggrieved by its provisions. It is not always easy-in fact, it is generally difficult-to apportion guilt and innocence in matrimonial breakup but clearly in some cases there is a totally innocent, deserving spouse. That spouse may not only feel wronged within marriage but also could now have the marriage brought to an end by the guilty party after a relatively short period. I cannot, however , attempt to evaluate the psychological advantage or disadvantage to a spouse, on the one hand being able to prove publicly himself or herself wronged and, on the other hand, to hold out at his or her discretion for a period of five years against the interests of the guilty party. I cannot weigh that against the hurt of prolonging the period of time before the dissolution is reached, the period during which time such hurt is often nurtured. More dramatic, however, is the fact that we have now legislated for easy divorce. It is argued by some that divorce is now so easy that it tends to destroy the status of marriage. In other words it is argued that the law has failed in its responsibility to bastion the basic social institutions. It is an important charge deserving of serious consideration. It is a charge that I shall deal with on a future occasion. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-By agreement, it is proposed that the Senate now, at 2.15 p.m., consider the ministerial papers which were tabled on 27 May last. It was an undertaking of the Government on the last day of sitting that these papers would be considered at an early stage during the Budget session. I understand that the Whips have considered the matter of how best to deal with the papers. On their suggestion, might I put the proposition to the Senate that the papers be considered in the same way as we have done earlier today as prescribed by Sessional Order. A list of the papers tabled on 27 May has been circulated to honourable senators.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I think that this report has probably stirred more interest in the academic and business industries than any other report for some considerable time. It has been part of the conference grist for the mill operation and has probably spawned its own little industry which hopefully will be good for business. I would like to make some comments about the types of assumptions that are made in the report and raise what I believe are some of the concerns that are being expressed, particularly in universities around Australia where business management has traditionally taken place.

Can I say at the outset that the report is not only limited to those institutions which are currently mentioned in it because many other institutions , not only universities but also colleges of advanced education, have a considerable stake in this area in one or the other. It is made very clear, of course, that the report does not deal with very large areas such as educational administration. Rather, it deals specifically with the direct notion of business education.

I would like to turn to what I see as some of the major limitations of the report. First of all, I do not understand, and there is in fact no good reason given in the report, why management education should be considered only a post- graduate phenomenon. I think the report ignores-certainly the section of the report which deals with small business indicates that-the growing volume of generalist and functional undergraduate programs in the United States of America , Europe, Britain, Canada, South Africa and also Australia. Those generalist, functional types of operations are an innovative program and as such I believe ought to be fostered and continued particularly in respect of small business. I would refer here to much of the excellent work being done by the University of South Africa in relation to this phenomenon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a question of credential?
