—No, it is not. It is a question of what type of program could be mounted at a university at a particular level.
—Could I seek your help? Does the report address itself to the credential or to the course? I think that is a central point of consideration of the Ralph report.

—The major thrust of the report is one of organisation. It is concerned with the organisation of business management and makes a number of assumptions. The assumption to which I am referring is that this is a post- graduate phenomenon. It seems to me that is not an argued proposition; it is an assumed proposition within the report. I am putting a counter proposition that it should not necessarily be assumed that management education is a post- graduate phenomenon. I am pointing out how elsewhere in the world there has been a considerable increase in the undergraduate area, to a very effective level, I believe. This goes back to the point that small business requires in this area not only undergraduate but also diploma or non-certificated courses because people cannot really afford to do the higher level course. If we are considering only big business, presumably one might be looking only in this area. That is a further point that I wish to make later. In many of the masters programs that are being suggested, the emphasis seems to be very much on very large management operations and that we need management education right across the board in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there is an assumption, in fact an assertion and some recommendations , that people cannot get an M.B.A., certainly a high quality M.B.A. at least, on a part time basis. I think that is a highly questionable assumption, and I wish to refer again to overseas courses in terms of innovative approaches and alternative systems. There are weekend executive programs where a person comes in for a weekend and then may not appear again for six to eight weeks for another weekend. These programs are geared very much to the idea of someone who is operating in the field but who needs additional support from an institution. At last count I was able to ascertain over 60 such programs are now in operation in America. I think it would be rather absurd if we were to go in the opposite direction from the extremely prestigious business schools such as the ones in Houston, Texas and Chicago.

Thirdly, the notion that there has to be some type of critical mass of students is a very attractive one on the surface, and presumably it would be attractive to government in terms of the amounts of money it is going to spend. However, a critical mass operation applied to other professional facilities in Australia would, I suggest, lead to uncontrollable operations. Indeed, when one suggests this in relation to other professions one sees the rather threadbare types of arguments and support that can be applied in this area.

Another set of problems that I merely point to relates to an underestimation of the need for funding doctoral programs at a regional level. I believe that this ignores the reality of universities. If we are going to build a top class business school in one or two areas-the additional area outside Sydney as suggested in this report is Melbourne-then we will be in for a running down of our regional schools. There is no way in the world that we will attract a top class person to teach only undergraduates. The Government should not ignore what is a fact of employment life in universities. A top quality person will not put up with teaching only undergraduates. He will go to where he has doctoral students. It is a necessary gravitation. Such a proposal would kill off regional schools, thereby killing off the opportunity to do part time operations, to do in-house operations, and to have flexible delivery systems of the type that I have briefly referred to. Therefore, I think the notion, attractive though it may be as the central proposition in this report, that there be a national school has died. It is something out of the 1950s or the 1960s. Yes, it was good at that point. That is what we believed was really on. That was what we needed. We do not need it now and business does not need it now, except at the very top levels, and if it is at the very top levels people will probably be paid to go to Harvard, Chicago or Houston anyhow. That is what happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would make it much harder if there were only one national school.

—Yes, I will acknowledge that so that it can go into the Hansard . The break between undergraduate and graduate education which the report suggests is, I believe, fundamentally at error in the university scene. I do not know how it came about, but it is in there. I think anybody who knows anything about the way universities operate and how we get quality post-graduates will realise there has to be continuity. This goes back partly to staff, partly to equipment, partly to the relationships between the institution and the outside society.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I have time today to make is a vital one. Although I hope that we can have a fuller debate on this because it is an extremely important issue. The ability of the universities or the colleges of advanced education to provide effectively in this area requires them to be integrated as fully as possible with the business they are serving. Therefore we need not massive national schools but quality schools in regional areas. One national school, I agree with . I do not think we need any more. We need quality regional schools that are linked in every State with their management, and it is the management which will provide the quality and the practical experience to the staff. Indeed, many colleges of advanced education and universities around Australia are using people from industry on a part time basis. I would like that idea to be promoted , and I hope that at some future stage we will be able to have a longer debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1981MAINTENANCE ORDERS (COMMONWEALTH OFFICERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my third attempt to continue the piecemeal discussion of family law reform. A little while ago I had reached the stage of the important problem having accepted that we legislated for simple and easy divorce, whether in doing so the legislature has failed in a social responsibility to support marriage. I support the responsibility of the community and the laws reflecting that responsibility to work against marriage breakdowns. Although the number of divorces has risen considerably now that the procedure is easier, I can find no evidence to show that the level of marriage breakdowns is rising. It may well be that in the past there were as many breakdowns of marriage but that the legal tie was not so often broken. I can see no reason why a marriage which is not a marriage should be supported by the law simply for the sake of preserving statistics. It may well be that the parties are separated or, even if they are not legally separated, living in an environment that is totally unsatisfactory to the well being of their children.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme of the Family Law Act is basically to deal with a situation in which a marriage breakdown has occurred and then to provide a humane, compassionate and effective forum for resolving matters between the parties and dealing with the future of the children. To claim that it is a function of this Act to bulwark the institution of marriage is to give it a role that was never envisaged. This misunderstanding, I believe, is at the root of so much of he criticism of the Act.

I have said that the community and the law have this responsibility to support the institution of marriage and the family. However, it is not the role of legislation designed to deal with a situation of resolving problems after a breakdown. It is true in some cases reconciliation may be possible and the Act must be flexible enough to allow for those few cases, but they will be rare exceptions. In the vast majority of cases when the parties commence proceedings under the Family Law Act and irreconcilable breakdown has occurred.

Those who condemn the Act as causing breakdown would do better to look to other ways in which the community and law can support marriage and the family-for example, in the encouragement of and, if necessary, financial assistance to, voluntary counselling organisations, in finding ways to overcome the stress of unemployment and in seeking ways to overcome the damage caused by financial pressures. Those who condemn the Act would do better to look to the income tax laws and ask whether those laws sufficiently recognise and support the institution of marriage. Quite clearly, to parties who are financially better off unmarried, they do not. The churches and social groups must recognise their support responsibility where much greater contribution can be made than in advocating technical changes to an Act dealing with the dissolution of marriage. Strengthening community support takes more than changing a law.

As I have said, the Family Law Act principally concerns events after an irreconciliable breakdown. Therefore, the ones who most often suffer in such circumstances are the innocent, the children. Whether they suffer in addition by the severing of the legal tie is highly problematical. The community and law have a responsibility in relation to the innocent victims of marriage breakdown and divorce. Thus, it demands that simply because the parties have dissolved their marriage, they should each still have a responsibility for care and maintenance of the children until a court determines otherwise. In other words, the parents will retain joint custody. Obviously there are some circumstances in which one parent should have custody to the exclusion of the other. In some cases, the conduct of one party evidences a total failure of responsibility.

In all cases, however, the primary consideration must be and is, in fact, what is in the best interests of the child. I am satisfied that, generally speaking, it is in the best interests of children if litigation is avoided. However, the community has a responsibility to satisfy itself that any agreement reached between the parties is in the best interests of the child. I believe the court should be able to order separate representation for children when it deems it appropriate. Similarly, if it is concerned as to the suitability of both parents , it should be able to include, as a party to the proceedings, an appropriate child welfare officer. The court should always take into account the wishes of the child. They should be weighed in the light of such factors as age and maturity but the court should not be bound by those wishes. Bearing in mind in particular the strength of parental influence, it is the court's overriding responsibility to make the decision on behalf of the community as to what is in the best interests of the child.

In matters of custody, parents should be able to bring proceedings before the court as soon as the separation occurs-again, the overriding consideration being what is in the best interests of the child. The behaviour of parents should be taken into account to the extent that it affects their suitability as parents and custodians. Therefore, in my opinion it is relevant to take into account behaviour which destroys a marriage or a stable family life because it may be relevant to whether or not the party is able to meet the responsibilities of a parent. Thus, evidence of promiscuity or cruelty appears to me to be relevant. It might run against the scheme of the Act but where the interests of children are concerned, those interests must be paramount.

It must be remembered that access is the right of the child, not the parent, and so similiar considerations apply. Courts should be able to vary custody and access orders when it is in the best interests of children to do so. Obviously it is better to get the correct decision in the first instance but mistakes do occur and circumstances change. Matters of custody and welfare of children should have priority over all other Family Court matters. On the death of a custodian, custody should not revert automatically to the other parent. The Court should be given greater guidance as to matters to be taken into account when deciding what is in the best interests of children.

I do, however, briefly raise a fundamental question which does not appear to have been addressed by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, and that is, the question of whether, in a helping situation, a legally qualified judge is best qualified to determine the major social matters involved. Although I am of the opinion that in every dispute concerning children there should be a thorough evaluation of the circumstances by a social worker who should report to the court, I still have reservations as to whether someone who is trained to determine questions of fact and to apply legal principles to such answers is best qualified to determine what is in the future best interests of the child. I would support contested custody cases being determined by a board consisting of a judge and two other persons who perhaps have experience in such fields as social welfare and child psychology. I recognise that increased costs would be involved but I see that as the price in the community must pay in best intersts of its children.

Questions of maintenance of the children also must be decided. In this case I believe both sides should be obliged by the community to meet the responsiblity to maintain their children, even if their marriage has broken down. As this is an obligation the community should impose, it should be enforced by the community not by the other spouse. The contribution of maintenance may be in personal service or it may be a monetary contribution according to the circumstances of the parents and according to such questions as where the child is primarily living. If the parents are unable to maintain the child the community as a whole must meet that responsibility.

I find the subject of spouse maintenance more difficult. The Act, of course, provides for a limited obligation for a spouse to maintain the other, even in marriage. I see there is a strong argument that upon a dissolution not only should the spouse have a right of action to support maintenance but also the community should be entitled to bring that action to protect its financial interests. In marriage, often by mutual agreement the capacity of one party to maintain fairly himself or herself is detrimentally affected. If, through no fault of that person, the marriage is dissolved he or she may be considerably worse off. Therefore, it does not seem unreasonable to me that the other party should contribute to maintenance of the parties whose position has been financially detrimentally affected by the marriage. It is a decision, however, that should be made by the Court in all the circumstances. Thus the conduct of the claiming spouse must again be relevant.

The other major area of dispute concerns property. As a general principle, I believe that property accumulated during a marriage should be shared equally at the dissolution of that marriage. Such a principle of community of property does not presently exist in this country although there have been trends in the courts in that direction. I would like the Court, however, to have greater guidance to that end. I have no objection to the parties to a marriage contracting questions of property but I still think the Court should have an overriding discretion. This would particularly be so when the interests of children might be affected by the contract.

There are a number of other matters to which I wish to refer briefly. The first concerns injunctions. I believe there must be a power in the areas of custody, maintenance, property and principle relief to protect both the property interests and the physical wellbeing of the parties and children. Therefore, procedures for injunction must be continued. The second matter relates to reconciliation and conciliation. As I mentioned earlier, the unfortunate truth is that by the time the parties reach the Family Court the opportunity for reconciliation generally has passed. Court counsellors, because of the pressures of duty and the environment of the Court, may not be suitable reconciliators in any event. Therefore, I believe they must have a close working relationship with the marriage guidance councils, churches and other social groups which have the time to contribute and are prepared to contribute in this area. On the other hand, Court counsellors must work as conciliators with the aim of lessening the bitterness and distress where possible. They must work towards a sensible resolution of the interests of the parties, particularly of children, during the course of the divorce. The role of the court conciliators should be separate and distinct from that of welfare officers advising the Court.

The third area is in relation to the court's appellate jurisdiction. There has been considerable criticism of the frequency of conflicting decisions. It would appear that the range of judges in the appellate court is too great. I believe that if the current single judge court is to remain the appellate court should be more limited in number. If appeals are to be on questions other than law I believe that appellate judges should have the continuing experience of sitting at first instance. If my suggestions in relation to a broad sitting in contested custody matters were adopted I see no reason why there should be an appeal from such decisions on questions of fact.

The fourth aspect concerns joint application. I recognise that legal purists and supporters of the adversary system in family law matters argue against such applications. However, I believe that their view is outdated, that where parties are in agreement and the period of separation has taken place they should be able jointly to initiate an action to bring the marriage to an end.

The fifth area concerns what is misleadingly referred to as divorce by post. It is, of course, not divorce by post. It differs from current procedure only in that if the respondent has no objection the applicant need not attend in person or be represented by counsel. The determination is still made on the same evidence, that of the application and the supporting affidavits. The advantage is stated to be a saving of court time and costs. It makes divorce easier only to the extent that it saves counsel fees if counsel is, in fact, to be engaged. The position of the respondent is protected in that the court must still be satisfied as to the basic facts and, in any event, the respondependent can object to the procedure.

I found this a difficult question to decide, particularly when children of the marriage are involved. In such circumstances I believe that the applicant, or counsel, should appear. I say that notwithstanding that I recognise that under section 63 of the Act the court must nevertheless be satisfied as to the circumstances of the children before the decree may become absolute. If in such circumstances a report by a welfare officer as to the arrangements for children being satisfactory, were submitted I would be less concerned. When questions affecting children are not involved and there is no objection by the respondent I see no real reason why the change recommended by the Joint Committee, one which is in operation in Britain, should not be supported. However, I believe that the court should specify a date on which the matter will be considered so that evidence of certainty will be retained. I have considered the contrary arguments advanced, such as respect for the solemnity of the situation, but cannot see that the failure of counsel or applicant to attend the final stage makes any difference whatsoever. It might be argued that it makes divorce just a little bit easier but, as I have indicated, I believe that is attempting to place upon the Act a responsibility which is not its obligation.

Sixthly, ideally I prefer closed hearings on family law matters. That may well be a prejudice which I developed in witnessing abuse under the Matrimonial Causes Act. However, it is consistent with my earlier argument that the community has an interest in seeing whether the obligations that it imposes on parties, as to maintenance, custody et cetera, are carried out. There has often been criticism that the court is not meeting its obligation to the community. Therefore, I am prepared to accept that some scrutiny is wise and, accordingly, to accept the recommendations of the Joint Committee as a fair compromise.

The seventh point concerns costs. The jurisdiction obviously requires considerable financial support by the community. Therefore I accept that, as a general proposition, costs should not be ordered. In some cases children require representation and it is more important that they be represented than that the costs involved should be raised. I would like to see left to the court discretion to issue orders for costs in cases of vexatious and unmeritorious litigation and appeals.

Finally, there is the subject of the Family Law Council and the Institute of Family Studies. I have argued today that the need for support in the prevention of marriage breakdown is paramount, but this can be better achieved by extending our knowledge in such areas as family stress. Therefore, I wholeheartedly support the concept of the Institute of Family Studies and the work that it is doing. There should be a continuing review of the court and other instrumentalities in the field and, similarly, I support the Family Law Council and its contribution in most difficult areas. It is within the scheme of this speech that, at the Committee stage, I will approach the question of individual amendments.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Walters:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I take the opportunity to bring to the attention of the Senate the major findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, as set out in its report entitled 'Homeless Youth'. The report comes at a time when there is strong interest and concern in the community about unemployment, poverty, family breakdown and the basic fabric of society itself. Our report covers all these areas, but it is important to realise that our terms of reference concerned matters affecting homeless youth and not the community at large. Therefore, the findings and recommendations of the Committee do not come up with a blueprint for an overall community strategy to deal with these problems, rather a strategy to deal specifically with the question of homeless youth.

SPEECH.PARA: In this regard the Committee has developed a 12-point strategy which it urges both government and the community-which includes families particularly-to acknowledge and recognise. Later I will seek permission to have those 12 points incorporated in Hansard. In assessing the nature of the problem it was apparent that a large proportion of homeless youth come from broken families or families facing crisis. This seriously concerned the Committee. Is it that the stresses and demands of modern society, coupled with economic hardship, are placing unprecedented pressures on the family unit or, rather, that today the family unit is not coping with the pressures as well as it did in the past? It appeared to the Committee that the answer was a combination of both of these factors. Family conflict and breakdown, unemployment, low socio-economic background, little education, lack of skills, emotional problems and social inadequacies are all factors which seem to typify the situation of the majority of homeless youth who use the available services. It seems to the Committee that it is most likely to be the youths who have already been socially disadvantaged, who have missed out throughout most of their lives, who will end up homeless, not the young people who have enjoyed a fairly stable family life and a fair share of life's benefits. If this is the case, the Committee felt that it was important to try to identify these youths before they became homeless, to adopt as far as possible a preventive approach. The school, because of its wide-ranging yet relatively personal contact with young people, is perhaps the best place to perform this role.

When it came to an assessment of the extent of the problem the Committee found the statistics to be so unreliable that it hesitated to refer to them at all. The Committee felt that until such time as a properly conducted survey is undertaken, with adequate supervision and control, there will contine to be only conjecture as to the actual extent of the problem and whether it is increasing. However, this does not mean that the program should be delayed until such time as the full extent of the problem is known. I believe that in recent times one of the major factors bringing the plight of homeless youth to the attention of the public was the establishment of the Commonwealth-State funded youth refuge scheme, which commenced on 1 July 1979. Under this jointly funded program 68 agencies have been funded. They have been able to offer 86 separate services. In all, these have provided some 750 beds for emergency accommodation.

The Committee was favourably impressed with the work of some of these refuges. However, they are not the solution to the problem of homelessness. The Committee believes that the most effective response to the problem would be to provide medium and long term supportive accommodation. Nonetheless, the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth-State funded Youth Services Scheme be continued, but with a substantial upgrading of accommodation facilities in most youth refuges.

As already indicated, without uniform and reliable statistics, it is most likely that policy initiatives in this area will be of an ad hoc nature. The Committee has therefore recommended that a properly financed and managed statistical collection must be undertaken and this should form part of an ongoing Commonwealth-State youth services scheme.

I now move on to what I regard as the major findings of the Committee's inquiry into homeless youth. What is urgently required is access to appropriate medium to long term housing and for many young people this should be of a supportive household type. The long term housing needs for youth, however, must be considered in the context of the needs of all other disadvantaged groups. Bearing this in mind, the Committee has recommended that part of the general low cost housing shortage could be alleviated by more effective utilisation of existing stocks of Commonwealth and State dwellings. Too many government-owned properties are lying idle at a time when there is a growing demand for low cost accommodation. The Committee believes that the Commonwealth and State governments need to monitor closely the utilisation of all public housing stocks and adopt a more flexible approach to the leasing and renting of such dwellings.

I now turn to specific housing programs for homeless youth. The Senate would already be aware that the Commonwealth Government announced on 30 September 1980 that it was providing $10m over three years under the Homeless Persons Assistance Program for specific capital projects. Even though some of this money has already been allocated, the Committee has recommended that part of the remaining $10m be made available to community-based management groups to help establish supportive youth households in areas of demonstrated need. The Committee has strongly recommended that this money be made available to renovate , refurbish and modernise existing dwellings that are currently lying idle within a number of regions. This in effect would provide assets many times greater in value than the contribution made. The Committee believes that this approach, rather than the general advertising for housing proposals, will result in a greater utilisation of resources and less likelihood of duplication of facilities within regions.

In fact, the Committee has gone further and suggested that preference for Commonwealth funding be given to those proposals which aim to provide more than basic shelter for their clients. If such schemes can demonstrate that they are able to provide a supportive household environment, then the Committee strongly believes that both Commonwealth and State governments should give further consideration to providing additional funds for such schemes under the Housing Assistance Act 1981.

While the Committee is strongly committed to the development of medium to long term supportive households, the Committee nonetheless believes that homeless youth should not become isolated from the rest of the community. Therefore, the Committee saw a great deal of merit in the introduction of universal bond insurance and/or bond and rental assistance schemes. Such schemes would help homeless youth whose only barrier to successful independent living is one of limited financial resources. The schemes would also be of assistance to youths who are ready to move from a supportive household to full independent living.

By far the most difficult area to tackle was the area of income security. As already mentioned, the Committee was very mindful of the fact that it needed to consider issues as they specifically affected homeless youth. The issue of unemployment benefits was far broader than the terms of reference of this inquiry and the Committee therefore found it difficult to isolate the issue of homelessness and income security from the general issue of income security.

It would seem that the present philosophy of the Government with regard to the junior unemployment rate of, as it was, $36 is that it is only meant to support those 16 and 17-year-olds living in the parental home. The economic and social factors on which the junior rate was set six years ago have altered significantly and it is therefore important that the Government make clear the basis on which the junior rate is determined and what that rate is expected to cover. Not only would it be impossible for anyone to live independently on $36 a week, but in the case of a number of other unemployed youth, that amount of money would not be sufficient to support them in the family home, particularly if the parents are unemployed or are in receipt of a pension. While I am encouraged by the recent Budget announcement to lift this rate by 11 per cent to $40 as from November 1982, it still does not lessen the concerns I have just raised.

Bearing in mind the current level and duration of unemployment and in particular youth unemployment, coupled with the medium to long term employment prospects, the Committee has recommended that an allowance equivalent to the difference between the over 18 years of age unemployment benefit rate and the junior unemployment benefit rate should be made available to certain unemployed youth under 18 years of age. These would include, firstly, those who have had to establish themselves for one reason or another away from the family or statutory home and, secondly, those whose families' financial circumstances are such that the additional benefit would enable the family to remain together as a unit rather than the young person being forced into possible homelessness. Apart from special instances, this allowance, we believe, should be paid directly to the hostel or supportive household which is accommodating the young person, after an appropriate application has been made on his or her behalf. This allowance would be regarded by the hostel or household as a significant proportion of that young person's full board and lodging.

What I believe has to be taken into consideration by the Government is that the recommendations put forward by my committee are a package and that the success of each recommendation is very much dependent on the Government adopting all the recommendations. We have been very mindful throughout our report of the current economic conditions and the many other competing groups in the social welfare area for the limited available resources.

Finally, I believe that the recommendations made in our report are both practical and sound and certainly cannot be regarded as extravagant in the current economic climate. There is no easy formula which neatly divides the areas of responsibility for homeless youth among the various levels of government, the family and the community at large. I believe there needs to be a minimum level of service provided nationally which can be supplemented at the State or local level depending on the particular needs within each region. If governments provide the necessary resources to enable homeless youth to cope with their immediate problems of food and shelter and to help them to become productive members of the community, the immediate cost is likely to be far outweighed by the long term social and economic benefits. Failure to address the problem of youth homeless in the short term may in fact nurture a potential skid row population.

In conclusion I wish to express my personal appreciation to my fellow Committee members for their contributions during the inquiry and during the deliberations which followed. I should also like to record the Committee's gratitude to a former member of the Committee, Jean Melzer. (Extension of time granted). She made a valuable contribution not only to this report but also to many previous reports of the Committee. In addition, I should like to record the Committee's gratitude for the co-operation and assistance received from State governments and many departments, organisations and individuals throughout the inquiry. Our thanks go also to the Committee staff, to our own personal staffs and to the various specialist staffs of the parliament for their ready response to our many and varied needs during the inquiry. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to have the 12 points to which I referred earlier incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
1. That families have a legal and/or moral responsibility to support and shelter their children up to at least 18 years of age.

2. That when family support breaks down irretrievably or is non-existent both government and the community have a clear responsibility to provide the necessary support for the young person until such time as he or she is able to make the final transition to full independent living. Indications for intervention at any other stage by government are not at all clearcut and therefore it cannot be taken that assistance will be automatic and unconditional . Care must be taken that government does not usurp the responsibility of parents under most family situations.

3. That young people have obligations and cannot expect that the community will unconditionally support them if they wish to become independent without first being able to establish appropriate living skills and secure full-time employment.
4. That family breakdown and youth unemployment are major factors which are associated with youth homelessness.
5. That there is no perfect substitute for a strong supportive family network and full-time employment, and therefore any youth housing programs and income support schemes must be second best.
6. That homeless youth programs should not isolate homeless youth from mainstream society.
7. That homeless youth are individuals and the delivery of any program to assist them must acknowledge that personal needs of each participant may vary considerably.

8. That homeless youth are an integral part of our community and their rights to public housing should be recognised. However, the needs of one group should always be seen in the context of the needs of all other groups.

9. That greater utilisation of social welfare resources can only be achieved by greater co-operation between the many well-established agencies and newly emerging groups. There is a need for greater co-operation rather than competition.

10. That government sponsored youth housing programs should endeavour to make full use of all existing dwellings before new capital programs are approved. There are many hostels, institutions and houses that are either lying idle or grossly under-utilised. Every effort should be made to assist schemes which can bring these types of accommodation up to an acceptable standard for homeless youth.

11. That Commonwealth Government funds for homeless youth programs be made available only to community groups and organisations, who have fully costed their proposals and have laid down clearly identifiable standards, goals and objectives and are willing to submit necessary data to facilitate the planning of services.
12. That Commonwealth Government funds for homeless youth should be made available on the basis of a demonstrated need in a particular region or district .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This being the first published document of any Senate standing committee with which I have been involved, I feel a certain proprietary interest in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare and welcome the opportunity to make a contribution to the debate. The quality of the report-its summary of the large amount of evidence provided, its inclusion of a large amount of factual information and statistics that were provided and which have since been obtained-I believe, is a credit to the Committee and its Chairman, and certainly to the secretary and his staff.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the tone of part of the report is somewhat moralising, tends to be value-ridden and includes a bit of pop psychology. I wish to dissociate myself from that particular aspect of the report. I have been concerned all along that the families of homeless youth have been portrayed to a degree as being culpable , of being inadequate and of being to a degree responsible for homelessness among the young. It is also invidious that a Committee which includes two career women should be seen to be publishing remarks about working women in this society and, at least to a degree, laying some responsibility on them for failure to be competent mothers. It seems to me that the families of homeless youth are every bit as much victims of a society which cannot cope with its problems as the young people themselves.

The recommendations are a useful approach to the problem in many respects and include a number of principles which I hope will be followed through and in better times expanded upon. It is good to see that we have come to conclusions which acknowledge the need for more financial support, not just for young homeless people but for their families as well, in an attempt to forestall the set of circumstances which often causes a family to rupture, to part company and to result in the homelessness of its adolescents.

It is also excellent to see in this report recognition of the fact that the $36 unemployment benefit, even increased now to $40, for 16 year olds and 17 year olds is totally inadequate. When it was introduced as a benefit for 16 year olds , it constituted 22.5 per cent of average weekly earnings. The $40 now available , since the Budget, for these young people in this age group represents only 12. 5 per cent of average weekly earnings. We have seen a recognition in this report , too, of the need for medium term and long term accommodation. The need for this is clearly expressed. The reasons for it are given with considerable emphasis. There can be no doubt in the mind of any government that is concerned for its young people that this should be a matter for immediate and urgent action.

We have also seen recognition of the fact that many of the workers in youth hostels and crisis centres are working for much less than award wages. The phenomenon of the 'burnt out' worker was described to us on a number of occasions. One of the recommendations of the Committee is that the form of funding for the Community Youth Services Scheme be adequate so that salary scales could be established for youth refuge workers that would be consistent with other rates of pay in the social welfare area. This cannot be done by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission unless there is an application from one of the parties. Recent developments in the industrial area have led us to believe that the current Government is not prepared to take that sort of initiative. On the contrary, it has opposed the efforts of the Australian Social Welfare Union to obtain a national award to make sure that these workers would not continue to be exploited.

However, my further disagreement with the report is that it fails to address with any efficiency at all the real causes of homelessness. I suggest that these are the sheer grinding poverty and the stress which accompanies it, which is consequent upon the current level of unemployment, and the criminal depletion of stocks of welfare and low cost housing. In December 1981 there were nearly 100, 000 people in Australia waiting to be housed. This has been one of the most important causes of households finding that they simply cannot accommodate their growing young people who in previous times would have been able to contribute to those households, who would have been out working and who would not have been blamed for creating the stresses that have developed.

Finally, I go to the first of the 12 points referred to by Senator Walters. It states that families have a legal and/or moral responsibility to support and shelter their children up to at least 18 years of age. To the extent that the Family Law Act 1975 lays down a legal responsibility for the material support of young people up to the age of 18 where this is practicable, one cannot possibly disagree. There is no doubt in my mind, however, that the moral responsibility for this particular problem should be clearly laid where it belongs-with the policies of the Government that we have had over the last seven years. Those policies have done nothing whatsoever to ensure that households are able to survive in dignity, that they are able to cope with the normal stresses and strains of living. The Government has done everything to deplete the stock of welfare and low cost housing. That is where the moral responsibility belongs and it is high time that something was done about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly about this report by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare and to echo some of the sentiments expressed by Senator Giles. The subject was not an easy one for the Committee to investigate and the report was not an easy one to write, not only for some of the reasons alluded to by Senator Walters, such as the great difficulty of getting any accurate statistical information about just what is happening in the area of youth homelessness. It was also difficult to write because of the difficulty in defining the problem and the boundaries of the problem to which the Committee could and should address itself, because of various circumstances which surrounded the writing of the report and because the commitments of many members of the Committee limited their contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: At one stage Senator Giles and I even considered writing an alternative report or writing alternative opinions into the report. Circumstances prevented us from doing that. I share her qualms about some of the language used in the report, particularly some of the glib explanations as to the role of families in the situation of youth homelessness and what seemed to be a tendency to make moral judgments about the position of families in the community. We had many a friendly battle about the wording which should have gone into the report, and maybe Senator Giles and I did not win as often as we thought we should have done . But in the end we felt better that the report should come out.

What we are saying is that basically we agree with the recommendations in the report, as general as they are. We were not in a position to make judgments on financial matters, not being part of the Government and not having the information available that the Government has in making specific recommendations , as, for instance, to the amounts of money people should get. But we were glad that the whole Committee and everyone who gave evidence to it recognised that the present sums paid, for instance, to those under 18 on unemployment benefits were ludicrous and derisory. I suggest that they still are, even after the Budget. There was recognition of the need to provide some assistance, either by direct payment or through other means, to enable young people in this situation to get into accommodation and to acquire the living skills necessary to live independently. As Senator Giles says, this is only one aspect of a very broad economic and social problem which faces Australia.

The best way in which we can improve the youth homelessness situation is to provide jobs, training and assistance, not only to the young unemployed, who make up the vast majority of this homelessness group, but also to their families . We need to get their families out of the grinding poverty which leads to young people being placed in this situation of homelessness. It is this poverty and lack of support by the community which has led us to the present situation, which all the States recognise as a very serious problem. Until we as a Parliament and as a community face up to this we will continue to have youth homelessness at the level at which it now exists. That level will continue to increase. All the moralising and blaming the families for their difficulties and for the so-called breakdowns which face them will not solve the problems of youth or society.

I hope that the report at least makes some of the more conservative people in our society realise, firstly, that there is a serious problem and that it exists in every State at an unacceptable level. Secondly, I hope that the report makes people realise the inadequate level of support we are giving to those members of our society whom we will not provide with a job or with an alternative to work. There is a need to give them far more assistance than we have in the past. Thirdly, there is a need for more public housing in general. More mid term and long term accommodation is required for this group in our community, and this aspect was alluded to in the report.

Finally, there is a very real need to sort out the legal responsibility in our society for those children aged between 14 years and 18 years. The responsibility not only of the parents of those children but of society has to be defined so that people in this area can work with some certainty, knowing just where they stand, where these young people stand, and where the responsibility lies. It should not be a case of glibly saying, as is so often the case in this Parliament and outside of it, that it is all the fault of the parents, whether they are suffering grinding poverty, unemployment or social disadvantage. From that point of view I believe the report will be a useful one. I hope that the Government will take it seriously. With the riders that both Senator Giles and I have mentioned, I recommend that all honourable senators take note of the report and gain some realisation of the very serious problem which faces this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare I wish to speak briefly to the report entitled ' Homeless Youth'. Whilst I note that it is a unanimous report, I am a little surprised at some of the criticism that has been made. Perhaps the criticism, call it what you will, relates to how a person sees the family situation, and I will touch on that in a moment. As honourable senators have indicated, the Committee on Social Welfare for its report on homeless youth put in considerable time in the various States of Australia and the Northern Territory reviewing the various programs and other factors that affect homeless youth. I believe it is true to say that all members of the Committee would have been surprised, perhaps as horrified, as I was at some of the situations we found throughout the country , particularly in the industrial cities. We saw many young people ranging from a very young age up to their twenties. In many of the places children aged between 11 years and 12 years were on the streets because they no longer had a home. On very many occasions children of this age and slightly older, but particularly children under 18 years of age, were living in very harsh conditions. In fact, they were on the street, and we found many who did not have even a semblance of a home. I remember that in Victoria we saw large industrial rubbish tins placed on the sides of the streets, and children were using these large containers in which to sleep at night, out of the weather. We saw children using empty houses, empty cars, anything where they could get out of the weather. As for eating, they had to live by their wits. In doing this, naturally they came up against the law. They were living on their wits and they stole, used any means whatsoever to enable them to live. This is a vast problem, but it varies to quite a degree through the different States.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a case of saying in the Senate that the family is responsible for all these situations. There should not be any bashing of the family, if one wants to express it in that way; far from it. I believe the problem does commence with the family, but the family is not to blame. I hasten to say that it is not always the family in the lower social scale and on lower wages where these problems occur. The fragmentation, the breakdown of families, children leaving home, occurs in families with a wide range of incomes. It is a fact that these days families are under considerable pressure and stress, whether for economic or other reasons. This has meant that in very many cases the family has been fragmented. The father has left and gone to somebody else, or the mother has left and has gone with somebody else, or for various reasons the child has been forcibly kicked out of the family home. For many reasons such as those the child in the family is unwanted-unwanted perhaps by the other partner, unwanted perhaps because that child was just another mouth to feed, or because the family did not want the responsibility of the child. So the child, either forcibly or through mental abuse, has been pushed out of the family. It is a very sad situation.

When describing this situation today it may be thought that it occurs only at one or two places in a suburb or perhaps once in a street. One of the difficulties we faced was in acquiring accurate statistics regarding the immensity of the problem. It has been shown in very many areas that the problem may be immense. I believe it is. Because of this, something has to be done. Various councils around Australia have provided houses for homeless youth and I congratulate the councils for taking such an interest; but much more has to be done by the Federal Government, State governments, and the third level of government-local government. Councils have assisted tremendously the various organisations in the community. It is somewhat horrific, and I do not think that is an exaggeration, to go into some of these broken down homes that were empty and are now used to house homeless youths. The houses themselves are in very poor condition. To see the grouping of these young people together, endeavouring to give each other company and support and to see people in the community endeavouring to help them is something that frankly I think most people should experience so that steps can be taken to overcome the problems.

The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Walters, has worked long and hard on this report. She has had the co-operation of the Committee and the co-operation of many other people to bring down this report. I believe it is an invaluable report. A vast number of reports come in from the community Australia-wide these days. When they first hit the desk of the Senate, they cause some interest or some alarm. But many of the reports gradually gather dust. Whilst it may be said that a particular report is a fine report and something should be done about the matter with which it is concerned, because of the immensity and pressures of government, on many occasions nothing is done. In these circumstances, in a situation where we have a percentage of the youth of Australia at risk, it is our responsibility as individuals, as members of families and as members of government to do something about it.

I am very pleased to note in the initial statement by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, that in these days of the Budget sitting, he has made some mention of homeless youth. He has said, amongst other things, that long term measures for help in this area will be considered in the light of the recent report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare on the problems of homeless youth and in the light of the final evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme. I note also that the Government is moving in these various areas for the training of youth. But there are many aspects of the training of youth and while in the context of some of these reports we are perhaps thinking of apprenticeships and matters such as that, I would suggest that there is another type of training also that has to be brought about, that is, assistance to help young people learn how to live in a family atmosphere which they have missed from their younger days. It is a sad and serious situation and I would hope that we have the support of everyone, not only in government but also in the community, to do something for these young Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Special Broadcasting Service Annual Reports

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Peter Rae:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In tabling the report on 27 May 1982 I briefly outlined it. There were two major problems. One was a failure by statutory authorities to produce reports when required by statute to do so under a mistaken belief, apparently, that they were entitled, when in existence for only part of a year, not to bother reporting for that year and then could put in a combined report for a period in excess of the year, that is, for the period of one year together with the full part of the next year. The second problem was that a Minister who was then the Minister in charge had apparently acquiesced in that approach being adopted. The point that the Committee would most want to make is that it hopes that statutory authorities with a reporting obligation understand that a statutory obligation is a statutory obligation which ought to be complied with. I think that summarises the Committee's report and I have nothing further to add.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Peter Rae:
That the report be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: — Again, I made a statement on behalf of the Committee at the time of tabling the report on 19 May 1982. At this stage, and in view of the indication given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry that the Bill to which it relates would not be proceeded with, I have nothing further to add unless the Bill is proceeded with, at which stage I would wish to participate in the debate on the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity of thanking Senator Peter Rae for his intervention in this matter. The real question at issue was the levying of charges. This was the sum question which the Committee examined-the composition and appropriateness of these charges. The particular matter in question had far-reaching ramifications. The issue which was under examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, Senator Peter Rae's Committee, affected a relatively small group of producers. But the underlying principles had a far wider effect and although the honey producers will, we believe, benefit considerably as a result of his astuteness, his intervention and his and the Committee's actions, it can also have far-reaching implications so far as the levying of charges are concerned on a whole range of authorities throughout Australia. I should like to take this opportunity of congratulating the Committee for examining this matter. I think this is one area where the Senate has demonstrated its power of review and its ability to question certain actions of the Executive in the interests of ordinary producers, be they large or small.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Missen:
That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have so far been no other speakers in the debate. I take it that the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) will probably move the adjournment of the debate accordingly so that it can stand over until the Government has finalised its response to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May on motion by Senator Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — This Bill, the Constitution Alteration ( Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981, is complex, with rather obscure objectives. The apparent objectives conceal the real ones because this Bill, despite its title, is not about fixed term parliaments or about 4-year terms. It really sets out to destroy the Senate with a great degree of subtlety. It also seeks to restrict the reserve powers of the Governor-General. In looking at this Bill we have to go back to the origins of the Australian Labor Party dogma in relation to upper houses, not only the Senate but all the upper houses in Australia. The Labor Party's doctrine, of course, relates to the concentration of power, the infallibility of Caucus and all those central accumulative goals it has to put power in very few hands. It was a dogma of the ALP-until its conference in Adelaide in 1979, for over 60 years-that the Senate be destroyed. Of course there was an example in Queensland in the 1920s where the upper chamber was destroyed.

SPEECH.PARA: A Morgan gallup poll was taken in 1980 which showed that only 22 per cent of the people in Australia wanted the abolition of the Senate; but 78 per cent saw the need for checks and balances on the legislature. They saw the need for a States House, they saw the need for a review chamber; above all, they saw the Senate as a place where the rights of the minorities in this country could be preserved. In an inarticulate way the average person in Australia knows that the Senate is his last buttress, the last bastion against the legislative excesses of a House of Representatives. While he cannot talk about the legalities of the Senate he knows intuitively that the Senate is an important part of his freedom as a citizen. That is why the people of Australia overwhelmingly support the retention of the Senate, with the powers it has at present. That is why this Bill will fail, why it will get nowhere and why it should not get anywhere.

I am rather interested in the way Senator Evans has suddenly changed from a position of absolute aggressive opposition to the existence of the Senate to a degree of deceit and deception in putting up this Bill. For the benefit of the chamber I quote a few statements made by Senator Evans in the past, which I do not doubt he will not want to hear. An article appeared in the Canberra Times of 2 July 1978 headed: 'The way to abolish the Senate or at least muzzle it is to white ant it from within'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a prisoner of my party, Senator, and we changed our policy.
—Yes, it was changed to a policy of deceit and deception in character. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: If one believes as I do along with all good Labor men and women true, that the role of the Senate ought to be abolished or at least deprived of its capacity to destroy properly elected governments there is surely no better forum in which to promote these insidious heresies than the institution itself.

What a hypocritical statement from someone who is prepared to sit here and accept the title of senator, to serve in this chamber, when those are his sincere and genuine beliefs. I again quote what the good senator said:
The Senate has by all accounts always been a silly and pompous institution but now it is obvious to most people that it has become a very dangerous one as well .

I can imagine people thinking it is a silly and pompous place if they have to listen to many of Senator Evans's speeches. With those views-views which I believe accurately reflect the views of the Australian Labor Party-it is no wonder that in my State for over 42 years the Australian Labor Party has never won a Senate election. At least in Queensland people have some common sense and can see through the deception and fraud that the Labor Party puts forward in saying on the one hand that it wants the Senate abolished and on the other hand that it wants people to vote for senators in the Labor Party. Let me go to Senator Evans's maiden speech lest it be thought, as Senator Evans was suggesting a little while ago, that the article in the Canberra Times was a temporary lapse, an aberration, of his suspect cerebral processes. In that maiden speech quite a few anti-Senate statements were made, but one is worth quoting. He said:

If this House does have a useful role to play in the legislative process it does not lie in menacing or threatening a properly elected government with the power of life or death based on some spurious conception of the Senate's position as a defender of States rights or federalism.

That is a clear statement of intent. I am surprised that from a lawyer there should be a statement about the speciousness or spuriousness-I am not sure of my own writing here-of the concept. I would have thought the concept of the Australian Constitution--

TALK.START.PARA: —You could not tell the difference even if you could read your own writing.

—Senator Evans has had enough to say on the subject. Irrespective of whether it is a specious or a spurious concept, I would have thought that even to a layman like myself the intent of the Australian Constitution was quite clear with respect to the powers and the place of the Senate. As recently as 14 August 1980 Senator Evans's revered leader, Mr Hayden, in my State, in Mackay, made the following statement about the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: We are committed to its virtual elimination.
That, in a nutshell, is the position of the Labor Party, with respect to the Senate; that, in a nutshell, is the intent of this Bill-the elimination of the Senate.

I have given enough time to the arguments of Senator Evans. I would like to move away from his dogmatic party lines and look at the matter on the basis of what is best for the State that I represent, looking at the interests of all Queenslanders and looking at the Bill from the point of view of what is best for all Australians. Both individually and collectively the proposals embodied in this Bill diminish the accountability of Parliament to the people by making the positions of the parliamentarians more secure. If we go ahead with this Bill what will come about is the very thing that Senator Evans fears; the people he calls the Huns and the Visigoths of the House of Representatives will indeed carry the day and have supreme power in the national Parliament.

Since Senator Evans is weak on history I think we ought to go back to basics for a moment and look at how the Senate arose and why it has a place in the Australian Constitution. Before the 1901 formation of the Commonwealth of Australia we had a collection of sovereign States. They were all successful States. We have only to go around the capital cities of those States and to see the great and fine buildings that were built before Federation to realise that not only were they commercially successful but also they had a great deal of confidence in their future. Had that not been so, they could never have built the buildings they did. But when they came together they came together not as a central power but as a federation and they came to preserve their individual rights as States. In the latter part of the nineteenth century, as in the latter part of the twentieth century, the great concentrations of power were in the south-east corner, where the overwhelming number of people lived-between Sydney and Melbourne. That created an imbalance because one of the propositions of Federation was that there be a House of Representatives with electorates of equal population. Out of 75 seats in the House of Representatives, that provided 26 for New South Wales, 23 for Victoria, only nine in Queensland, seven for South Australia, five for Western Australia and five for Tasmania, when the representation was based on equivalent electorate sizes. The outlying States said that they were not going to be overwhelmed by the great population densities in Victoria and New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia does not end at Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra.

—That is quite right. If it did we could lock up all the Laborites down there and get on with the business of developing the country. But the balance of power was put in an upper House as a check and balance on the population excesses in the south.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say something about the people who created the Constitution. There seems to be a myth around that the people who put the Constitution together in the 20 years before Federation were woolly-minded academics who knew nothing about politics at all. In fact, nothing could be further from the truth because the people who put the Constitution together were practising politicians and most importantly they were practising politicians from bicameral legislatures, legislatures which had an upper House. They came together to form a Senate which would have equal representation from all the States irrespective of the population. Furthermore, they gave that Senate powers to see that their aims of creating a House with a check and a balance on the excesses of a lower House would be fulfilled. So they gave this upper chamber powers that probably no other upper chamber has. It is quite wrong to compare the Australian Senate with either the American Senate or the House of Lords. The Senate was created for a different purpose. It is most important to remember that the people who created the Australian Senate knew full well what they were doing.
This Bill also deals with the reserve powers of the Governor-General. I would like to quote Mr Justice Evatt in his thesis 'The King and His Dominion Governors'. He says:
Parliament is the parliament for the time being only and it does not necessarily reflect the will of the electorate for all purpose and for all time.
To suggest that the the right of appeal to the Governor-General can be removed makes the government of the day the judge and jury in one fell swoop.

The Bill also deals with the fixed term parliaments, the proposition that the Parliament runs for a set calendar period. Circumstances change and attitudes change. The internal affairs of a country change, and external affairs and international relationships change. Personalities change; people die and are replaced at by-elections. People leave parliament. We are dealing with a dynamic system; we are not dealing with a static system. It is quite reasonable to have some degree of flexibility in our legislative program. There is nothing at all immoral in saying that a parliament can run for a period less than a statutory calendar period. Senator Austin Lewis so eloquently developed the theme that if we have a fixed term parliament it becomes very difficult to control the Executive. In the extreme case we could have an Executive that was quite incompetent, inadequate or even corrupt. One could do nothing about such a situation because the Executive could go on governing until the statutory period was over.

The thing that I find so amazing is the suggestion that there is something immoral in a government going to an election before the end of its term. We compete for the treasury bench, for the position of governing this country. We have our political ideals and our political philosophies and objectives. But we also compete for government and government is the goal that all political parties seek. I find it completely illogical that anyone could suggest that a government that puts its reputation on the line and its hold on the treasury benches on the line by going to the people early is in any sense doing an immoral thing. Such a government is asking for a judgment on its ability to continue governing. I find that the high watermark in a democracy-not in any sense at all something to be deplored or something which is in any sense immoral .

There has been talk about life of Australian parliaments being too short. Australia has grown up since Federation with a statistical average life for a parliament of 2 1/2 years. This has had certain effects on the country but we have coped with it. The suggestion that we would be better served by a longer running parliament has not been proven at all. The proposition that we go to a four-year parliament, which is a different concept from the fixed term parliament, is a rather specious argument. The populist theory that is put forward is that somehow or other we will get a courageous government, that the Budget in the first year of a three-year parliament will do unpleasant things to the electorate, the Budget for the second year will do moderate things and the Budget for the third year will do things that ingratiate the government to the electorate. It is argued that if we have a four-year parliament somehow or other we will get two years of hard labour, one year moderate and one year easy. I do not believe that because the crucial issue here is courage of the parliament itself, and courage is a factor that is independent of time. If we have a government that does not have the backbone to take a long term view of what needs to be done, particularly in relation to the economy, irrespective of how long the term is-whether it is three, four, five or seven years-we will still have a non-courageous government. It is the quality or the character of the people in that government that determines whether the right thing is done for the country, not the period that a government serves.

There are side issues here and one that particularly interests me is defence. Things like defence extend beyond the life of any parliament. Weapons systems and financial support for these systems cannot be measured in terms of a three, four or five-year parliament because one often looks at systems which run for 20 or 30 years. I return to the point about management of the economy and of doing difficult things. I lived in Britain for quite a while and I have also lived in the United States of America. I am not aware that the economic performance of Britain, which has a five-year parliament, has been any better than that of Australia. In fact I think Australia with three-year parliaments over a considerable time-30 to 40 years-has done immeasurably better than the United Kingdom with its five-year plan.

I oppose this Bill in all its intent because it sets out to remove the powers of the Senate completely. I think that Australia will be badly served if this Bill is supported in any way at all. I am quite confident it will not be because I think there are enough people with enough common sense in Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania to ensure that it never sees the light of day. On that point I rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not take quite the categorical view that Senator MacGibbon takes on this matter. I am pleased to see that this Bill has changed a lot over a period. There was a time when I would have agreed very much with Senator MacGibbon and that was when the Bill was in its original truly outrageous form in which it would virtually have rendered the Senate powerless and valueless simply by having this rather curious little system of joint sittings that Senator Evans tried to get away with. I do not know what he thought the rest of us were to put an idea like that in front of us. However, that has gone under the bridge, we hope, for ever. I hope the Australian Labor Party is not contemplating any such ridiculous idea in the future. Of course, that proposal would, among other things, merely have meant that the rather heavy expense of maintaining this House would have been of no value. I think it is very naughty to have suggested that we should impose on the public a charge for something which has no value, a sort of residual monolith-that is what this place would have been.
—It would make the cost of the new Parliament House a lot cheaper if you abolished this place.

—That is a very attractive point of view. But what remains of Senator Evans's Bill is still of great importance because what we are looking at now is the extent to which the Senate should recommend to the people of Australia changes in our powers. It is rather important that we should be here with the hair shirt on recommending our own destruction or in some way the diminution of our own powers. That is not an improper point of view. In many ways, perhaps, it is a respectable one. But I hope to mention a little later that it probably is unwise and not the best way in which things could be done. I suggest that the mere fact that diminution of power of the Senate is recommended by the Senate would influence some people to some extent towards accepting that. They might say: 'These guys do not think they can handle it the way it is now. Maybe we ought to go along with them.' I would have thought that that is not quite the right way of doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, if there is going to be any question of Senate reform I would like to see it come from a constitutional convention, a genuine populist convention. I am sure that Senator Evans will agree, although we have some difference of opinion over that adjective. That populist convention should include all sections of the community. I believe it would be more beneficial even if it originated in the other place or was debated there first before being debated here purely because that would be perceived, rightly or wrongly, justly or otherwise, as a more impartial point of view. I certainly cannot see any great hurry over this matter and there is a good substantial reason for the lack of haste. I personally think I could vote at any time for the concept of fixed term parliaments during the Committee stage of the Bill. I like that idea. I think it has worked well in other countries and I personally can see very few reasons against it. But there are some other matters on which I still have some reservations.

I will vote for the Bill at the second reading stage not because I agree with all areas of it-very far from it-but because it will allow consideration of what is an important subject to go on to the Committee stage. Of course, even more importantly, a constitutional amendment of this kind, as Senator MacGibbon has mentioned, cannot be finalised by us or by the Parliament in toto. It is a constitutional amendment. All we are doing is considering a proposal which would be put to a referendum for the people to decide. It would also, of course, have to pass the House of Representatives. I doubt that would happen, the Government having indicated its opposition. Of course, the Constitution does say that the Governor-General may put the proposal to referendum if one house of parliament has passed it. I think the word 'may' is very significant. I doubt whether that discretion of the Governor-General is anything more than a fiction. In fact, in cases where the word 'may' is used, I think he would need to be advised by the Government unless there were some very strong reprehensible situation-

TALK.START.PARA: —Could he appropriate the funds necessary to conduct the referendum?
—No, I think no.
—And if so, unless the government of the day agreed it is unlikely that the funds would be available. Therefore, it is really a useless provision, is it not?

—Yes, that is an excellent point. The honourable senator has assisted me with that. I had not thought of that. I think the point is important . For that reason alone, I think we can rule that one out. It is certainly Australian Democrats policy to change the emphasis in government so that people are involved more directly. We as a party are dedicated completely to the idea of consultation with the people. Of course that is what we are talking about in this Bill. I think Senator Evans is to be commended very much for the simple fact that he is trying to do something about the Australian Constitution in toto .

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution is a blatant anachronism and needs revision. Indeed, I am one of those people who believe that it needs complete revision. A completely new document would be the best way of proceeding and probably in the long run the most economic way in terms of time and effort, rather than going to the Australian people to change a bit here and a bit there. It would be better to try to get a completely new Constitution and then try that out on the people to see what they wanted and be guided by the decision.

There are those who see a traditional value in the Constitution simply because it does date back to the turn of the century. I must confess that I found very strange the view that the Constitution of generations is regarded as if it were some kind of old building or a piece of antique furniture, which of course it is . That type of sentimentality seems to me very dangerous but one still hears it around the place, surprisingly enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you?

—One does still hear that it is something that we should revere and venerate. I have heard this said by people, not in here, to do all honourable senators justice, but I have heard it said in the community. The fact is that it is the Constitution that sets the basic guidelines for Australian society ought to be as appropriate as possible to conditions and requirements in modern life. A document prepared, for instance, when there were no aeroplanes is not a particularly suitable basis for regulating the aviation industry, and of course there have been difficulties over that. That is only one area which has caused problems. One of the catch-22 provisions of the Constitution relates to the provisions for its own reform.
