I think that is the most important part of the problem. I would like to hear Senator Evans on this at some stage. He can help me on this matter. I think debate on this Bill is fairly academic because if the Bill is to pass the Senate it next has to pass the House of Representatives and then it would have to be put to a referendum of the Australian people in the form of suitable questions that can be answered yes or no. It really worries me how we are going to achieve that. I am not blaming Senator Evans or anybody for that. That just happens to be one of the difficulties of constitutional amendment which do tend to limit people in what they can actually put up in the form of-

—I have done my best to help you out on numerous occasions. It would be put to the people as the question: 'Do you approve the passage of the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill; yes or no?'

—I would suggest to you, Senator, that I have this problem too in respect of the one I put up on the numbers for a referendum on initiative. It is the same problem that the honourable senator has had. I suggest to him that that is not really good enough; it does not give the people the variety of choice that they ought to have in a matter of that kind. You cannot just say that this is democracy and put a general proposition. I felt that strongly in respect of my own Bill. I could say arbitrarily that a quarter of a million people should sign an initiative for a referendum. I would much rather have a situation in which we would have a variety of options and the people themselves could decide what those various elements were. I am sure you would agree with me on that, Senator Evans, although it is in the ideal area. We cannot do it but surely you would agree it is preferable to have a set of options on constitutional reform, and indeed reform of the Senate, being put to the people rather than a single Bill to which they would answer yes or no. That is one of my great worries about how good this consultation would be with all the best motives, because of that one factor alone, that is, how it would be regarded by people who are just being called on to say in respect of a total package: Do I approve of it or do I not approve of it? I do not think that is the way constitutional reform is going to come about.
—The trouble is you cannot run the nation the way you run the Australian Democrats.

—Not yet, but we will. Speaking of the Australian Democrats, as Senator Evans has raised this point, there is no real problem. I think that originally the driving force behind this Bill was the events of 1975. Nobody in the Labor Party or elsewhere has any reason to worry because the Australian Democrats have given solid undertakings that the Senate will not create that situation of bringing down a government as the Whitlam Government was brought down in 1975. It simply will not happen while there is a Democrat balance of power here and I predict that will be for some little time yet to come. Meanwhile I do not think we have to worry about that situation and that motivation being a problem for the time being.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on that point, speaking personally, I see some difference between my saying or the Australian Democrats saying we would never use our vote to block Supply in the Senate, that being the one proposition, and supporting another situation in which the powers of the Senate were restricted in that way for all time. I suggest that is an important distinction for those of us in this place. In the first case we are providing for circumstances we ourselves can assess and control. In the second case we are trying to influence the far distant future in which conditions and events, quite inconceivable to us, may occur. I think that is the strongest possible reason against any restriction on or change in the present powers which after all do not have to be used. They are there to be used if necessary but not otherwise. So for that reason alone I have yet to be convinced of the wisdom of clipping the wings of the Senate.

I agree that it would be good to see a total revision of the Constitution by some means. I think very many people in the Australian community want that but it seems unlikely in any real terms since Bills like this one from Senator Evans arise from a sense of frustration, a desire to improve at least some areas and I think that is part of the problem. Hence I will vote for the second reading so that the Committee stage can proceed. At that stage I think we should more properly look at the detailed matters which Senator Evans has brought forward including his new black typed sections which I will look at with very great interest. My reasons for giving the Bill a second reading at the moment are that I approve of fixed term parliaments and I would not wish to obstruct any reasonable process of consultation with the people. I think it is our responsibility to allow a matter like this if possible to go through to the people. Indeed, it is a matter that they might properly wish to decide on. They are my only reasons for voting for the Bill at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill has been fairly well debated so far or if not well debated at least extensively debated. I do not propose to talk about a number of the things that have already been dealt with at length by other speakers. By way of introduction I want to make the remark which was alluded to by Senator Mason, that is, that in view of the attitude of the Government expressed very clearly this is an exercise which I do not really understand. The present Government has made it quite clear that this Bill, if it passed the Senate, would not be introduced and passed by the House of Representatives.
—Has it?

—I would have thought it was abundantly clear from the speeches that have been made that that is the situation. For the reasons which I am going to come to, whilst it is an interesting exercise, it is a little surprising that Senator Evans sees it necessary to debate this and to bring it forward for further consideration on a number of occasions.
—He is nothing but determined.

—Yes, but for reasons I want to come to. I think there are other ways which are proceeding which would perhaps be more appropriate and more effective particularly in light of the fact that on this Bill, on this subject, the Government has expressed a clear attitude. Whilst it remains the Government in charge of the House of Representatives the discussion is one of academic--

—For you of all people, Senator, to regard this place as a prisoner of the Executive of the House of Representatives! Are you not interested in rational, constructive debate to advance the cause of reason, justice, truth and the Australian way?

—Senator Evans has just taken the next part of my speech and converted it into his own words. Those were the thoughts which I was next coming to, which were then going to lead into the point I wanted to make that these questions are being considered and debated in other places. Reports and results will be produced which, I believe, will enable further debate on the subject. The two bodies to which I wish to refer principally are Standing Committee D of the Constitutional Convention-Senator Evans and I are the Senate's representatives in relation to the issues contained in this Bill-and the Constitution Bicentennial Review Project, which has been established with the assistance of the New South Wales Law Foundation. I believe there has been considerable misunderstanding as to the nature of that project and the nature of its membership. I emphasise that it is called not a reform project but a review project, and that it consists of a wide cross-section of members, some with differing views from within the same party. I think Senator Missen might agree with me on that point. People from the community also are involved. I believe it is an extremely worthwhile exercise in attempting to distil where some of the areas of unsatisfactory operation of the Constitution may exist, where some of the areas which are in need of review exist, and what are some of the arguments and possible alternatives. That is the sort of approach I have to the New South Wales Law Foundation project.
—Senator, would you not agree that that project would not want us all to go dead on reform in the meanwhile?

—Senator Missen asks would the project want us all to go dead on reform in the meantime. I can only say that I imagine that, as is so in relation to a large cross-section of things discussed by the consultative committee for that project, there would be a wide cross-section of views. Some members of that Committee, and I am delighted that this is so, were the most vocal defenders of the Senate position in relation to the proposal for the simultaneous election referendum in 1977. Two people who were the spokesmen for the no case are on that committee. I do not think it is therefore possible to categorise the members of the committee as solely having one type of view or another, and I think that is a highly desirable situation. I will not go through some of the other membership, but I support entirely the existence of that committee, the value of the work which is being done, and the value of the role which it can play in educating the Australian population as to the sorts of questions which arise.

SPEECH.PARA: I come then to the point that whilst there is little use in this Bill being passed by this chamber, even if it were going to be passed, if it is then going to lead to a referendum immediately, for the reasons which I have mentioned. I believe that it is useful to have some debate extending in the various ways, but I am curious that Senator Evans should place debate in the chamber ahead of the report of the Constitutional Convention Standing Committee D, for instance, or even ahead of the initial publication from the New South Wales Law Foundation project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe that is because I give debate in this chamber greater weight than either of those external forums.

—I had rather hoped that the production of those reports would have given a better basis for debate in the chamber. I approach this matter as someone who has a view which is that the Constitution is not a sacred document but is an important document. It is a basic document. It is not a document which either ought to be or can be tinkered with with monotonous regularity. I think that, of necessity, the objective in preparing constitutions is that thereafter as few amendments as possible should be made. However, I do not want to go through the various areas where I think it is demonstrable that consideration needs to be given to some sort of change. One such area is the use of section 96 grants and the financial relationships between the States and the Commonwealth. It may be something that would not lead to a change in the Constitution being recommended, but at least it is something which needs a lot more thought and consideration and discussion. There is a wide variety of other points.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that we need, for instance, to change the provision in relation to double dissolution and the blocking of Supply, but I do not think it should be changed in the way proposed by this Bill. There are very strong arguments, and Senator Evans and I have been involved in them in other places, in relation to what is necessary to ensure that the situation cannot arise where this House can force the government of the day to an election without itself also facing the people in its entirety. It is inexcusable to allow that situation to continue to exist; but how we overcome that problem is another question. I hope that the publication of the report of Standing Committee D, including the dissenting report, will enable debate to be clarified more readily. I hope it will say what I do not have time to say this afternoon. We need to preserve the power of the Senate to force a recall of government by the people acting through, in this case, the House of review-the watchdog-as their agents, but it has to be on that condition, the condition that those people cannot exercise their powers without subjecting themselves at the same time to the judgment of the people who have elected them.

I prepared a document on another occasion when Senator Evans and I were involved in what was a less direct debate on these questions. I refer to a hearing of the Royal Commission into the Constitution Act 1934 in Tasmania, which reported recently. Two of the invited witnesses to that Royal Commission hearing were Senator Evans and me. We gave what might be regarded as the classical different approach cases, although there were many areas of agreement. In order to put my case more quickly and cover a lot of points, I seek the indulgence of the Senate in approaching with some liberality the Standing Order which deals with honourable senators reading speeches. I think that I can make my points quickly if I read the relevant parts of the submission, which is my own composition. Under the heading 'Australia 1982 and Beyond-Democracy with Responsible Government', I stated:

1. I still hold to the perhaps quaint notion that it is possible to enjoy responsible government even in a society as complex as the post-industrial society which is Australia today. I also hold to the quaint notion that the rights of the States as entities should be preserved and that they should enjoy effective workable democratic Parliaments with responsible government.

2. With the growth of the bureacracy, the relative demise of responsible government has been witnessed in Australia. This is not a desirable tendency and is one which needs to be positively resited, other-wise we shall arrive at the situation where the bureaucracy runs the country totally, using the Ministry as the mouthpiece and the Parliament as the imprimatur.

3. I believe democracy as we know it, and as most Australians would wish to enjoy it, is not, and should not be, a paternalistic system, but rather a system of checks and balances. The ultimate power must remain in the hands of the electors. This applies not only to the Australian National Parliament, but to the Parliaments of each of the States.

4. I believe that Queensland, having no Upper House, is an aberration, which does not truly reflect modern desire of the average Australian. The Queensland Parliament lost its Upper House as a result of a number old matters which no longer apply . . . .

Those matters include the fact that it remained anachronistic during the period of major change. It endeavoured to continue to operate upon a basis which was unacceptable to the notions which had been accepted throughout Australia, i.e. of a movement towards the adult franchise, removal of special property rights and qualification, elected rather than nominated membership . . .

I referred to other matters which were so contentious during the latter part of the last century and which have now been removed entirely from the Houses of Parliament of the Australian nation. The bicameral system which has been continued and refined by the Commonwealth and each of the States is a matter upon which there was a great deal of debate at the time of the Constitutional Conventions on the creation of the Constitution. It was the clear preference of the majority of the delegates that there should be a bicameral system. However, that system is not one which ought to remain static. The change that has come about since 1900-it has taken into account some of the matters to which Senator Mason and other speakers have referred-has shown that it is possible within a constitution-within a bicameral system-to embrace change and development.

I point briefly to the complete change which has taken place in the role of the Senate with the development of the committee system. The committee system as such-I emphasise the word 'system' to distinguish it from the ad hoc opportunity which existed previously-has, in the past 10 or 12 years, changed quite dramatically the relationship between Parliament and Executive and Parliament and the people. That is the type of change that can take place, notwithstanding continuation of provisions which previously were not used to provide that sort of opportunity. In many States they are still not used. Therefore, the continuation of the bicameral system gives the opportunity for development and change. It does not have to be destroyed or semi-destroyed for changes in the balance of powers, or whatever the proposal might be to take place.

For reasons to which I will now refer, I do not advocate any loss of powers on the part of the upper House. It is possible to distinguish completely between that and what has been to me one of the totally unacceptable developments in Westminster parliamentary history. I refer to the curtailment of the powers of the House of Lords, as the upper House, rather than change in the nature of its constitution. I think we can say that whilst many people may object to an upper House in which hereditary right is the basis for membership, that argument cannot be applied to a body which does not present that objection. The removal of the property rights forms of privilege, the paternalistic approach, which had been apparent in so many upper Houses in the last century and for part of this century, puts completely out of court the sorts of arguments and emotions generated by many in relation to the Australian Senate. Such arguments should bear in mind the distinction between the situation of the Australian Senate and that of the House of Lords and the Canadian appointed Senate and between our Senate and the sort of situation which was objected to in New South Wales, Tasmania and other States and which resulted in change to the upper Houses there . I repeat, those arguments and concerns cannot appropriately be applied to the Australian Senate.

I refer to our system as being not paternalistic but rather one of delegation, with checks and balances. The importance of that is that the checks and balances are provided by an upper House acting as a House of review. If we do not have the sort of paternalistic system which used to exist as the basis of a balanced democracy, as people used to call it-a term about which there is considerable confusion-we must have a system of checks and balances and a very independent and powerful House of review to provide them. If we neuter the second House, the House of review, we destroy the capacity for providing checks and balances. I believe that as long as the House of review is directly responsible to the people we will be able to have the best of both worlds.

In summary, I believe that to be effective a House of review needs the power to give to electors the opportunity of making the ultimate decision. It must have the power, in the ultimate, to call the executive government to account. As we have witnessed recently, giving the people the right to make a decision by way of referendum is not always an adequate means of solving a problem. I am referring to the Tasmanian constitutional deadlock between the two Houses over a referendum which did not give the people the opportunity to vote on the question that was most concerned with the argument taking place within the community. Any provision for disputes between Houses to be resolved by referendum is still limited by the fact that the government of the day can rig the referendum questions and thereby distort the result without managing to solve the differences which existed between the Houses. The nature of the question does not necessarily reflect the issues which the people and possibly the parties or individual members or would-be members of parliament, would wish to have made the subject matter for decision. A far more effective means is to have the deadlock broken by a mechanism whereby the decision as to who shall be in government and who shall be in parliament is resubmitted to the people. By this means the people make choices according to their own view of how those individual delegates will carry out their function as delegates of the people. In order to ensure that there is an adequate review of the operation of government with the ultimate determination in the hands of the people, it is necessary to have a House of review which can, in an extreme situation, force a government to the people on the basis that it too is accountable to them and up for judgment at the same time.
I also think that a consideration of money Bills is relevant. In my submission to the Royal Commission into the Constitution Act 1934, I said.

A particular point which is, I believe, often overlooked in relation to the debate on the powers of an Upper House in relation to money Bills, is that the original concept of the rights of the Lower House with regard to taxation and the determination of expenditure, derived from the position where there was an objection to the powers of the non-elected Upper House against the powers of the popularly elected Lower House.
That argument no longer prevails.
The argument now must be related to the efficiency of government and accountability in government.

The principal reasons for ensuring that the powers to impose taxation and to decide upon expenditure remain with the Lower House are nothing to do with its popular election, but rather are to do with the fact that elections for the Lower House are intended to be taken upon the basis of the people selecting the policy and program of a party which will be in a majority in that House and will thereupon proceed to form a government and implement policies of taxation and expenditure which it has outlined in its manifesto and for which it has an electoral mandate.
In my submission that situation should remain unchanged.

The questions now relating to money Bills and the powers of the two Houses should relate to effective and workable government; what is a proper role for the house of government and what is a proper role for the house of review in a fully elected bicameral Parliament?

The provision that the house of review should not have the right to initiate money Bills (other than appropriations with regard to the operation of the Parliament, and in particular of its own House) are sustainable. I don't stay to debate the question of whether there should be any power to initiate money Bills but rather to stress that there should not be cause for the initiation of money Bills in the house of review. It is not a particularly important power to retain for an effective Upper House.
However, the power to reject money Bills or to request amendments is of fundamental importance for the reasons which have been outlined . . .

In other words, the House of review cannot carry out adequately the role for which it exists, namely that of review, scrutiny and the provision of checks and balance, unless it has the power to reject and the power to request amendment. My submission continues:

There must exist both the capacity to enforce the scrutiny and accountability of the executive and also the power to make requests for the re-consideration of the proposed expenditure of public funds. It is for at least those two reasons that the full power to reject or request amendment should be retained.

I would like to go on to talk about a number of other matters but, as I have mentioned, many of them have been covered. I adopt the views which have been expressed by Senator Lewis in relation to fixed term parliaments. I commend the views which are expressed in a paper which will be published by Standing Committee D in relation to the problem of the definition of 'ordinary annual services' and the absolutely essential nature of any amendment to the provisions for changing the position with regard to supply to include the consitutional definition of 'ordinary annual services'. Otherwise so much of what is proposed by Senator Evans would become vague and subject to so much possibility for abuse that his amendments would be of little effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there are relevant parts of the Bill, surely, on fixed terms ?

—I am trying to talk about just some of the matters very briefly. I wanted to refer to some of the other places where views which I would have liked to have had time to express now are set out. I do not propose to hold up the Senate today. I think we will be coming back to the debate on these issues-at least I hope we will be-after the report of Standing Committee D of the Constitutional Convention is prepared and after the New South Wales Law Foundation constitution review project book has been published early next year. At that time I will seek an extension of the time I have not used this afternoon because I believe that at that time the debate will be more fruitful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the Senate Hansard of 18 March 1982, page 1005, which records Senator Evans having said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will grant Senator Lewis leave to speak again at a later time.
I seek leave to speak again at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—My charity is becoming exhausted, Mr Deputy President, but there is no question of our going back on our word; leave is granted.
—There being no objection, leave is granted.

—I thank the Senate and I thank Senator Evans. I had no doubt that he would not go back on his word. I appreciate the opportunity to speak again. Since I last spoke on this subject Senator Hamer has criticised the case which I made against the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill. This gives me an opportunity to respond to Senator Hamer's criticism. In my view his criticism is based on some errors of fact and some confusion about the Bill and what I had to say about it. There are errors and confusion right throughout his speech, but I intend to refer only to what I think are the most significant.

SPEECH.PARA: The first sentence on the substance of the Bill in his speech contains a misconception. He said that the Bill deals principally with two quite separate issues-fixed terms and the Senate's power over money Bills. In fact, the provisions dealing with the Senate's powers are not confined to questions of supply but potentially cover all types of legislation. In my paper on the Bill which I incorporated at page 1000 of the Senate Hansard of 18 March 1982 it can be seen that I identified some six major changes to the Constitution. In my book , Senator Hamer has not addressed himself to some of the very important aspects of the Bill such as, for example, the provisions dealing with the Governor- General's powers, in which provisions I have pointed out some radical defects. Senator Hamer then said:

I am very surprised that the biggest advantage-that it solves the problems of holding simultaneous elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives- has not yet been mentioned in this debate.
Again that is not true because I dealt with simultaneous elections in my paper, which was incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did, too.

—Senator Missen points out that he dealt with the matter. So, again, Senator Hamer is not telling the Senate what is the true situation. In any case, it is not true that the provision for fixed terms solves the simultaneous election problem. Fixed terms as such would have no effect on simultaneous elections in the absence of further changes to the Constitution. The Bill brings about simultaneous elections by altering the terms of senators. Senator Hamer seems to favour Senator Evans's second proposal, which I think he has put as an amendment; namely, to have a House of Representatives elected after an extraordinary election continue only to the end of the term of the previous House. In fact, neither of these proposals has any necessary connection with fixed terms for the House of Representatives, as Senator Hamer seems to imagine.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer scoffed at my quoting Walter Bagehot on the grounds that Bagehot wrote a long time ago. He later asserted that Bagehot wrote in 1850. In fact, he did not write in 1850. He did write a long time ago but I suggest that longevity does not invalidate the things that Walter Bagehot said about the Constitution. I suggest to the Senate that a person of Senator Hamer's age should be very careful about falling for the cult of modernity and youth in relation to who he quotes. The publishers of Bagehot's book keep publishing it because it is so popular. The people who write an introduction to it, such as Mr Norman St John Stevas, refer to it as being continually relevant to today. Just three days before our recent Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen, finished his term I heard him refer to the book. I made a note of his words; he was on a talkback program on the radio-a very modern thing for a Governor-General to do. He referred to Bagehot's book and said: 'It has a peculiar modernity and relevance to today'. Yet Senator Hamer scoffed at me, referring to the quote without bothering to deal with what I was talking about.

I go a step further. Incredibly enough, we find a book recently published called The Constitutional Challenge: Essays on the Australian Constitution. In it there is an essay by Senator Hamer. He talks about 'towards a valuable Senate ' and, guess what, who does he quote but Walter Bagehot. Yet the honourable senator scoffed at me for quoting Bagehot. It is unbelievable. I used the quotation to demonstrate that the ability of the Government to appeal to the electorate is a means-Bagehot points this out-of ensuring responsibility on the part of the House of Representatives. A right of the Government to appeal to the people should not lightly be removed.

Senator Hamer points out that under the present constitutional arrangements it is possible for the Government to be changed without an election. I suggest to the Senate that this does not invalidate the point which I made, contrary to what Senator Hamer appears to believe. The point is that a government overthrown or in danger because of developments in the House of Representatives has the right to go to an election if it chooses to do so. I refer to the events of 1975 . There is no doubt that Mr Whitlam, as the Prime Minister in 1975 when Supply was being blocked in this place, had a right to go to the people. He chose not to exercise that right, but he had the right to go to the people. No one would have questioned him had he done so. Subsequently he was replaced by Mr Fraser and, notwithstanding the fact that the House of Representatives passed a vote of no confidence in Mr Fraser as the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser took the issue to the people.

A vital point for the House of Representatives is that a government in that House should always be able to take the question to the people of Australia and let them decide. Senator Hamer did not bother to apply his mind to that quotation and the purpose of what I was talking about. On one occasion, in 1925, a Governor-General in Canada, Lord Byng, was severely criticised and held to have acted contrary to constitutional usage. That was because he refused a dissolution on the ground that, as he was saying, an alternative government could be formed. I suggest to Senator Hamer that before he makes dogmatic statements about these sorts of matters he has a good look at the constitutional history of federations.
I made certain statements about Watergate, and I do not resile from any of those statements notwithstanding the fact that Senator Hamer says:
Almost every statement there is false.

Senator Hamer said that because I had mentioned that it was four and a half years before the people of the United States got an opportunity to throw out the Republican Administration. Senator Hamer scoffed at this and said that it was false because there was an election within six months of Watergate. Of course there was. Did he think I did not know that? But the point was that the people of the United States did not understand what Watergate was all about when that election took place. I suggest that far from my being false, Senator Hamer was dissembling when he made that statement to the Senate that there was an election within six months of Watergate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit rough.

—Of course it is. I have been told by my colleague from Victoria that every statement that I made in that speech in relation to Watergate was false. I do not resile from what I said. I say sincerely that my statements were not false. Senator Hamer went on to say that President Nixon was forced to resign-indicating to him an exercise in power on the part of the United States people and Congress. In my view Senator Hamer has completely misunderstood both the events in the United States at that time and the point I was making. As I stated, it was not until the next presidential election four and a half years later that the people had the opportunity of expressing a verdict on Watergate by removing the Republicans from the White House. The fact that President Nixon resigned in the middle of his term merely reinforces what I said. The effect of that resignation was simply to install in the presidency President Nixon's nominated Republican successor.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the American constitutional situation is different from ours, but the facts to which I referred illustrate the drawbacks of fixed terms. It was President Woodrow Wilson who said that one of the great disabilities of the American Constitution was the fixed term concept. At a time when Senator Evans is proposing to the people of Australia that Australia should look at fixed term concepts, the political experts of the United States, as a result of Watergate, are looking at the reverse and saying: 'Look at the advantages provided in the United Kingdom and in Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which experts? Produce a couple. Don't just wave your hands around, man. Produce an expert.

—Senator Evans asks me to produce an expert. I did not realise that he would ask that question during this debate, but he knows that there is an expert because I had the fellow's book at the seminar on fixed term parliaments, which Senator Evans and I debated. I shall obtain the book and provide it to Senator Evans after this debate.
—We shall give you leave to speak again.

—Senator Hamer seems to accept that fixed terms for the House of Representatives necessarily involves fixed election dates. I pointed out in my paper that it is possible to have fixed terms with flexibility of election dates . That is why I discussed fixed election dates as a separate proposition. It is true that Australia seems to have been, fortunately, free of internal troubles and external threats, but we cannot presume that this will continue. I have not yet heard one supporter of the fixed term proposal give me any reason why we must also have fixed election dates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer scoffs at the possibility of a minority faction in the House of Representatives keeping a paralysed government in office and believes that this is 'so unlikely that it is scarcely worth providing for'. But Senator Hamer does not bother to apply his mind to the fact that in recent history the Scullin Government in 1931 found itself precisely in that position-being kept in office as a minority government. We all know that there was the party split in the Australian Labor Party and the emergence of the Democratic Labor Party. The ALP was not in office at the time, but it could have been so. Some of us are suspicious that in the middle of 1975 there could very easily have been a split in the ALP and that the government of the day could have been kept in office. But we are not privy yet to Caucus secrets to ascertain whether that might have been so. However, I suggest that it is very brave people of Australia who believe that there would not be a party split at some stage in the future, in any of the political parties existing in Australia. Senator Hamer's remedy for party splits is a beauty, too. He says:
. . . the Government could declare any Bill a vote of confidence.

If that means what it appears to mean, it is patently absurd, because that would destroy what is alleged to be the major advantage of fixed terms-the removal of the threat of dissolution which Prime Ministers are alleged to use to cower the House of Representatives into supporting every government proposal. I referred to that matter at the beginning of my paper on the subject. Senator Hamer asserts:
It must not be thought that elections following government loss of control of the House are likely to be frequent. This happened only once in our 82 years history-in 1929.

That is not correct. Again I refer to the example of the Scullin Government, which was forced to an election in November 1931 by loss of control over the House of Representatives. Finally, Senator Hamer said that I was 'on very shaky ground indeed'. I have said enough to indicate that it is Senator Hamer who is on very shaky ground, rather than those of us who oppose the Bill.
I turn briefly to the Australian Labor Party. As part of its platform, the ALP proposes-and this I believe to be a quotation-
. . . to ensure that the Senate has no power to reject defer or otherwise block money Bills; to provide that the Senate may delay for up to six months but not reject any other proposed law.

Senator Evans has made it clear in public debate and in this place that he is promoting this Bill as part of his party's long term proposals which I have just quoted. I seek leave at this stage to incorporate in Hansard a paper by Dr Neal Blewett, a former professor of politics at Flinders University and now Federal ALP member for the seat of Bonython. This paper was published in Labor Forum, Volume 1, No. 1, in the autumn of 1978.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Dunstan shows the way in constitution reform

The constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia was designed by a group of mostly conservative, colonial politicians. However radical the concept of a new nation, the institutions of that new nation were intended to serve conservative interests, secure conservative ends, and support a conservative society. And the judges of the High Court have gone even further-the most extravagant of their interpretations enshrining so-called 'private enterprise' as a constitutional principle. Thus socialists have been expected to give loyalty to a constitution which proscribes their ideology.

It is therefore not surprising that every reforming Federal government in Australian history, let alone every Labor Government has been entrammelled and frustrated by the constitution. To the detriment of the nation and at enormous cost in time, energy and money reforming ministers have sought to evade, circumvent and change the crippling net cast by the founding fathers. One of the most promising features of the Whitlam Government was the ingenuity it displayed in circumventing the artificial constrictions of the constitution. Great gaps may yet open in the rigidities of the constitution as the tortuous logic of defensive constitutional lawyers is turned against them by their radical fellows . Nevertheless the weakness of this approach is that it further emphasises the legalism of the Australian policy, a legalism that has served to undermine the responsibility between governors governed, that has helped to alienate Australians from their political institutions.

On the other hand efforts at popular change have been almost uniformly unsuccessful. Of the 36 amendment proposals put to the Australian people in 77 years only eight have been successful. And we have now reached the nadir of absurdity where an overwhelming affirmative vote of the Australian people for simultaneous elections has been frustrated by narrow majorities in Queensland and Western Australia and by the constitutional paranoia of the Tasmanians. Respect for the states may be a necessary feature of our constitution; denial of so overwhelming a popular verdict merely ridicules our democratic pretensions.
The South Australian Experience

Nevertheless, lessons for national constitutional change may be drawn from the South Australian experience of the past decade. Environmentally South Australia seems little different from the rest of Australia. Whatever fashionable pundits may say the polls suggest that South Australians are neither more nor less conformist than other Australians, neither more nor less radical than other Australians, neither more nor less politically adventurous than other Australians. Yet South Australia has, in the past decade witnessed a constitutional transformation unparalled in modern Australian history. Admittedly the task of tackling a state constitution is a more limited and less cumbersome exercise than tackling the national constitution. But even if the scale of the enterprise is more daunting, those who would embark on national constitutional reform can learn much from the South Australian transformation of the past ten years.

In 1967 South Australia possessed a bicameral parliamentary system structured to serve the conservative cause. A gross malapportionment of seats-the notorious Playmander-had enabled the Liberal Country League to dominate the House of Assembly, despite infrequent popular majorities, for all but two years of the preceding generation. The Upper House, the Legislative Council, was an even more solid conservative bastion, a Labor majority never having been glimpsed there. The restricted franchise, the rural bias of the Council districts, and the voluntary enrolment and voting had ensured that Labor representation had never been more than a negligible minority.

In 1967 the House of Assembly consisted of 39 seats: 13, or one-third, from metropolitan constituencies; 26, or two-thirds from non-metropolitan, mainly rural constituencies. These proportions almost exactly reversed the population distribution in South Australia, with approximately two-thirds of the population living in greater Adelaide, one-third outside. On average, metropolitan seats contained three times as many voters as non-metropolitan seats. In the crucial election of 1968, the ALP, with 52.0% of the vote, won nineteen seats; the LCL, with 43.8% of the vote, won an equal number of seats and was restored to power on the vote of the single independent. Such was the democracy endorsed by the conservative constitution of South Australia.

Moreover, the timing of redistributions was dependent on the whims of the politicians and, more accurately, for most of the time on the whim of a single politician, Sir Thomas Playford. And any such redistribution was totally subject to the self-interested scrutiny of the politicians.

In a single decade this perversion of democracy has been swept away. The present House of Assembly consists of 47 members, 33 from the metropolis and 14 from the non-metropolitan areas. This reflects accurately the population distribution in the State, and has led to the creation of virtually equal electorates. Moreover, redistributions are ensured at least every six years should the seats depart from equality; the decision on which is made by a permanent commission not by the government. The redistribution proposals themselves are not open to political finagling, but may be challenged by ordinary citizens. (This provision was grossly abused during 1977 by ostensibly independent citizens acting as defacto agents of the Liberal Party in an effort to delay the implementation of the new distribution. Competition in hypocrisy was keen; between 'independent' citizens protesting the new dispensation after having tolerated the Playmander without a murmer for years; and the Liberal hierarchy with its Pilate-like stance on the appeals).

In 1967, a mere ten years ago, less than half the adult population of South Australia was on the Legislative Council roll. The boundaries of the five four- member Council districts were so drawn that the effective Labor vote was bottled up in a single district, Central No. 1. In 1967 the Council consisted of 16 Liberals and 4 Labor, a division which had survived with only marginal modifications for fifty years. A body so entrenched could savage Labor legislation with little fear of the consequences. Between 1965 and 1968 the Council rejected or laid aside eleven bills, including some of the major measures of the Walsh-Dunstan Ministries, and successfully inserted major partisan amendments to at least twelve other bills. Such mutilation of Labor measures was simply a continuation of the traditions of half a century.

Today, in 1977, all this has changed. The constitutionally preserved bastion has gone. There is now full adult franchise for the Legislative Council, voters participating in Council elections having doubled between 1973 and 1975. There is now a single state-wide electorate for the Council, thus preventing gerrymandered boundaries. A list system of proportional representation now operates, guaranteeing representation to any group which can secure some 8% of the vote. The composition of the Council is now Liberals 11; ALP 10; and it is likely that in the 1980s Labor will have a Council majority for the first time in South Australian history. The Council now treats the legislation of the Labor regime with much greater discretion, recognizing that any false step might well bring its fragile majority to a premature end.

Thus these ten years represent the most sweeping constitutional and institutional transformation in South Australian history, possibly in modern Australian history. What lessons are there here for Australian reformers?
Goals for Reformers

First, Federal Labor needs to advance a clear and attractive statement of the major goals of constitutional reform. This statement should be sufficiently clear and attractive to mobilise widespread support, yet not so detailed as to prevent tactical flexibility in the pursuit of these goals.

South Australian Labor had a simple and compelling constitutional goal; the creation of an institutional system fair as between the major parties. This goal appealed to a distinctive trait in the Australian political culture-the ideal of fair play summed up in the phrase 'fair go mate'. Thus the goal aided the mobilisation of the non-political, while at the same time it destroyed the unity of non-Labor, for the ideal of fair play seduced the progressive elements in the Liberal party. Yet the goal was sufficient to permit tactical flexibility, as in the dramatic introduction of a list of system of proportional representations for council elections.
A much more complex set of issues face Labor when contemplating reform of the antiquated national constitution. Let me state without detailed argument a set of major goals-
1. A modern constitution in that the autocratic pretentions embodied in the powers of the Governor-General will be eliminated.
2. A democratic constitution in that the methods of election for the governing institutions will be direct and equal.
3. A popular constitution in that the popular and representative house shall have unchallenged authority over the executive.
4. A unitary constitution in that indisputable legal authority will be vested in a popularly elected national legislature.

Only one of these major goals is likely to arouse real controversy as distinct from partisan opposition-the issue of the unitary state versus federalism. I merely outline here the overwhelming case against the maintenance of the present federal system. Elected national majorities and the pursuit of the national interest are constantly frustrated by the diffusion of power under a federal system. Witness for example, the way in which the anti-Australians, Court and Bjelke-Petersen, have frustrated national majorities of whatever political hue. This frustration is wasteful, and its negativism is essentially supportive of established vested interests. Federalism is excessively legalistic, with the result that judges, not elected majorities, are decisive. And this legalism permits those with economic resources as, for instance, the wealthy multi- national companies, to exploit the legal loopholes and unsupervised gaps in the system. Moreover Federalism inhibits national economic planning. Australia's tardy recovery from the economic recession has little to do with the unions, much to do with the fact that federalism has deprived Australia of the central economic weapons possessed by nearly every advanced industrial society. And the problems ahead will merely highlight the inadequacies of Australian federalism. As Hugh Stretton writes in
Capitalism, Socialism and the Environment

To distribute environmental costs and benefits with deliberate justice and to restrain inflation by any but the most reactionary means, quite complicated long term policies have to be carried out under coherent central direction with co- ordinated action by executive, legislative and local arms of government. Such coherent action is just not possible under Australian federalism.
Clear and Attractive Goals

The basic constitutional goals need to be stated in lucid and attractive language. Labor needs to maximise the use of the 'hurrah' words in our political vocabulary in order to mobilise community support and to split its conservative opponents. A democratic egalitarian appeal must underwrite Labor opposition to Governors-General, judges, gerrymandered electoral systems, and an unrepresentative Senate. The appeal to Australian nationalism must offset the conservative preference for State parochialism. Labor must stress the commitment to the Australian nation against the lesser loyalties to Western Australia or Tasmania. Labor must corral the symbols of Australian nationalism, because there will be critical elements in what is in many ways a cultural battle.

Labor needs to advocate protective measures particularly for the fainthearted and timid who see federalism as a guarantee of participation and liberty. For this reason, if for no other, it is necessary to include in the package a bill of rights as a guarantee for all those who fear the sweep of Australian democracy or the claims of Australian nationalism.
Federal Labor needs, too, an imaginative and elaborate plan for regional government which, while not encumbered with nonsense about local sovereignty, will assure decentralisation.
Again, as in South Australia, the ALP should avoid spelling out the goals in minute detail, so that the party leaders can seize the opportunities of the moment to advance the basic strategy.

These proposals are long-range, but not utopian. Unless the major goals are stated and popularised, unless a basic strategy is adopted, Federal Labor will go on making, for the next twenty five years, all the tactical errors of the past quarter century.

Despite advances made at the Perth Conference, the present Federal Platform fails to spell out clear constitutional goals in language designed to rally popular support. No coherent strategy is set down; rather there is a mixture of long range ambitions and short-order projects; a melange of strategic goals and minor details. Nor is there much sense of priorities. Moreover, the constitutional policy is embodied in language which only occasionally rises above the banal.
Constant Repetition

The second prescription is that once the goals are established they demand constant reiteration. In South Australia, Labor publicity and Labor speakers pressed relentlessly and tirelessly the constitutional themes. In every parliamentary session in the late 1960's Labor introduced a one vote one value bill into the Assembly; in every session in the early 1970's Labor introduced a measure to provide adult franchise in the Council. These ritualistic exercises were not designed to change votes inside parliament, but to mobilise popular support outside.

By contrast the referendums of the Whitlam period were handed to a populace unprepared and unmobilized. The sudden prices and income referendums were an unplanned, almost accidental response to economic difficulties, presented as a kind of afterthought. The clutter of referendums at the double dissolution of 1974 were offered at relatively short notice, went unargued by most Labor politicians, and were unavoidably lost in the issues of the first double dissolution struggle.
Unity and Change

The third prescription is that constitutional reform is impossible without unity. There were undoubtedly party differences in South Australia, particularly over tactics, above all over the best reform plan for the Legislative Council. But the differences never became public. They were resolved in the party room. Party members were prepared to compromise, to abandon pet projects, for they knew that any public breech would imperil constitutional reform.

The reverse has too often been true at the national level. State Labor parties have played a state's rights card to ruin national Labor referendums. And in 1973, political and industrial Labor were split on the prices and incomes referendum. Such divisions are a guarantee of failure.
Seizing any Opportunity

Fourthly, Federal Labor must seize any opportunity that will serve the long term goal, even if there are short term political gains to the enemy as a result . In South Australia in 1969 the Liberal government of Steele Hall proposed a major reform of the Playmander, a new redistribution which while it would not right, would at least partially correct, the imbalance between metropolitan and rural representation. It was not an ideal plan; and would bring kudos and credit to the Liberal Steele Hall. But it was a major step towards Labor's strategic goals; and Labor supported it despite short-term benefits for the Liberals. It was a wise decision. All of Labor's future gains were founded on Steele Hall's reforms.

Thus Federal Labor should judge every initiative on constitutional reform in relation to Labor's long term goals. Any proposals which contribute to Labor's strategy should be accepted, however soiled their initiators, and however much Labor's opponents may gain in the short-term.
Dramatising the Issues

Fifthly it is necessary to dramatise and personalise constitutional issues, which too often leave the elector bored, apathetic and negative. The great mass rallies in South Australia in early 1968 compelled even the Liberals to constitutional reform. Dunstan's public histrionics during the crisis with the Legislative Council in June 1973 invested the rather dreary debates in the legislature with the drama of high conflict, thus turning a parliamentary occasion into public theatre.

Federal Labor needs to think seriously about dramatizing constitutional issues. Sir John Kerr has already made a spectacular contribution: the progress from Yarralumla to Parisian exile, a shambolic shuffle from high tragedy to low farce .
A Symbolic Event-Remembrance Day 1975

Kerr brings us to the sixth prescription-the need for an event as a symbolic focus for the constitutional struggle. In South Australia this was provided by the election of March 1968, in which Labor with a clear popular mandate was yet ejected from office. The election became the symbol of the denial of democracy to South Australians. Dunstan did not present the election result as a case of ' we wuz robbed', but simply as an affront to the democratic values of all South Australians.

The constitutional perversion of November 1975 is on the way to becoming the symbolic event on which the national constitutional struggle can focus. Remembrance Day 1975 serves superbly to bring home to a wider range of Australians than ever before the absurdities of the Australian constitution. It highlights the worst features of the constitution-its formal absurdities, its autocratic pretensions, its gutted democracy, its conservative bias.

The events serve too to endanger the whole conservative order. When next the conservatives prate of law and order, remind them of their law and order in late 1975; when next they prate of constitutional propriety, remind them of their constitutional impropriety in late 1975.

As Dunstan used March 1968 as the focus for constitutional change in South Australia, so let Federal Labor use Remembrance Day 1975 as the symbolic focus for mobilising Australians for constitutional change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I refer briefly to some aspects of this paper . Dr Blewett says at the beginning:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . every Labor Government has been entrammelled and frustrated by the constitution . . . One of the most promising features of the Whitlam Government was the ingenuity it displayed in circumventing the artificial constrictions of the constitution. Great gaps may yet open in the rigidities of the constitution as the tortuous logic of defensive constitutional lawyers is turned against them by their radical fellows.

I draw the attention of the people of Australia to that statement, which was a clear exposition back in 1978 by Dr Blewett of the ALP as to what he is proposing if the ALP ever gets into office. By tortuous logic the ALP would turn the constitution wide open to enable it to institute its changes and its platform. It is clear that Senator Evans has these ideas in his mind because he has made reference to what he could do with the constitutional power in relation to bilateral agreements in foreign affairs.

Let me turn to other aspects of this paper. Dr Blewett made it clear that 'one of the long term goals of the Australian Labor Party would be a unitary constitution in that indisputable legal authority will be vested in a popularly elected national legislature'. I hope that people understand what that means. He is saying that the ALP wants to vest all control in this Parliament in Canberra. In effect, the State governments will wither away in the old Marxist principle. We know that the Labor Party wanted to introduce regional arrangements because it tried it in 1973 or 1974 during its term of office. It wanted to set up regional arrangements financed from Canberra in place of the States. I ask the people of Australia to think about the ultimate result of that. Do they really think that Western Australia would remain a part of Federal Australia if the whole of the power was concentrated in Canberra? Honourable senators heard Senator MacGibbon this afternoon. Do they think that the people of Queensland would put up with being controlled from Sydney and Melbourne? The ALP fails to think through its policies. It is a question of applying our minds to the ultimate result of these proposals. They sound all right to airy fairy professors of philosophy-I am sorry, Dr Blewett is a professor of politics-but when one applies one's mind to the practical results of these things one sees their deficiencies. I do not understand why members of the ALP do not stand up and say to these academics: 'Go home and let us run the country in the way it ought to be run, that is, as a federation. Do not give us all this political nonsense and garbage'.
Let me turn to what Dr Blewett went on to say about how to effect constitutional reform. That is very easy. This paper was published in 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak only very briefly. I will not canvass the merits or otherwise of the issues of the debate. However, since I understand that we will have a division on the question that the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981 be read a second time, I indicate that I will vote to give the Bill a second reading. I wish to indicate very briefly my reasons for voting for the second reading. I support the concept of fixed term parliaments. I am not happy with some aspects of Senator Evans's Bill . I could not support the restrictions proposed in relation to the Senate. I am unsure as to the full ramifications of some sections which relate to the Governor-General.
