SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- I thank the Senate for what has been for the most part, with certain conspicuous exceptions, including the exception which is now leaving the chamber, a thoughtful and constructive debate. It has been an important debate and will go on being an important debate when we resume -as I hope we will-at the Committee stage next week, not only because of the timeless constitutional problems with which it deals but also because of its immediate relevance in the present political context. It is a political situation in which there is evident a mass of destabilising speculation as to yet another early election in this country; yet another election occurring two years or less after its predecessor; yet another election creating instability and uncertainty in businessmen, public servants, and everyone else charged with the task of managing this country and living effectively in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Many detailed points have been made in the course of the debate. I do not intend in this reply to endeavour to answer them all. I think it is best to debate questions of detail in the Committee stage, as I hope we will next week. For now, in reply I simply want to summarise where I think we are at in this debate, summarise what the Bill is trying to achieve, indicate what I perceive to be the major objections to it in both its unqualified and qualified form, and indicate the general nature of the answers I would make to those objections.

I remind the Senate that the Bill was introduced into this place on 11 November 1981. I also remind the Senate that on 18 March I foreshadowed a number of amendments to the original Bill, which amendments have not yet been formally moved or tabled in this place. Those amendments were circulated to honourable senators on 6 May, and it is to the Bill as proposed to be amended in that way that I now speak. For the convenience of honourable senators, yesterday I had circulated to everyone outside this chamber a memorandum, kindly prepared by the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel, showing how the Constitution would look with the consolidation of the original Bill and the proposed amendments constituting changes to it. I believe that that particular memorandum will considerably ease what might otherwise be a rather complicated process in the Committee stage of this debate.

In dealing with the arguments about the Bill I think perhaps the best way to proceed is to start by summarising the basic fixed term concept and explaining the two major and quite distinct justifications for it. I shall then go on, after that basic treatment, to indicate the major objections to that basic concept and show how the Bill, as it is proposed to be amended, meets those objections to that basic concept and what the relevant answer to the objections is. The basic concept can be stated very simply in a sentence. It is to provide that elections for the House of Representatives be held on a fixed constitutionally determined date, and not, as is the case at the moment, at the whim, essentially, of the Prime Minister of the day.

The two basic rationales for this idea are as follows, and they are distinct and separate. The first of them is to introduce stability and predictability into the electoral cycle, to meet the situation that has prevailed since Federation and which has been particularly the case since the last war, when the average term of the Parliament, as I understand it, has been two years and four months only; to correct the situation where there is acute uncertainty, often beginning very early in the life of a Parliament as to how long that Parliament will last, uncertainty which does create problems for rational planning in both public and private sectors. It is a much more stable and sane environment, particularly in the context of times of economic uncertainty, for Governments to come and go according to a pre-determined cycle, rather than coming and going according to the whims and opportunism of the political masters of the day.

As I understand it, there has been very little dissent around the chamber to that basic proposition that, other things being equal, it would be desirable for us to have that extra degree of stability and certainty in our election cycle. The objections have been rather as to whether the disabilities, as they are claimed to be, with that concept outweigh that advantage. But the fact that it is an advantage or would be an advantage to have that stability and certainty does not seem to have been seriously contested.

The second basic rationale, and the one which in many ways has been much more controversial, is the argument that a fixed term concept would produce a solution to the problem, and many of us in this country would argue that it is a problem, involved in the instability of our whole democratic system flowing from the existence and the potential use of the Senate's power to force a government to the polls by blocking Supply in a situation where that government retains its majority in the lower House-in other words, the problem of 1975, and of 1974, for that matter; the problem which continues to exercise the minds of political commentators and political practitioners of all parties. The fixed term concept is essentially an indirect solution to that problem. It does not involve the direct head on attack on the notion of the Senate having those powers, which some perhaps more directly or adventurously minded constitutional reformers have argued as the preferred approach. It is an indirect solution to the extent that it is simply a consequence of reforms, that is, the introduction of the fixed term system, which are valuable for their own sake and for other reasons, namely , the reasons of ensuring a greater predictability and stability in the electoral cycle.

The argument is that, as such, since it is an indirect solution and not one that involves anybody in particular having to choke on words they may have uttered in political times past, it is a more potentially politically palatable solution for certain parties and individuals in the political process than would be other more direct solutions to that problem. That political judgment may prove to be quite unfounded. I acknowledge, as Senator Peter Rae says, that the initial response of the Government to the suggestion that the fixed term parliament offered a useful way through the problem of Senate power has not been an encouraging one. I remain forever optimistic, however, that the process of rational debate in this place and outside it will in fact over time encourage a change of view. I certainly think it is worth while for the Senate, being the institution, after all, most immediately affected by any such proposed change, to express its view upon it.

That then is the basic concept, put very simply, and the rationale for it being put equally simply. But there are a number of objections to that basic concept, some of them thoughtfully put in the course of this debate, some of them much more dogmatically put. I believe those objections need to be answered, although not in the degree of detail that will be appropriate in the Committee stage. Perhaps we can usefully at this stage at least draw a map of where the main objections are coming from, what they amount to, and the broad nature of the answer to them.

I say at the outset that I readily acknowledge the force of a number of objections that can be put to the fixed term concept in its absolutely unqualified form, and indeed I have built into the Bill and the amendments that I propose subsequently to move to it answers to some of those objections. In the real world that we inhabit it is only a relatively qualified form of the fixed term concept that could, politically or constitutionally, make any sense. But let me not draw those sorts of distinctions. Let me try systematically to identify the major categories of objections first of all and then the particular objections within each of those categories.

I think there are perhaps five categories of objection overall. In the first place, there is the objection that the fixed term concept removes the opportunity for getting rid of governments which should be got rid of. The second category of objection is that it removes the opportunity for a government to renew its mandate in circumstances where, it is argued, it is desirable for it to have that opportunity. The third category of objection is that, if there are any qualifications to the fixed term concept at all, it is not really a fixed term system and the whole thing is a mirage or a chimera and not worth pursuing.

The fourth category of objection is that the fixed term proposal will not, in fact, solve the problem of the Senate's powers, to the extent that people perceive that to be a problem. The final category of objection is that to the extent that the fixed term concept, as put forward in legislative form, does solve the problem of Senate powers, vis-a-vis the House of Representatives, then it is destructive of the Senate as an institution. I think those five categories pretty well broadly summarise the range of themes that emerged in this debate and in external commentary upon this issue, of which there has been a good deal. I will endeavour to deal, as succinctly as I can, with the basic objections put in each of those categories.

First of all, I deal with the arguments around the general theme that the fixed term concept makes it impossible to remove a government which ought to be got rid of. Objection No. 1 within this category is as follows: It is said there must be a provision for an election to be held when a government in the House of Representatives loses its majority and no other government can be formed which has the confidence of the House of Representatives. The answer to that objection is: Yes, of course. The fixed term concept must be qualified if we are to retain a Westminster parliamentary system of the kind we are all familiar with, to accommodate that particular contingency. The Bill makes provision for that in terms of the no confidence procedure which is there set out. Whether the details of that particular drafting of the no confidence formula are sufficient to satisfy everyone that the problem has been effectively met, is something we can again debate in the Committee stage.

Objection No. 2-this, I think, came most prominently, as did many of the objections, from Senator Lewis-is as follows: It is said there must be an election whenever a new government is formed, and that the Bill is deficient to the extent that it does not allow for this. This is the notion that somehow the system of responsible government demands that there not be new governments formed simply by the ebb and flow of majorities within a chamber but that whenever a government loses the confidence of the chamber for any reason, then without waiting to test whether some other government can be formed with a majority, an election ought to be held, and that to the extent that the fixed term parliament concept, as it is drafted in my proposed Bill, would rule that out, to that extent the fixed term concept is a bad interference with the principles of responsible government. My answer to that kind of objection, as I think was Senator Hamer's, is that, true it is, the Bill does not provide for any mechanism to deal with that situation; in fact, on the contrary, it makes provision for a new government to be formed, after the old one loses the confidence of the House of Representatives, without an election being held if that new government can win a confidence vote in the House of Representatives. I would simply argue, as defenders of this proposal would argue, that it amounts to a misunderstanding of the Westminster system of responsible government to demand more than that of this proposal. It is a misunderstanding of the system of responsible government as it has always operated to require that an election be necessary in those circumstances.

Objection No. 3 is a trickier one and one that will, I think, demand some more thoughtful and careful response from this chamber. That is the argument, again put with considerable passion by Senator Lewis and also I suppose by Senator MacGibbon that the fixed term concept as has been advanced here makes no provision for the removal of a government which is grossly misbehaving itself. Senator Lewis put it another way by referring to this being a kind of charter for elected dictatorships. This sort of objection overlooks, of course, that this is pretty much exactly the case at the moment under our system of responsible government. So long as a government has secure majorities, particularly, of course, if it has them in both Houses, there really are no practical limits on what that government can do. There is, however, a possible argument, which I readily acknowledge, that if a government is, to put it at its highest, behaving in a way that amounts to a gross and patent breach, not only of the law in some way but also of the constitutional system itself, then there is perhaps, it can be argued, a constitutional convention which would allow the Governor-General a reserve power to dismiss in those circumstances.

As to that argument, I would simply say this: The existence of that power is highly controversial and highly contentious. It has never been exercised in modern times in the United Kingdom under the constitutional monarchy as it there operates. It could only be thought capable of operating, I suspect, in the Australian rather bastardised system of constitutional monarchy that we have developed through the Governor-Generalate and the governorships in the States. It has never really been used in Australia, with the possible exception of the Game case in 1932, although what was involved there remains highly controversial since it was simply an illegality that was claimed and nothing really higher than that on the part of the Lang Government. It is difficult to argue that that is what was involved in 1975, although defenders of Sir John Kerr will undoubtedly argue that that does constitute a further precedent of some weight for the existence of such a convention.

Finally, it can be argued that it is a power which surely, given the difficulty it has caused in the past, is unlikely ever to be used again. It also can be said in general terms that if there is any prospect of a dictatorship being exercised by anyone in our democratic system on first principles, as unhappy as any dictatorship might be or any behaviour tending in that direction, it is rather more appropriate that that misbehaviour be on the part of an elected government rather than an unelected officer, however high that officer's status might be. To the extent that there is some ultimate sanction which might be argued to be needed here-I understand this is the sort of point that is worrying Senator Martin-I acknowledge there may be some case for giving consideration to perhaps a constitutional impeachment procedure of a kind that is available in the United States of America in its fixed term system against the elected Executive, the presidency. That is something about which I have fairly profound reservations but I acknowledge that a serious argument can be conducted on it and I think the appropriate place to have it is in the Committee stage.

The next category of objections that I identified relate to the notion of a renewal of mandate-that a government ought to be able, for one reason or another , to renew its mandate before its term expires, if it feels that to do so would be to the advantage of either it or the country. The first objection under this heading-let us keep them numerical and call this one No. 4-would be cast in these terms: The government of the day would need to be given the opportunity to seek a double dissolution if it were being obstructed in its ordinary legislation-let us leave aside money Bills-by a hostile Senate. As to that and the concept of a renewal of mandate in that situation to overcome the possible hostility of an upper House, I simply say that I agree and that the Bill as now proposed to be amended does make provision for the retention of the double dissolution provision in its present form. That retention creates some other difficulties for other aspects of the proposal, but we will come to them in a moment. So in the sense of renewal of the mandate in the context of upper House obstruction, yes, that is accommodated.

Objection No. 5, however, puts the point another way and focuses purely on the situation within the lower House itself. This objection is that the opportunity is needed for the Government to renew its mandate if it has some controversial measure that it wants community support for or if it is drifting in a kind of limbo situation without having, on most of the measures that it puts up, the support of the House of Representatives but not being in a situation where anyone is prepared to move a no confidence motion in it. This scenario, implausible as it might be thought to be in practice, was one that, of course, again was pursued and pushed with some vigour by Senator Lewis. As to that, I answer that it is true that there are not the same opportunities under this proposed scheme for the Government to call an early election for reasons of this or any other kind. The answer has to be here that this is simply the price that one pays for the other advantages that are involved in the fixed term concept and that on balance it is a small price given the magnitude of the other advantages in terms of stability and predictability of the electoral cycle, not to mention the potential advantages in terms of the relationships between the two Houses. In other words, I put the point-it is a confess and avoid sort of answer I suppose, as lawyers would describe it-that yes, that is one of the situations that can arise in a fixed term parliament concept, creating an incapacity for a government to renew its mandate as a result of real or imagined difficulties within the lower House itself, but in practice that is a situation relatively unlikely to arise as long as our party system operates the way it has done. To the extent that it does arise, that is just one of the prices-probably the main price-that we would have to pay for having all the other improvements that would be involved in this change.

The next category of objections-in my list it comes out as No. 6-is this: If we have any qualifications at all to enable an extraordinary election of the House of Representatives or to enable a double dissolution in the circumstances of upper House disruption that we have postulated, we no longer have a fixed term parliament system. The objection is put a little less formally than that by saying that it is not really a fixed term system as long as the government of the day can manipulate these kinds of exception provisions to its own advantage. One way it could do so, it is suggested, is by passing a no confidence motion in itself in the House of Representatives as a purely formal device to get itself to the polls on an earlier date. Another much more practically likely possibility, it is thought, is that-

TALK.START.PARA: —What, and vote against itself?

—That is what is said and what is argued. I think that would be wildly implausible as a practical matter, at least on the first occasion that that device was sought to be used. It might be easier to do it subsequently and claim that it is simply a technical device to get an early election. But one would look a damn fool doing it for the first time. I would hate to have the task, even with Senator Chipp's public relation skills, of persuading the public that I was fair dinkum, wanted their support and demanded their confidence, having just moved a vote of no confidence in myself. Nonetheless, that is an objection that is seriously put and I think it has to be seriously answered.

SPEECH.PARA: The more serious objection, I think, is that the double dissolution provisions can be very easily manipulated by a government of the day simply by throwing up to the Senate some manifestly unconscionable proposition and using the Senate's obvious rejection of that manifestly unconscionable provision as a trigger in the hands of the House of Representatives government to be used any time it pleases to get, not just a dissolution of the House of Representatives at a politically opportune time, but the whole of the Senate out as well. How do we answer that kind of objection? As I said, the first scenario involving a no confidence motion moved by a government against itself is probably pretty fanciful but the second one is much more realistic.

I think there was a problem in the first version of this Bill to the extent that there were no real disincentives built into the mechanism to operate against the system being used, or rather misused, in that way. But the amendment that is proposed-all of these amendments have been, I assure the Senate, a product of an awful lot of discussion around the place-makes provision for an early election that is held for any of these extraordinary reasons to produce a government which holds office only for the duration of the original cycle. So it is that if one is two years down the track and one decides that the electoral scenario 12 months hence is likely to be a little hot and that one would rather have an election right now, one does not derive any advantage from pushing the double dissolution button or pulling the trigger that one has already created some time before to give oneself that conveniently timed election. There is no point whatsoever in doing it because the government that would be thus produced would hold office only for the duration of the cycle; in other words, until one year hence. I think for all practical purposes that is likely to amount to a pretty massive disincentive to the artificial use of these extraordinary election provisions in fact to get an election on at a time of the government's own choosing.

The final category of objections we come to are the implications of all of this for the Senate. There are two distinct objections-Nos 7 and 8 in the list respectively-so far as the Senate is concerned. Objection No. 7 is of the following kind: The fixed term concept will not solve the problem of Senate power. The way this argument is put is as follows: There is nothing to stop the Senate blocking Supply just because of the basic fixed term rule being in the Constitution. There may be double dissolution Bills already in existence of which the Senate can take advantage at the time it blocks Supply, in exactly the same way as occurred, of course, in 1974 and 1975. There were, fortuitously, double dissolution Bills already in existence. We did not have to wait for the three-month double dissolution process under section 57 to work itself out.

It is further argued that the Senate could block Supply on the basis that it insisted the House of Representatives resolve the impasse thus created by passing a vote of no confidence in itself. In other words, the argument is put that one could not just assume that the Senate would take the view in those circumstances that there was nothing it could do to force the House of Representatives to an election. The Senate would fasten its beady collective eye on that provision which says that a government can go to the polls early if it satisfies the formal requirement of a no confidence resolution being passed in it in the House of Representatives. The Senate could demand, it could say to a House of Representatives: 'You have a means of holding an early election; we will block Supply and create an awful lot of difficulties for you but you can resolve those difficulties by going to the polls, by using the technical device of passing a technical vote of no confidence in yourself'.

The further argument-and it is a more worrying one-is that the Senate might block Supply, not with the intention of forcing the government of the day to the polls but rather with the intention of forcing concessions from the government of the day as far as the Budget was concerned, forcing actual changes to the Bill rather in the way that occurs in the United States at the moment. The Senate cannot force anyone to the polls by blocking a Budget and it knows that compromise ultimately has to be achieved if the nation is not to collapse on the rocks. But it also knows that its mere ability to block, and all the delay power that goes with that capacity to block, gives it an enormous amount of bargaining power vis-a-vis the other chamber and it is bargaining power, of course, that it constantly uses. Therefore, all those arguments amount one way or the other to a proposition that merely by putting in place a fixed term system does not in itself solve the problem of Senate power.

What are the answers to that? One possible answer is that these are theoretical options only as far as the Senate is concerned, that the Senate just will not block Supply as a matter of practical political dynamics; if it cannot force an election by doing so it will not risk the hostility or political obloquy that would be involved in doing so. The other practical argument is that the House of Representatives will be careful in future to avoid creating double dissolution triggers to avoid just that possibility of the Senate taking advantage of a fortuitous section 57 trigger being in place.

But I am not sure that those answers are really good enough. I acknowledge that there are problems in relying simply on these kinds of dynamics. I acknowledge that there are real problems in the potential development of greater Senate power with respect to Budgets than exists at the moment if one has a fixed term system but keeps the Senate Supply power absolutely intact. Thus the Bill contains a provision to amend section 53 to remove its powers with respect to major money Bills. That amendment is in a substantially modified form in the terms of the proposed amendments which are before the Senate at the moment. I have suddenly realised that I have only 30 minutes in which to debate this matter. I was working on the basis that my speech would take about 35 minutes. May I have a few extra minutes to finish off my speech, Mr Acting Deputy President?

TALK.START.PARA: —You need to seek leave to do so.
—I need only about three more minutes.
—Two minutes.
—Senator Evans, it has been suggested that leave will be granted if you limit yourself to two minutes.
—Okay.
—Leave is granted.

—I am on my second last point. I was trying to put the whole thing in a proper context. I am saying that I think that ultimately the only way in which one can cope with those sorts of arguments is simply to say that the Bill must contain a provision to amend section 53 so as to remove or limit the powers of the Senate with respect to money Bills. We can debate the details of that formula later. But unless we do that we have a whole lot of problems in terms of the relationship between the two Houses created by the fixed term mechanism.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the objection is of a quite different kind but is still related to the Senate. To the extent that the fixed term parliament concept will solve the problem of Senate power with respect to money Bills, it is inconsistent with the credibility and status of the Senate as an institution for its powers to be limited in this way or its status to be changed in this way. My answer is simply this: It is a confusion to think that questions of formal power with respect to money Bills will necessarily impinge upon and necessarily reduce the status, the prestige, the clout of the institution. It is a mistake to think that those things are inextricably intertwined. I do believe that the Senate has a major and useful role to play as a House of review and that its status in that respect will be enhanced rather than reduced if its powers with respect to doing the things that we have been talking about are in fact removed.

I make it clear in answer to Senator MacGibbon that while it was once my position that this place ought to be abolished that is no longer the position of the party nor is it my personal position, having thought very carefully through the realities of this situation. I think there is much that this and other upper Houses can do in improving legislation, scrutinising the Executive, monitoring the bureaucracy, initiating and generating ideas. None of those functions will be impinged upon in any way if the powers of the Senate in these very formal senses we are talking about are in fact reduced.

It is a long argument. There is not time to have any more of it now, I readily acknowledge. I am grateful, Mr Acting Deputy President, for the indulgence of the Senate thus far. I simply make the point that there is enough in the argument now for the Senate, I think, to support a second reading of this Bill although there is much more that needs to be debated in a reasoned way at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I apologise. I was not aware of the situation; I should have been. But I do think it important that I should, if I may, take some moments-and I will be as brief as I can-to state the position following the debate itself and particularly following Senator Evans's summary. This private member's Bill seeks to make some very radical changes. Should those changes be carried within the Parliament, in both chambers, put into referendum form and carried in referendum-a very unlikely result-they would make great changes indeed in the nature and character of both Houses of this Parliament, and that should be kept in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say at the outset that the Government is opposed to the Bill and will oppose the Bill in this chamber, and should it proceed elsewhere it will be opposed elsewhere. If I may comment very briefly, the nature of this Bill goes to the very heart of and seeks to change the very structure of the parliamentary institution as it was formed, as the convention debates envisaged it and as over the years the various communities and States have enshrined it. The fact is that the people of Australia, in their six separate State parliaments, in giving some fixed sovereignty to the Commonwealth and setting up a Commonwealth Government while withholding the residual powers themselves, were determined that there should be a bicameral system of a very specific nature. Indeed, the very existence of a Commonwealth parliament depended on one fundamental thing-that the rights of the less populous States should be preserved and therefore they should have within themselves at all times the power to be able to resist being overrun by the two more populous States. Therefore, fundamentally this Parliament was constructed in two ways. The House of Representatives was modelled on the House of Commons and the Senate was modelled upon the Senate of the American Congress with a similar geography, a similar size, a similar equality of States and with an identical attitude towards the placing of a finance power.

I want to direct my attention fundamentally to the senators of the four less populous States. These States said: 'If we do not have the power to resist money Bills, if we do not have the power in fact to bring the lower House to account, then we, as four States, will have no voice at all in the Commonwealth Parliament'. Fundamentally we are getting right to that. The populace of the four less populous States should keep in mind that this attacks the very nature and structure of this parliamentary system as it was seen to be formed. I have no doubt in the world that should it by mischance ever be put to referendum by a future government it would not be acceded to in the four less populous States, or I think in the other States.

The arguments that have been put bear a little testing. It was said that we need to have a fixed term for the House of Representatives; otherwise there is some destabilising element and some unpredictability. Indeed, reference was made to destabilising speculation in recent days. That was aimed by Mr Hawke to destabilise Mr Hayden. That was the reason for that and it would have occurred whether there was a fixed term or otherwise. But I want to say that it is an interesting situation. I think there is a confusion of argument here. There is confusion between the length of a term-a three-year term, a four-year term, a five-year term or otherwise-and the concept of stability. It may well be that those who think that a three-year term is too short see some instability in a term of three years or less.

I want to remind the Senate that if Senator Evans's arguments are correct then the House of Commons has been wrong for centuries- because quaintly enough the Mother of Parliaments has always, even though it has had a five-year term, believed that a fundamental of a lower House should be a fixed maximum term and that the government should go to the people when it wanted to go to them, and it has been doing that. Does anyone say that the United Kingdom has been unstable and that there has been unnecessary speculation over the years because of this? Again there is a quaint belief that there is something wrong in going to the people before the end of a term.

The fundamental principle of democracy is the right of the electorate to recall those who are temporarily governing it and to submit them to the jury system. When this Senate was set up it was given the power, particularly in terms of the four less populous States, to bring people to the test of the ballot box. What is wrong with that? What can be fundamentally wrong with the test of the ballot box? The very first proposition I put is: If indeed we are talking about fixed terms for the House of Representatives there may well be some who think that the tenure, the maximum term, should be longer than three years, but if there is instability it has not occurred in the centuries of experience of the House of Commons. That, I think, is the strongest argument that one can put in this regard. Secondly, of course, all honourable senators must understand that implicit in this Bill which was brought in on 11 November-I ask honourable senators to bear that date in mind because it has been referred to-is that the money power of the Senate, which is the real target of attack by the Australian Labor Party, should be removed ultimately so that, in fact, the less populous States would no longer have a voice. It is no good having other kinds of voices. It is no good our getting up here like a high school debating society if in fact the very reason for the existence of the bicameral system has been destroyed.

Every honourable senator in this place from those four less populous States should, before committing themselves to this legislation, go back to the conventions of the Constitution. They should then go back to their own States and ask the people in those States whether they are willing to take away the rights of the smaller States to say to the House of Representatives: 'No, you will not overrun us. If you attempt to overrun us we will have the right of recall.'. They would not have the right of recall in three or four years' time when more and more damage could have been done but would have the right of recall with immediacy. The great reason that there has been a federation in this country is that that reserve power has lain there. Again, I want to say that this Parliament, using the powers of the Constitution, brought about a dissolution of Parliament in November 1975. The Parliament, acting within the powers of the Constitution brought about that dissolution. The Governor-General simply acted within the Constitution. It does no one any good to say otherwise. Indeed, the result at the ballot box in the subsequent elections has made that clear. If the proposal to have a system of fixed term parliaments itself is indeed right, the experience of the House of Commons has been wrong. Nobody has suggested that.

I simply want to sum up by saying that arguments may be put at constitutional conventions for a longer term of Parliament and there may be arguments that if the Senate is to seek the recall of the House of Representatives the Senate itself ought to be pulled out so that both Houses can be submitted to the jury. The alternatives are that if this policy were adopted in its totality, the Senate would have no real cause for existence. Make no mistake about that. If that were the case the Senate's fundamental power of being a States' House and of making sure that it is speaking for the States would have gone. Its ability to recall would have gone. That is the fundamental point. I cannot believe that any honourable senator could go back to one of those four States and say: 'I am advocating a change in the teeth of the constitutional conventions drawn up in the late nineteenth century. I am in fact supporting a situation which would place those States in a vulnerable position in the other place. In fact, it would be three or four years before we could even have a say at the ballot box to rectify this.'. That seems to me to be the height of insanity within a federation. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak in this debate. I would have liked to deal with this Bill in more detail but I am not able to now. I thank the Senate. I indicate that the Government will oppose this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not want to have a further right of reply in response to what the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) has said. There is nothing more I want to say on this subject at the moment. I do not believe anyone in the chamber wants me to say anything more on the subject. I do not believe there was anything in the tired old cliches advanced by Senator Sir John Carrick which demands that I say anything more by way of reply. I think it is important that I simply stake a claim, as it were, for a genuine right of reply to be vested in those honourable senators who introduce private members' Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: It may have well been a result of a misunderstanding or whatever on Senator Sir John Carrick's part that he sought to speak in this debate after I had sat down, having exercised my right of reply. I suspect his motive was rather less elevated than that and that his contribution was motivated by desire at the last possible moment to remind his troops as to what the Government's position was and to intimidate them to that extent. I hope that they will not look at his contribution in that spirit. Such a crude tactic does not deserve being treated with any respect at all. I do not think Senator Sir John Carrick's contribution was consistent with the constructive spirit which, for the most part, has pervaded this debate and which is necessary if we are to have rational discussion on matters of constitutional reform. It is only by bipartisan consensus that this will happen. Since Senator Hill has to catch an aeroplane I will sit down now, having made that point. I hope I have made it very forcefully .
