SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to alter, in accordance with the wording circulated among honourable senators, the terms of the motion of which I gave notice at an earlier stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the Polish workers were and are seeking bread, peace and that freedom of association enshrined in the International Labour Organisation Convention No. 87 concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, and that this Convention has been ratified by both the Soviet Union and Poland;

(b) condemns the declaration of Martial Law in Poland on December 13 last year and the subsequent imprisonment of some 15,000 trade union activists, intellectuals, journalists, and members of the KOR dissident group;

(c) condemns the continuing detention of Solidarity officials, including its leader Mr Lech Walesa, and calls on the Australian Government to lodge a strong protest with Polish authorities at the treatment of Mr Walesa and other Solidarity officials.

That this resolution of the Australian Senate be conveyed to Archbishop Josef Glemp, Primate House, Warsaw, Poland, being a person who is concerned for the welfare of Mr Walesa and who is also in communication with General Jaruzelski.

As honourable senators will appreciate, the course of history has affected the relevance of some of the wording of my original notice of motion. On 26 November 1980, more than 20 months ago, when I first gave notice, we were all fearful of an imminent Soviet invasion of Poland. That invasion did not take place but instead, on 13 December 1981, almost a year later, martial law was declared. The independent trade union, Solidarity, was suspended; many thousands of people were detained; curfews were imposed and numerous civil liberties were suspended. Despite the release of some detainees last July, the Solidarity leader, Mr Lech Walesa, and an estimated 1,500 people or more, are still detained for their opposition to martial law.

The last overnight curfew appears to have been lifted but the continued detention of Mr Walesa and many other trade union activists, intellectuals, journalists and members of KOR, apparently without any trial, is intolerable. There have been many false rumours that Mr Walesa was about to be released but the release has never taken place, except for a brief occasion when he was permitted to see his new-born daughter. It is said that Mr Walesa is presently being held at a prison camp at Alarmowo near the Soviet border which, by its very location, has ominous overtones. We cannot just forget about these brave people. The second anniversary of the Gdansk agreement of 1980, which gave birth to Solidarity, will occur on 31 August. The remaining underground leaders of Solidarity have called for peaceful demonstrations during August. I might mention that two representatives of Solidarity will be in Australia at the end of this month and the beginning of next month.

My original resolution called for this matter to be raised in the International Labour Organisation and the United Nations. In fact, the matter was raised in the ILO last June, when a Solidarity leader took the floor and, not unexpectedly , all Soviet bloc delegates walked out of the meeting. It was also raised earlier this year before the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations. On 10 March that body voted to call on the Secretary-General to appoint a body of inquiry to investigate the alleged abuse of human rights in Poland. It was the first time since the establishment of the Commission in 1946 that it had been called on to investigate developments in any East European country.

The Polish events have produced strong feelings from quite diverse sources. For example, I remind honourable senators that on 29 December last the Praesidium of the Socialist International issued a statement denouncing the 'brutal repression of human rights' in Poland and calling for the release of all detainees, the restoration of Solidarity's right to act in freedom and the ending of martial law. The Australian representative at the Human Rights Commission meeting quoted the strong words of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, on 26 January 1982 and called for the lifting of martial law and the release of detainees.

I am confident, therefore, that this motion will attract support from all quarters. I have taken the unusual step of including in my reworded motion a request that, if the motion be adopted, the resolution be conveyed to Archbishop Josef Glemp. The significance of this is that while Solidarity might have been suppressed in Poland, the Catholic Church, which is keyed to an appreciation of the Polish situation, has not been suppressed. I have no illusions that the resolution will produce an immediate release of Mr Walesa and the other detainees but it, together with other expressions of solidarity and support from other areas of the world, must remind the Polish authorities that the outside world continues to remember what has happened and is concerned for the welfare of the brave people who were attempting to exercise rights which we take for granted. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion put before the Senate this evening by Senator Harradine. I do so because there is no doubt that the Polish people continue to suffer a repression which is quite unjust and which denies to them the rights of all workers, in particular, and peasants to organise in societies and associations of their own creation in order to advance the conditions of their working lives and, indeed, of their whole lives within Polish society. I have pointed out to the chamber before the many links between Poland and Australia. Many Polish refugees came to the shores of my home State of Tasmania-indeed, it is the home State of Senator Harradine-after the Second World War and found arduous employment in the hydro-electric camps which dotted the Tasmanian landscape at that time. Of course the flow of refugees to Australia from Poland has not ceased, as people seek that freedom which they are unable to obtain under the regime of the Communist Party and the military dictatorship which has latterly displaced it.

SPEECH.PARA: Further than that, we have a link which goes back in history. One recalls that in 1794 Kosciusko, the great American revolutionary hero, returned to his native Poland in order to lead a rebellion against Russian repression and occupation of his country. Kosciusko's troops armed themselves with scythes attached to long sticks or branches, which were taken up as a symbol by the Rural Solidarity in its marches of protest in 1980-81. Of course that link between Australia and Poland is memorialised by the naming of our highest peak after Kosciusko, that revolutionary hero of the Polish people who failed, regrettably, to remove the Russian occupation and suppression of his people back in the late 18th century.

There is more to our relationship than the mere naming of our most noble peak after that Polish revolutionary hero and I am quite sure that the motion moved today will commend itself to the whole of the Senate. It provides a way in which the Senate can express in a definite way its support for and solidarity with the great mass of the people of Poland. The motion mentions that the Polish workers are seeking bread, peace and freedom of association enshrined in International Labour Organisation Convention No. 87. Earlier this year that Organisation attempted to condemn the present authorities in Poland for their denial of those basic rights of organisation and association. It should not be forgotten that the International Labour Organisation is perhaps the only organisation in the world which has the mechanism available to it to investigate the conditions of workers in the states which are party to it.

Such an investigation was carried out and the conference committee on the application of conventions and recommendations did condemn the Polish Government 's actions in respect of the enforcement of martial law which denied its citizens the right to organise in associations of their own creation. When that resolution from the conference committee was taken to the plenary session of the ILO, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, its satellite states and other countries subservient to USSR foreign policy prevented the report of the conference committee being adopted by boycotting the plenary session and thus disabling it from operating for lack of a quorum. Thus only in that way was the International Labour Organisation prevented in plenary session from condemning the Polish martial law authorities for their repression of the rights of workers and peasants in Poland.

It is pleasing to note that the Australian Labor Party is under no such constraint and passed a resolution at its national conference, held in the first week in July this year, which supports the workers of Poland. I would like to read that resolution into the Hansard record. It states:

Conference supports the right of the Polish people to determine their own future free from external interference and pressure. Therefore it condemns the imposition of martial law in Poland and the accompanying restrictions of political, civil and trade union rights.

Conference urges the Polish Government to release all political prisoners and restore civil liberties. In recognition of the close relationships between a stable economy and political freedom in Poland, Conference urges western governments to provide economic assistance.

Conference calls for the granting of exit visas to all Poles who wish to be reunited with their families living in Australia. We urge the Federal Government to apply all diplomatic pressure within its means to achieve this end.
This resolution to be conveyed to the Polish Embassy, Solidarity in Australia, and the Committee for Polish Family Reunions.

There we have a resolution of the national conference of the Australian Labor Party which is in direct line with various resolutions passed at the various levels of the Labor movement in Australia, whether the industrial movement or the political wing. As Senator Harradine pointed out, it is in line with resolutions passed by the Socialist International with which the Australian Labor Party is affiliated. It articulates in formal terms the Australian Labor movement's point of view regarding the events in Poland which have so tragically befallen that country.

It may be that many Australians, seeing some weeks ago on television the release of some numbers of detainees, may have thought that there was some loosening up of the strict regime under which the Polish people have been suffering these past months. Indeed, that is not so. Repression continues. Those who are found to be organising in support of Solidarity continue to be imprisoned and of course we have had the spectacle of thousands flocking to Victory Square day after day in order to recreate the cross of flowers which adorns that square, despite the fact that the troops of this martial law regime desecrate that cross by removing it during the early hours of each morning.

That cross, which was originally intended as a memorial to the late Polish Primate, Cardinal Wyszinski, has become a focus of opposition to martial law. I think the symbol of a cross of flowers is very significant. It is a symbol of the faith of the people, which is the source of their values and which they cherish and which gives life to, and sustains their strong yearning for, self- determination in their working and social lives. The delicacy of the flowers is also significant because to me it symbolises the very vulnerability and fragility of the human spirit as it strives to be free. Apparently that can be so easily suppressed and bruised by those who use brute force. But that cross of flowers is restored day by day, just as surely as the authorities try to suppress the expression of freedom of the human spirit which we see in Poland.

This motion, which, as I say, I am confident that the whole Senate supports, expresses our view as free parliamentarians in a democracy in support of the revolution which is occurring in that particularly vital country in eastern Europe, where the ordinary people have withdrawn their allegiance on such a large scale from the state and the Communist Party in favour of that organisation which was illegal, was allowed to flourish for a matter of months, and then was declared illegal again and has been supressed ever since. This revolution in Poland commands our support. It has an evidently democratic basis. It is democratic in that it is obviously really based in the will of the people, as tens of millions flocked to its banners. But it commands our support even further because of its evidently non-violent character. It is one of those revolutions against repression which has the characteristic so marked in the revolutions and social change brought about by Gandhi and Martin Luther King. Once again, in Lech Walesa's movement, we see that non-violent social change is the way eventually which forges the new society.

The spectacular impact of Solidarity throughout the West, and of course within the Iron Curtain countries, has been that the people attempted to form these free trade unions, both among the industrial proletariat and among the peasants in Rural Solidarity, against the will of the party. They exercised free will against the will of the Communist Party. They exercised the right to associate against the will of the Communist Party. They did so with tremendous courage. The party, of course, is unable to grapple with this phenomenon, because paradoxically it proves one of Marx's hopes-namely, that working people can take control of their destiny, can humanise their place of work, can humanise the whole of society by themselves exercising their freedom rather than being subject to the power of capital or of the bureaucratic Communist Party, which purported to express their hopes for the future.

The claims of the Communist Party have been stripped bare and have been reasserted only by the imposition of a military dictatorship which at present controls the destiny of the Polish people. But as with the restoration of the cross of flowers day by day in Victory Square, I believe that the Polish people and their spirit, evidenced so often over recent years, will bring about a completely new society in Poland which will have much to teach both those who presently suffer behind the Iron Curtain and those of us in our presently organised mixed economies in countries such as Australia.

As I have said, there are many links between the Australian and Polish people. They are expressed in the naming of our most noble peak after the great revolutionary hero, Kosciusko. They have been expressed in other notices of motion in the Senate concerning humanitarian aid, submitted by the Labor Party but supported by the whole of the Senate late last year. I believe that this motion is very timely. I hope that when it is conveyed to the Archbishop Primate of Poland, he will give it circulation so as to lift the spirits of the Polish people and to confirm the hope with which they carry out their struggle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to associate the Australian Democrats with the motion. We have heard the situation in Poland expounded with passion and with great discernment by Senator Harradine and Senator Tate. I do not want to try to add more to what they have said, except to say that too seldom do we have debated in the Senate matters of this kind of great concern outside Australia. This is a motion of which all honourable senators would want to approve, and I commend it to the Senate. I do so particularly in this case, concerning a country such as Poland, which has a tragic situation, in which its history has been dictated to it over decades and centuries by its geography, so that we have there people who, through no fault of their own, are subject continuously to the kind of pressures to which they are subject now. It seems to be a perpetually recurring theme in their history. If only there were some way in which the world could organise itself so that this did not happen-so that people were not hostages perpetually to history, continually being damaged and destroyed by it.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular movement in Poland is of the greatest importance, probably to the world, because it is, after all, an expression of freedom of a kind, the freedom to live and work and do things as they wish, within a communist country. This is of great importance. I am one of those who believe, and I always have believed, that it is useless and ridiculous to look at a monolithic communism throughout the world as something which must be attacked and destroyed. That seems to me one of the most ludicrous and ridiculous ideas that ever was expressed, yet for a long time it was expressed by very many people. Fortunately , what would have been the consequence of their expression never came to pass, and I hope that it never does so. But it is of great reassurance, I think, to any student of history and international affairs to see what is happening in Poland. I think that every one of us must feel deeply for everyone concerned with that movement.

I agree with Senator Tate that the movement is the more striking and the more important because of its basically non-violent nature. For this to occur within a communist country is of great moment to the world-although it is not surprising that the country within which it occurs is Poland. So the Polish people do not want to be satellites, mere pawns in the games of international politics. One wonders whether the Russians might, in the case of Poland, be thinking back to the lesson of China. Perhaps this might happen. Right back to the beginning of the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party, it is notorious that the Russians did not support Mao Tse-tung and the party which eventually created the communist republic. Far from it. They saw this as a radical diversion from communism-a group of mere agrarian reformers who had to be discouraged. Nevertheless, there of course the situation was not controlled by the Russians. The People's Republic of China developed into the sort of country, I think, which is very different-I have not been in Russia but I have been in China, and I have spoken to people who have been in both countries-where there is a very different view of things, yet all are embraced within the basic communist ethic. On that basis it behoves us to support the motion and we must commend Senator Harradine for bringing it forward. The Australian Democrats will certainly support it. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As a Liberal senator, I very much support the motion that Senator Harradine has brought to the Senate. It goes to the heart of my own political philosophy and the philosophy of so many in South Australia who have expressed themselves on this totalitarian action in Poland. It is not just the people from Poland and the now very well established range of Polish communities across all the States of Australia who are concerned about this matter. It is not just the immigrants from eastern Europe who have come at various stages, particularly after the Second World War, to gain freedom in Australia-from Romania, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union-and those ousted from their own countries of Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, and from other eastern European countries. It is also those other refugees, from Vietnam and other places of disturbance in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only these refugees who have in their own lifetime experienced so directly the challenge to freedom and their necessity to escape to a free country, Australia. I believe that it goes very deeply to the hearts and thoughts of all Australians that there is a contest in Poland, a battle for freedom. That is why there has been such unanimity in Australia in expressing support for the call for a return to true freedom in that country. I know that General Jaruzelski and others in that dictatorship would contend that their actions were conducted with the noble intention of saving Poland from a Soviet invasion or that they were to save Poland from anarchy, disarray, disorder or civil war. In my mind these justifications are not plausible or compelling. They are excuses which bear careful consideration but they are still wanting. I believe people in Australia who have analysed the situation and those who have preceded me in speaking in the Senate are not convinced by these contentions. We have seen an odious denial of freedom to the people of Poland by a totalitarian dictatorship. The apparent excuses that it may use are not in any way a justification for this action.

What has Mr Lech Walesa done to deserve detention? What crime has he committed? He has sought to represent the people of his country. He has sought to bring them material, social and political gains. It is a blot upon the history of Poland that this present dictatorship has made a martyr of him by denying him his freedom and keeping him in detention.

An even worse odour surrounds the totalitarian system of the Soviet Union. I know that the people of South Australia were horrified this past week to read in our newspapers that the tragic attempt at the assassination of the Pope has, with substantial evidence, been traced to the Bulgarian secret service and beyond to the KGB in the Soviet Union. Whilst these sorts of conspiracies and plots always leave some doubt in the minds of those in Australia capable of sensible analysis, the evidence does appear to be substantial. I do not easily jump towards conspiracy theories about the Central Intelligence Agency or the KGB being behind all sorts of actions such as this around the world. But if that substantial evidence is all the more confirmed as the weeks go by the intensity of the odour that surrounds these secret totalitarian instruments in the Soviet Union and in Poland will increase.

The motion and its appropriate words will be directed from the Senate to Archbishop Josef Glemp, who represents not only the church but also the vast majority of freedom loving people in Poland. I assume and accept that a copy of this motion will also go directly to the attention of the Polish Ambassador in Australia and to the Polish Government. I had thought to seek an amendment to the motion so that it would have been specifically directed in that way as well as to the Archbishop and the people of Poland, but I rest in that matter because the Government of Australia, through very clear statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has already directly protested through the Ambassador and conveyed to the Polish Government its abhorrence at the denial of freedoms in Poland and it has called for redress . I am assured that there is no diminution in the Australian Government's position in this matter. I conclude by quoting from a statement by the Prime Minister on 26 January of this year. Amongst many statements that he made at that time he said:
Because they dared to try to obtain for themselves some small part of the freedoms which we take for granted, the Polish people are now suffering appalling hardship and repression under martial law.
A short time afterwards at the thirty-eighth session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights Australian representatives concluded their submission in the following words:

Australia calls for the lifting of martial law, the release of detainees, and an early return to the circumstances in which the people of Poland can be left free to find their own solution to their internal economic and political difficulties on the basis of consensus and reconciliation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had I not spoken in the debate I would not want it to be suggested that I did not support the motion. I rise merely to say that the problems in Poland are difficult and need to be resolved in the interests of the great majority of the Polish people, if not all of them. I could find fault with some aspects of the motion. For example, I am not sure that we are correct in suggesting that the treatment of Mr Walesa is necessarily something that ought to be condemned even though I condemn the fact that he is imprisoned and has been in detention for such a long period. Nevertheless, I think the overall direction of the motion is one which can be supported by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not necessarily agree with all that has been said during the debate. I find myself closer to the views that have been expressed by Senator Mason. I believe there are different motivations and objectives which we seek to apply to the circumstances that exist in Poland. To that extent it is a question of understanding the evolution that is taking place in some countries. The contribution that Senator Mason made about not regarding these countries as monolithic monsters needs to be examined a little more closely by people who are listening to this debate or speaking in it. The Polish people have a long history of struggle for freedom. They have been oppressed by old imperial Russia , by the Germans. Some people will assert that they have been to some extent persecuted by the Soviet Union. That is a point of contention. The Polish people are notorious for their desire for independence, freedom and the right to determine their own affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —'Famous' might be the word you are looking for.

—Yes, maybe it is. That strong feeling of the Polish people is one that we should support. Very few people who value liberty, freedom, the right to assemble and protest and to establish their own form of democracy would disagree with those objectives. I do not believe that we can contain in any part of the world the struggle for democracy, human rights and the desire to establish a better society. In the circumstances in Poland today there is enough evidence to show that the people still want to retain a socialist form of society. The Solidarity movement has made that plain on numerous occasions. The people do not want to return to a capitalist form of society. They want to retain the public ownership of the means of production, distribution and exchange. But they want to do it in their own way. I think that is the point on which they are in conflict with the Soviet Union and with other countries of the Eastern bloc. I think what we are seeing now and what we have seen, and I think to that extent what the government and the conservative members of the Parliament have failed to understand, is the slow but sure democratisation that is taking place and the breaking down of the monolith concept of communism.

SPEECH.PARA: Many forms of christianity exist and there are many forms of socialism, and, for that matter, there are probably many forms of communism. It is a question of understanding the aspirations of the Polish people. It seems to me that they are really in the forefront of the struggle to democratise their socialist regime. They want to retain a system under which they own the means of production. They want to move into areas of self-government and self-management. If one reads the intellectual views that are being expressed inside Poland, albeit sometimes by the underground Press, there is no doubt that the Polish people are impressed with the Yugoslav experience of self-management of its productive processes. I find it difficult, for example, completely to condemn the martial law that has applied in Poland now for such a long time. It may well have been that if the Polish authorities had not taken the steps that they took, they may have been involved in a much more dangerous exercise from the point of view of the Polish people. For example, an invasion by the Soviet Union would have been disastrous. It would have created a flashpoint in world relations and I doubt whether that would have contributed towards the normalisation that we want to see in that part of the world.

I think the super-powers have a tendency to regard certain areas as spheres of influence. For instance, the United States of America regards Latin America as a sphere of influence and therefore any movement towards democratisation and a greater say by the people in the management of their own affairs, even if they want to establish a form of socialism, is being denied to them. Similarly, the Soviet Union regards Eastern Europe as its sphere of influence. I cannot accept the fact that any of the major powers can establish, for their own purposes, for their sovereignty or for the protection of their interest, that other countries must occupy a subordinate position. That is an unacceptable position from the point of view of those people in Australia who regarded themselves as of the Left. It is not a position that we accept as being tenable or acceptable. For my part I want to see the establishment of the rights of people, wherever they are in the world, to determine their own affairs and to establish the form of society of their choice, even if they want to go to the degree of completely repudiating any influence of capitalism in the way in which their society operates. It is for each country to determine the form of society that it wants. That is why I took the strong stand that I did in respect of Timor and why I believe in our membership of organisations such as Amnesty International.

I think we have to put ourselves in the forefront of the struggle for human rights and the right of political dissent-the right for people to take views different from that of the majority view or even the view of the government of the day. Of course, we are pretty notorious for that in our own country. We spend all of our time opposing the government of the day. At this time we are in opposition against the government of the day. If elections are held and the government changes, then the conservative parties will take the view that they are entitled to campaign against the government of the day. If I accept that as a basic principle, and I do extend to all countries, to all peoples, to all groups, that same right and obligation to participate in the process of democracy. My only reservation about the motion is whether, in condemning martial law in Poland, that helps or hinders its development. But rather than being construed as being in opposition to the basic principle that no country should be forced to go through the torture and travail that exists now in Poland , I am prepared at least to lend support of the principles of normalisation in Poland and to express the hope that the trade union activists, the intellectuals , the journalists and the various dissident groups in Poland will ultimately be able to reach an understanding with the authorities, with the government, and with, as it turns out to be in this particular case, the communist leadership. That is the way in which this issued will ultimately be resolved in the best interests of the world and the Polish people.

I think if we look at this matter objectively, we will see that the Catholic Church, which is a very strong influence in the country, has taken a somewhat temperate position. It has not allowed itself to be manoeuvred into a position of opposition. It does not see itself as a rival centre, but rather as a conciliator, as a force in Poland that will try to bring together the different points of view in the country with a view to obtaining the normalisation which is so essential in Poland, and for that matter, in that part of the world.

I regard the rights of the trade unions in Poland and their leader, Mr Lech Walesa, as an important step in that process of reconciliation and, finally, normalisation. I appreciate that there are different motivations in this debate but I find it just a wee bit difficult to appreciate the attitude of some members of the Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He lends support to the trade union movement in Poland. However, in the time that I have been in this Parliament, there has not been a period of more than three or four months in which we have not had legislation introduced by the conservative parties which was designed to restrict the rights of trade unions and curtail the normal and proper functions and activities of the trade union movement. So I find a certain amount of hyprocrisy in that attitude. The Prime Minister is prepared to suggest to the authorities in Poland that they should have all the rights of normal trade union activity. But so much legislation passed here in the Parliament at the behest of the conservatives had as its motivation and its objective restrictions on the right of normal trade union activities and interference in trade union affairs. I know that Senator Harradine would concede that point.

It is difficult to make up one's mind about the destabilisation issue which was raised by the last speaker. I cannot say whether the KGB is involved in this or that particular activity in the world or whether the Central Intelligence Agency is involved. But I can understand the fear that exists in the minds of the leaders of the super-powers in relation to these matters. It is notorious that these organisations play a role of destabilisation, maybe in the belief that it is in defence of the interests of the countries that they represent. It is certainly notorious that the CIA plays a considerable role in Eastern Europe. Of course, it is this fear that accentuates the problem. It magnifies the problem and creates the antagonisms that we want to see resolved in countries such as Poland.

Finally, let me say that I do not believe that any ideology, philosophy, institution, party or movement can prevent the struggle for more democracy and the extension of the rights of people to determine their own affairs. I am certain that the martial law situation in Poland can only be a temporary phenomenon. It cannot exist permanently because ultimately the rights of the people to determine the form of society they want and the institutions to govern them will in fact prevail over the role that the authorities are playing in that country.

Only when there can be this reconciliation and give and take between what I suppose can be described as the forces of dissent and the authorities, only when they finally find a means of understanding one another's concepts, will we then have the sort of bread, peace and freedom which is suggested in the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel the need to speak because I have serious reservations about the motion before us. One cannot neglect one's duties in this place. It is fairly obvious that unless one watches the Notice Paper and is fully aware of the business that comes before the House, one could suddenly find that a proposition has been put before the Senate and supported when it ought to have attracted some criticism and some opposition. I find myself somewhat at variance with the proposition before us because I do not believe it is helpful. It is certainly not helpful to the Polish people who have suffered destabilisation over a number of years. Caught in a buffer situation between the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics and the Western democracies, the Polish people have come under the influence of conflicting forces.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the Polish people has been tragic. The conflict between these major forces has led to the virtual destruction of large parts of Poland, including the city of Warsaw, and led to the death of millions of Poles. One must have tremendous sympathy for them. What has emerged over the years is that the people and the economy of Poland have come under pressure both from the West and from what I might term the East. That has resulted in great damage and has led to the imposition of martial law. One must understand this before one condems the Polish people and, for that matter, the Polish Government in its endeavours to recover from a situation in which the country, because of Western influences and pressures, has found itself bankrupt. One must understand that the Polish Government in the past has been guilty of corruption and has not applied the principles of socialism as they ought to have been applied: It was difficult to apply those principles because socialism was never allowed to develop as it could have due to Western influences and the influences of the church. As a result, great poverty and great tensions developed. Many of the people moved from the country to the cities and subsequently were not able to be fed because collectivisation rationalisation of production in the countryside was not permitted to develop by one of the powers within the Polish economy-the church. One must understand this-

TALK.START.PARA: —Collectivism in the countryside prevented food reaching the cities .

—The opposite is the case. If the honourable senator looks at it clearly he will find that the rural economy in Poland did not adjust to the change in the overall economy. Just as we in this nation had to change and rationalise in many areas of our rural economy to produce the food to feed us and to export so it was necessary in Poland, but the church resisted that. No matter what Senator Tate says, that is the reality.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the proposition before us. I have reservations about it, and I must place my reservations on the record. It is hypocritical of us to give support to those forces that are in opposition to what the Government in Poland is endeavouring to do when in our own country, in Queensland at this very moment , prohibitive legislation is being imposed upon the workers that is horrific in its implications and in its application. At the very time that we are critical of what the Polish Government is doing, the Queensland has declared a state of emergency, has stood down workers, and is prepared to imprison them under the new security legislation because they seek to improve their conditions. If we are critical of what is being imposed in Poland, we must also be critical of the actions of a government within our own boundaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are hallucinating, Senator. Where would you rather live- Poland or Queensland?

—That is irrelevant, and the honourable senator knows it. He knows fairly clearly that one lives where one's roots are. One tries, as far as possible, to improve the conditions in the country in which one lives. It is quite idle to say: 'If you do not like it here, go elsewhere'. One stays to improve those conditions which one believes to be prohibitive and oppressive. It is no use the honourable senator coming forward with an idle interjection of that nature. I am concerned about this proposition because I believe it should be debated. It is said that considerable debate has taken place; and perhaps so. I add to the debate and I add my reservations to the debate. I am concerned that we do not have a proper understanding of the events which led to the Polish situation and to the restriction of Walesa. I regret that, and my record is clear. Many a time I have supported the underprivileged and the oppressed; just as this afternoon I supported the Palestinians and their right to exist in the face of the Israeli assault. I am not afraid to be branded anti-Semitic because I attack the Israelis and their actions in Lebanon, especially around Beirut. I am prepared to do that, I am prepared to support the Polish workers. But I am also prepared to understand the circumstances which led to the position in which Walesa finds himself. We are not without blame. All we are doing here is adding to that blame because we do not properly understand. We look at the Polish situation through capitalist eyes. I am suggesting that from time to time we ought to look at it through socialist eyes because that is the form of government which those people are prepared to accept. The real problem in Poland is that socialism is not allowed to be applied. That country came under tremendous pressures. The Polish Government was foolish enough to accept unlimited credit from the West, which the West then said was now-
—It was forced on them, was it? Are you saying it wasn't the socialist system that got them into trouble?

—Senator, it was not forced upon them, but nevertheless they accepted it, and they were unwise to do so. That sort of credit must and did come to an end. I have sympathy for the Polish people but I am not going to add to their problems. I think that this is a one-sided political exercise on the part of some, not to improve the situation but to exacerbate it. I find great difficulty in supporting the proposition which has been brought before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes the debate that has taken place on the motion raised by Senator Harradine and seconded by Senator Tate and to which a number of honourable senators have spoken. I think it is of interest to hear the differing views and particularly to note the conviction and sincerity with which those views were expressed by different senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's attitude towards recent developments in Poland remains basically that which the Foreign Minister (Mr Street) outlined in his public statement on 19 January 1982, following Cabinet's consideration of the matter. Since that time the Polish authorities have given us no cause to modify or retract our condemnation of the gross violations of human rights and civil liberties which martial law has inflicted upon the Polish people. No credible sign has come from the Polish leader General Jaruzelski that he is prepared to honour his earlier undertaking to allow a genuine restoration of reform in Poland. For that he bears an increasingly heavy responsibility, not only to his own people, but also to the international community, for which the continuing imposition of martial law poses potentially grave consequences for East-West relations and for international stability in general.

Australia continues to join with its Western allies in calling for an end to martial law, the release of detainees and a resumption of the process of reconsiliation based on consensus and restraint. The people of Poland must be left free to resolve their internal political and economic difficulties in accordance with their popular aspirations. Martial law is denying them that freedom. In response to martial law in Poland, the Australian Government has said and done a number of things. It has joined Western allies in calling for an end to martial law, the release of detainees and the resumption of genuine dialigue. It has conveyed its condemnation of martial law to the Polish and Soviet Governments. It has told the Polish authorities that in present circumstances we are not prepared to conduct normal bilateral relations with them. It has continued to defer a Polish request for further economic assistance and indicated to Warsaw that the roll-over provisions of a current Government- guaranteed credit facility are dependent upon the prompt payment of accounts as they fall due and that the option to cancel or suspend those provisions remains open to the Government.

It has supported Western moves to condemn martial law in international forums, such as the International Labour Conference and the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. It has told the Soviet Union that its role in the Polish crisis reinforces the need for Australia to keep in place the post-Afghanistan measures limiting bilateral relations. It has consulted carefully with allies in order to support Western objectives arising from the Polish crisis. It has decided to accept an increased number of refugees and migrants from Poland, as announced earlier this year by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and it has supported the sending of private humanitarian aid to the people of Poland.

The Government has had no cause to reconsider these measures. The Government took careful account of General Jaruzelski's speech to the Polish Parliament on 21 July which announced the relaxation of certain martial law restrictions and the separate announcement of the release of a number of detainees. Despite these steps, martial law itself remains in force and a considerable number of individuals, including Lech Walesa and other prominent Solidarity leaders, remain in detention. Recent demonstrations in Poland and their dispersal by the militia have underlined the wide gulf between the authorities and the Polish people.

The Government has made clear that, notwithstanding its strong condemnation of martial law, it will do nothing to impede the flow of private humanitarian aid to the people of Poland. In support of Australian community efforts in this regard, the Government made a cash grant of $1m to the national 'Help Poland Live' Appeal, of which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is also patron. Through the Australian Embassy in Warsaw, the Government has sought to monitor the flow of Australian private aid and to ensure that such aid is reaching the people who need it most. The Government is well satisfied with the assurances it has received in that regard from the Polish church authorities who are responsible for distributing private aid. Australian private aid is much appreciated by the church authorities in Poland and in Rome and has contributed significantly to the overall humanitarian relief effort. The measures the Government has taken will stay in place until the Polish authorities give us cause to reconsider.

We continue to condemn the role of the Soviet Union, whose persistent pressure upon the Polish people and interference in Poland's internal affairs have been a major factor in what has occurred. The Soviet Union has lent its active support to the imposition of martial law. It has once again acted in breach of its international obligations, as it did by invading and occupying Afghanistan. The Government calls on the Soviet Union to end its interference in Poland's internal affairs and, in concert with its Western partners, Australia recognises the importance of bringing home to the Soviet Union and the Polish authorities the seriousness of Western concern about what is occurring in Poland. In this regard, I draw to the attention of honourable senators the recent meeting between General Jaruzelski and President Brezhnev which suggested that the Soviet Union is continuing its support of the suppression of the people of Poland.

It will be recalled that the measures Australia introduced to curtail its bilateral relations with the Soviet Union in response to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan are wide-ranging and sustained. They include the suspension of scientific, academic and cultural exchanges; suspension of officials' talks at foreign ministry level; suspension of fisheries co-operation; suspension of Soviet cruise ship operations and a number of other things which have been made clear from time to time.

Australia's policy in response to martial law in Poland accords with and supports the position of our Western allies as expressed in the important North Atlantic Treaty Organisation declaration of 11 January this year and at the later Summit meetings at Versailles and Bonn. We remain in close consultation with our allies about the implications of what is occurring. Poland was discussed during the recent ANZUS Council meeting in Canberra. The communique of that meeting noted that the imposition of martial law in Poland demonstrated that the Soviet Union retained ambitions outside its own borders which could not fail to lead to a deterioration in the climate of international security.

It is also appropriate to recall the Government's warning that Soviet intervention in Poland would pose the most serious risks for East-West relations and for international co-operation. No country could remain immune from the consequences of such action and the Government sincerely hopes that the Soviet Union would remain mindful of the grave responsibility it bore in that regard.

Before the imposition of martial law in Poland, the Government had made clear, both publicly and to the Soviet Union and Polish authorities, its belief that Poland should be left free to resolve its internal difficulties without the threat of external coercion or interference. The Foreign Minister conveyed these sentiments to the Polish leadership during his visit to Warsaw in November last year. Strongly implicit in the Government's stated concern was a call that the Polish authorities themselves should desist from using force against the Polish people. It is a matter of deep regret that this call-echoed by many other countries-went unheeded. In taking this firm position, the Government at an early stage joined with other Western countries in recognising the dangerous consequences for Western security and for international stability in general should the Soviet Union intervene in Poland.

In the period since the Solidarity movement took root, the various groups within Poland and the Polish authorities themselves had demonstrated an admirable capacity for restraint and conciliation in attempting to resolve Poland's internal difficulties. We had hoped that that spirit of restraint and conciliation would continue, but our hopes were dashed by martial law. The Poles had to contend with their difficulties in the face of excessive public and political pressures from the Soviet Union and other members of the Warsaw Pact, notably the German Democratic Republic and Czechoslovakia. The Australian Government rejected such pressure, including adjacent military exercises, as unhelpful to the Poles and called upon Poland's neighbours to show restraint.

There would be benefit in our view in the Senate expressing its condemnation of martial law. This would serve to reinforce the position the Government has taken and reflect also the keen interest of the Australian community in what is occurring. It would also support the views of other Western parliaments.

We believe that an important factor of constraint to date against Soviet intervention in Poland is the firm position most Western countries have taken, supported by strong expressions of community and parliamentary interest in those countries. For that reason the Government welcomes the sentiments in Senator Harradine's motion. It is a further, important expression of this Parliament's close interest in developments in Poland and lends weight to the firm position of the Government which I have described. I suggest, too, that the actions of the Government thus far have already met most of the recommendations in the motion.

The motion refers specifically to the International Labour Organisation. In that context, the Government can say unequivocally that Australia has been and continues to be prepared to join with the international community in protesting against martial law in the strongest possible terms and in whatever international forums may be appropriate.

The International Labour Conference at its 68th session in June 1982 considered the issue of Poland in the context of freedom of association which is protected by ILO Convention 87, to which Poland is a party. The report of the Committee on the Application of Standards, which monitors the implementation of ILO conventions, included a special paragraph highlighting Poland's departure from Convention 87. At the insistence of several East European delegations, votes were called at the Committee and Plenary stages, resulting in the adoption of the report. The Australian delegation firmly supported the inclusion of a special reference to Poland in the report and also made a statement on Poland during debate in the Committee.

On the aspect of human rights, Australia has also been active. The 38th session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in February and March this year provided the international community with the first occasion within the United Nations context to take up the issue of martial law in Poland. The resolution on Poland adopted by the Commission, which Australia firmly supported, expressed deep concern about human rights violations under martial law. It sought an early end to current restrictions on civil liberties, affirmed the right of the Polish people to conduct their affairs free from outside interference, and requested the Secretary-General, or a person designated by him, to undertake a thorough study of the human rights situation in Poland. This report is to be submitted to the Commission's 39th session in February next year. The Australian delegation also made a statement expressing the Government's serious concern about developments in Poland. The Commission's next session should therefore have before it a comprehensive report about Poland. This report should provide a further opportunity for the international community to urge the Polish authorities to restore human rights and fundamental freedoms. Australia will support any such moves.

From this it will be apparent that Australian representatives have placed Australia's views on Poland firmly on record in international fora, including the International Labour Organisation, and have lent their full support to initiatives aimed at improving the circumstances of the Polish people. The Government will continue to explore further multilateral avenues to press its views about what is occurring in Poland.

The Government's only concern, Mr President, is with the specific wording of the motion and particularly that it be conveyed to the Polish Primate, Archbishop Glemp. As I have mentioned, an important part of Western policy on Poland is that a genuine dialogue be restored between all the main elements of Polish society. We recognise, of course, that the church is of fundamental import- ance in the present crisis. But the Government questions the appropriateness of addressing the terms of a motion such as this to the church alone. We have no reservations about addressing it to the church. But we would prefer to try to bring the terms of this motion to the attention of all the main elements, including the Polish martial law authorities who, we continue to hope, have not become entirely insensitive to expressions of international concern. The Government would be pleased to arrange for this to be done by the Embassy in Warsaw.

If Senator Harradine can see fit to add to his motion words to the effect that we also express our concern to other appropriate bodies I would be pleased to have that matter attended to by the Embassy. We do not question the motive behind his particular thought with regard to the Polish Primate, Archbishop Glemp, but we feel that other appropriate steps could be taken which might widen the expression of this motion if it is carried by the Australian Senate. I ask Senator Harradine whether he would concur in widening that part of his motion to include such a sentiment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I seek leave to add to my motion the words:

SPEECH.PARA: 'and to other appropriate authorities'.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Since the beginning of this week there have been a number of media reports relating to my ex-husband Donald John Maher and allegations that he has received privileges from the prison authorities in Queensland. My name has been connected with these stories by reference to the fact that he is my ex-husband, and there have been references to events involving me which occurred more than 10 years ago. The matter has been raised in a political context and I think it is necessary for me to put the record straight so that there can be no misunderstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: I separated from Donald Maher in September 1969 and sought a divorce which was granted in October 1970. I have not seen Donald Maher since June 1972-that is, for more than 10 years-and have had no contact with him for more than 10 years. The matters concerning him which have given rise to controversy over this week involve matters which are current or which have occurred over recent years. I am in no way involved with those matters. In light of the frequent references to me in these stories, however, I propose to outline the relevant events.

My contact with the Queensland prison system commenced in 1965 when, in the company of other members of the Queensland Debating Union, I participated in a number of demonstration debates to assist the Debating Union to establish debating and public speaking as part of the rehabilitation program in Brisbane Prison. Donald Maher was an inmate of the prison in 1965 and participated in debating activities at which I was also present. However, there was no personal contact between visitors and prisoners at that time and no personal contact between me and him.

During 1965 I became involved in debating activities in Wacol prison at the personal invitation of the then Superintendent of that prison, Mr Allan Whitney. I visited Wacol Prison frequently over a period of approximately three years and as a result came to know several senior members of the prison's administration, including the then Comptroller-General, the late Mr Stewart Kerr. Donald Maher was released from prison in December 1965. I met him at a debating function in January 1966. We were married in December 1966. We separated in September 1969. I applied for and was granted a divorce in October 1970. There was some occasional contact between us subsequent to the divorce on matters relating to our property settlement.

Subsequent to his being arrested and charged with murder in November 1971 I agreed to accept a power of attorney for him solely for the purpose of winding up his business affairs while he was remanded in custody awaiting trial. In order to close down and sell his business, it was necessary for me to obtain detailed instructions from my ex-husband since I had never worked in the business and had no knowledge of it. I experienced difficulty in gaining access to him at the prison in order to receive his instructions.

I therefore made a request to Mr Kerr to have visiting privileges additional to the visits allowed under prison regulations, which in any event were being used by members of his family. Mr Kerr stated to me that since I had, during the time of my association with Wacol Prison, proved myself to be trustworthy and had shown consideration for the requirements of the prison system, and because of the special position my ex-husband was in-that is, remanded in custody for an extended period awaiting trial and unable to handle his own business affairs-he would arrange for me to have visiting privileges similar to that of a solicitor provided that I undertook to confine my visits strictly to business matters and did not discuss with my ex-husband any matters that were not connected with that business. I gave that undertaking and abided by it. Mr Kerr also told me that a further restriction would be placed on my visits, namely that my ex-husband and I would be under close personal supervision by prison officers whenever it was necessary for me to see him. These were the conditions that applied to all my subsequent visits to Brisbane Prison. Mr Kerr told me that he would inform the Superintendent of Brisbane Prison, Mr Roy Stephenson, that I was to have this access. During the three-week period following my ex-husband's arrest it was necessary for me to visit the prison reasonably frequently-every two or three days. After three weeks I found it necessary to visit no more frequently than once a week, sometimes less frequently.

On a number of visits I had difficulty with the prison officers on duty when I sought to see my ex-husband. On these occasions they claimed to have no knowledge of instructions that I had special visiting privileges. On a number of occasions I found it necessary to contact either Mr Kerr or Mr Stephenson to gain access to the prison. I have no knowledge as to whether Mr Kerr made any contact with the then Minister in charge of prisons, the late Mr John Herbert, in connection with this matter and no reason to believe that he did. I have no reason to believe that Mr Kerr was ever aware that I was a member of the Liberal Party. The subject was never mentioned in any of our conversations and at that time I was no more than an active branch member of the Party. I had no contact with Mr Herbert, whom I did not know.

After my ex-husband's conviction in May 1972 I visited my ex-husband under normal prison visiting conditions. To the best of my recollection there were only two such visits and they were within the month following his conviction. I have not sought entry to Brisbane Prison for any reason whatsoever since that time, over 10 years ago. A couple of months after my ex-husband's conviction I was contacted by a welfare officer who worked at the prison. The welfare officer told me that my ex-husband wanted to have music lessons and that money would be required to pay a music teacher to visit the prison to teach him. I was holding some sporting equipment which had belonged to my ex-husband. I sold it and gave the money to the welfare officer. A few months later I received a further request to purchase some music text books, which I did. I delivered the books to the prison. To the best of my recollection that was late 1972. That was my last contact with Brisbane Prison. What should be clear is that my involvement is an involvement of more than 10 years ago and that in no way could it be said to be political. I am sorry to have to take up the time of the Senate with what are basically personal matters but the matter has been raised in a political way and I felt it my duty to ensure that the record is clear.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 576) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning a French Government program for the advancement of women.

ANSWER.PARA: In replying on 18 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2087), the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment undertook to examine the initiatives and report further.
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The program for the advancement of women announced by the President of the Republic of France, M. Mitterrand, on 8 March, International Women's Day, this year, is a wide-ranging strategy for enabling and encouraging French women to take a more equal part in the social, economic and political life of France.
A number of the measures announced will bring French women to parity with rights already enjoyed by Australian women-for example, a free choice of careers in the Public Service.
Some-particularly relating to rises in pension entitlements-do not translate easily into comparable Australian terms, as French pension rights unlike Australian entitlements depend on contributions.

Of particular interest is a projected series of laws giving enforceable rights to the wives of small businessmen and tradesmen, farmers and men in the liberal professions, where they work together with their husbands, to a choice between the status of employee, associate or partner. This status would entail all the legal rights of any other employee, associate or business partner under French law, and is a positive step towards recognition of the work performed by many women. The first of these laws-relating to trades and small businesses-was enacted in May of this year, and the law relating to farmers will be ready in 1983. Many people will be interested in the outcome of these important and innovative measures.
The French program aims to recognise, diversify and make visible the contribution of French women to their society. I applaud the initiatives and will examine further developments with interest.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Sale of Lottery Tickets in the Australian Capital Territory

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1440) Senator Reid asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, a question without notice seeking information relating to the New South Wales Government being asked to make a refund to Canberra on New South Wales lottery tickets sold in the Australian Capital Territory similar to the arrangements that have been negotiated with the Victorian Government.

The Minister has accepted the offer for a 75 per cent share of duty on Australian Capital Territory Lotto sales with an increase to 100 per cent of duty in 12 months time.
The New South Wales Government has however been asked to reconsider the offer for a share of net revenue from New South Wales lottery tickets sold in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1758) Senator Button asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Minister appreciate that this is not really a matter of expense? It is a matter of a statement made by the Minister for Defence in 1980 that flying hours and Royal Australian Navy steaming time would be increased as a matter of Government policy. The question is: What has changed, in terms of Australia's strategic environment, which enables the Minister to say these things are no longer important in 1982? Let me put it also in these terms: Was the decision which was made in 1980 wrong in regard to Australia's strategic preparedness?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I refer the honourable senator to the Hansard of 25 March 1980 page 1136; the Minister for Defence said:

. . . There will be few now who can confidently assert that, wherever favourable opportunities may occur for manipulation, subversion and interference, including the Asian and Pacific regions, the Soviet Union will not exploit them. Uncertainty and instability everywhere are stimulated by this . We cannot have the same confidence in our strategic prospects that we had two years ago. All of us, together or separately, must give evidence that those who perceive a threat to their interests are prepared to back their resolve with military strength.
The elements of concern stated by the Minister for Defence then remain relevant today, as was made clear by the Minister for Defence in Parliament on 29 April this year.
The major equipment decisions also announced by my predecessor on 29 April are a further earnest of the policy stated in March 1980, not a step back from it.

The statement of the Minister for Defence of 29 April 1982, emphasised that no 'planned objectives' would be abandoned, but that adjustments to the program were inevitable. These adjustments included areas such as operating costs and Service activities. Some activities such as steaming time will increase in 1982 -83 with the introduction of additional ships coming into service in that year. Other activities such as flying time will be curtailed but only in some areas. The major flying changes arise from the measures the former Minister for Defence announced concerning revised training for Mirage pilots and from the phasing out of Canberra aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2016) Senator Chipp asked me a supplementary question without notice in relation to the Four Corners program titled Argentina and the Bomb screened on 8 May 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chipp asked if the Senate could be provided with the Government's reaction to the concern expressed on that program and the statements made by West German Ministers and by international experts on the question of Argentina 's nuclear capability.

The transcript of the Four Corners program on nuclear activities in Argentina has now been examined by officers of my Department, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the Australian Safeguards Office and other relevant Departments. Based on their advice I believe my previous reply covered the major substantive points raised in that program. However, the Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information which may be of interest to honourable senators:

The Government maintains constant vigilance on all matters relating to the possible spread of nuclear weapons and the Government strongly supports international measures to maintain a framework of controls which will ensure adequate protection against the diversion of material to nuclear weapons production or nuclear explosives.

Argentina is not a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and does not meet the minimum requirements for nuclear co-operation with Australia. Argentina signed the Treaty for the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Latin America (the Treaty of Tlatelolco) in 1967, but has not taken the necessary actions to ratify the Treaty and to bring it into force for Argentina. Argentina has thus not accepted a legally binding comprehensive commitment to non-proliferation, nor has it accepted a commitment to maintain now and in the future International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards over all its peaceful nuclear activities, that is, safeguards of 'full scope'.

The Government understands that at the present time all known, operating nuclear installations in Argentina are covered by IAEA safeguards under separate agreements with the Agency. The Government also understands that Argentina is in the process of developing nuclear facilities which it asserts will employ indigenous technology. Argentina maintains that it has not accepted any legal obligations to place such indigenously developed facilities under IAEA safeguards. These facilities include a reprocessing plant and a pilot heavy-water production plant at present under construction. The Government is aware of the following nuclear facilities in Argentina:
Designation Location
Nuclear Power Reactors:
Atucha I Atucha
Embalse Cordoba (under construction)
Atucha II Atucha (under construction)
Research Reactors:
RA-0 Cordoba
RA-1 Constituyentes
RA-2 Constituyentes
RA-3 Ezeiza
RA-4 Rosario
RA-6 Bariloche Fuel Fabrication Plants:
Pilot Fuel Fabrication Plant . . Constituyentes (natural uranium)
Pilot Fuel Fabrication Plant . . Constituyentes (highly enriched uranium)
Fuel Fabrication Plant . . Ezeiza (under construction)
Heavy Water Production Plants:
Pilot Plant
Atucha (under construction)
Production Plant Arroyito (under construction)
Reprocessing Plant:
Pilot Facility Ezeiza (under construction)

The Government believes that Argentina does not possess nuclear weapons. The Chairman of Argentina's Atomic Energy Commission, Vice-Admiral Castro Madero, has said that Argentina wishes to retain the right to develop so-called ' peaceful nuclear explosive devices'. Argentina has also stated that it reserves the right to make use of nuclear energy for 'non-proscribed' military purposes in the future. It is possible that Argentina intends thereby to keep open the option of nuclear propulsion of naval vessels. Argentina appears incapable at present of fuelling or constructing a marine propulsion reactor from its own resources.

In keeping with its policy, the Government is paying close attention to Argentina's nuclear program and to the safeguards arrangements which apply to nuclear items supplied to Argentina by other countries. A number of countries have supplied nuclear items to Argentina under separate IAEA safeguards arrangements in recent years. They include Canada, the Federal Republic of Germany (FRG), Switzerland, the United States of America and the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics. There have been media reports of China having supplied heavy water and enriched uranium to Argentina without requiring the application of safeguards.

Nuclear cooperation between the Federal Republic of Germany and Argentina involving the supply of nuclear material, equipment and technology dates from the late 1960s and there are several agreements between Argentina and the International Atomic Energy Authority applying International Atomic Energy Authority safeguards to the items supplied to the Argentina by the Federal Republic of Germany. The Government understands that there has also been cooperation between scientists from the Karlsruhe Nuclear Research Centre in the Federal Republic of Germany and Argentina's Atomic Energy Commission over a number of years.

The Federal Republic of Germany and Switzerland concluded contracts with Argentina in 1979 for the supply respectively of a nuclear power station, Atucha-II, and a heavy water production plant. These transfers are subject to IAEA safeguards, but 'full scope' safeguards were not insisted upon.

Australia made suggestions for strengthening the safeguards arrangements for these facilities in discussions in the Board of Governors of the IAEA in Vienna in 1981 and in consultations with other governments. The suggestions referred in particular to the desirability of ensuring that nuclear facilities replicated indigenously from supplied nuclear facilities should be subject to IAEA safeguards. Australia also called attention to the fact that in the case of a country like Argentina which had not accepted the legal obligation to apply 'full scope' safeguards, the resulting safeguards coverage by a number of separate agreements resulted in fragmentation. Argentina maintained that it did not have an obligation to change the safeguards requirements which had been negotiated with the Federal Republic of Germany and Switzerland to apply safeguards going beyond the coverage of items to be specifically transferred to it by those countries.

Consistent with its expressed objective of independence and self-sufficiency in nuclear matters, Argentina could itself develop facilities of the kind supplied. The absence of a requirement for 'full scope' IAEA safeguards in the arrangements covering the supply of nuclear installations means that such facilities might not be placed under IAEA safeguards if Argentina decided to contend that they had been developed from indigenous technology.

The Government would welcome a legally binding commitment by Argentina to place all of its nuclear facilities, now and in the future, under IAEA safeguards. The Government will continue to direct its efforts towards this objective.

The abovementioned children accommodated in institutional care includes children under orders from the Australian Capital Territory Children's Court, children requiring accommodation for only a few weeks during which it is not practicable to arrange foster care, and other children for whom it has not been possible to arrange foster parents in a normal domestic environment because of behaviour problems or because of difficulties in finding foster parents prepared to accept responsibility for numbers of brothers and sisters.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Review of Commonwealth Functions: Department of Administrative Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What research into the local building industry was undertaken before making the announcement of a temporary freeze in Commissioner for Housing Loans;

(2) Was a check made on the number of builders who have either been bankrupt or forced out of business in Canberra in the last six months; and did the Government check on the numbers of builders, contractors, suppliers, employees and real estate salesman who would be affected by this decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following response to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 and 2) The temporary freeze of some loan funds was imposed in mid-February in the context of a general re-assessment of government expenditure. In this context the degree of research suggested by your question was unnecessary.
