QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Health seen a report in the Age dated 16 March 1981 in which the Victorian Health Commission is reported to have informed the State Government 'that without urgent action to contain an epidemic in hospitals, Victoria will without doubt achieve the infamy of the State that cultivated the most antibiotic-resistant strain of staphylococcus aureus ever'.

(2) In some hospitals is only one drug totally effective against this germ, and have some doctors and microbiologists predicted that this drug will also become ineffective as the germ develops resistance.
(3) What steps have been taken to monitor the Australia-wide spread of staphylococcus aureus.
(4) Will the Minister for Health refer the issues involved to the National Health and Medical Research Council as a matter of urgency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Methicillin-resistant staphylococci have been sporadically isolated world-wide since 1961. (Barber, M., Methicillin-resistant staphylococci, Journal of Clinical Pathology, Vol. 14: 385-393 (1961). Resistance of organisms to antibiotics has been a problem since they were first introduced. I am aware of the concern, not only in Australia but throughout the world, at problems associated with such resistant strains in hospital medical practice. The Federal Government is naturally anxious that any problems which have been associated with infection by this particular organism should be reduced and, if possible, eliminated.

(2) The newspaper article referred to in (1) reports this to be so but names neither the drug nor the hospitals. If the honourable senator would provide me with this detail I would be better placed to respond to the question.

(3) and (4) At present the Antibiotic (Standing) Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC) is examining the question of the incidence of methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus in Australia and has taken steps to monitor the extent of the problem. To this end, the respective State and Territory health authorities have been asked to co-operate with the Committee in establishing the extent of this problem. Various professional organisations have been asked to nominate sentinel laboratories which could report instances of staphylococcus aureus and other antibiotic resistant organisms.

The NH and MRC has had the problem of nosocomial (hospital acquired) infections , which now includes methicillin-resistant staphylococci, under review for some time and, as far back as 1978, recommended that Infection Control Committees or officers be appointed in all hospitals where such measures were seen as appropriate.

Of course this is essentially a State responsibility, the only area for which the Federal Government has direct responsibility being the Australian Capital Territory. Although the infections do occur in Australian Capital Territory hospitals, they do not present a major problem. The matter is kept under constant review by the Capital Territory Health Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is information available showing that 2,000 doctors have secured medical benefit payments which exceed by $20,000 the Department of Health estimates of expected income limits; if so, has the information in regard to such income held by the Federal Department of Health been forwarded to the Attorney-General or any other Federal authority, for example, the Commissioner of Taxation, and what further action will be taken by any Federal authorities.
(2) Has any investigation of these matters been undertaken by the Australian Federal Police, if so, on what date did this investigation commence, and have any charges been laid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On the basis of statistical analysis of medical benefit claims, my Department estimates that about 2,000 doctors have received medical benefit payments which exceed the expected income for their peer group (i.e. doctors practising in the same speciality in the same State) by $20,000 or more per annum.

While I am advised that the figures are accurate according to the parameters adopted, the automated Fraud and Overservicing Detection Sytem (FODS) which produced these figures is still under development. It would not be reasonable to infer that abuse is involved in each and every case. The term 'abuse' in relation to medical benefits includes both fraud and overservicing. (Fraud refers to claims for services that were not provided, and is an offence under the Health Insurance Act. Overservicing refers to the provision of services not reasonably necessary for the adequate medical care of the patient concerned.) The statistical estimating procedure used does not distinguish between fraud and overservicing-it only provides a starting point for more detailed investigations .

This information has been forwarded in general terms to some other Commonwealth authorities. The Attorney-General's Department is aware of the magnitude of the problem and has been instrumental in the formulation of methods to curb abuse of the health insurance arrangements. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) are also aware of these figures and of the basis of calculation, but have not been given data concerning the identity of each doctor as the Department is still working on the data. Where indications of fraud are found, the matter is referred to the police. The Commissioner of Taxation has not been given this information.

(2) Where indications of fraud are found, the matter is referred to the AFP by my Department. Details of investigations, prosecutions and convictions of doctors from 1975 to 30 October 1981 were given in the answer to Question No. 3256 asked by Mr Hayden (Hansard, 16 February 1982, pages 144-147).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Health aware that under the 'free hospital system' in Queensland, chemists make up prescriptions at the hospital dispensaries which are supplied at no cost to patients.

(2) Is the Minister for Health aware that as from the 1 February 1982 ' portability' of prescriptions for outpatients has been operating, and in the case of pensioners, the Federal Government is picking up the bill for all medicines so prescribed and which are made up by a private chemist.
(3) Has this action been taken on the direction of the Federal Minister for Health or has it been initiated by the Queensland Government in order to conserve hospital funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) The administrative action referred to in part (2) of the question has been initiated solely by the Queensland Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Thai companies are currently engaged in buying sapphires from Australian gemfields and what are the names of those companies and the names of the principals of those companies.
(2) What was the value to Australia in export earnings in sapphires: (a) during financial year 1979-80, and (b) during financial year 1980-81.
(3) Can the Minister for Trade and Resources obtain information regarding the value of cut sapphires of Australian origin that were exported from Thailand during the same period.
(4) What was the value of imported cut sapphire that Australia bought back from Thailand during the same period.
(5) Has the Commonwealth Government ever conducted an overseas campaign to promote Australian sapphires on world markets.

(6) Is the Australian sapphire industry facing ruin through the total lack of an orderly marketing system within Australia and through the stranglehold that the Thai cartel has over the international sapphire market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The information sought is not available to the Commonwealth Government nor, as I understand, to the relevant State governments.

(2) The Australian Bureau of Statistics has recorded the following values from the export of Australian sapphires: (a) $A14,633,000 for the 1979-80 financial year, (b) $A13,103,244 for the 1980-81 financial year.
(3) Provision is not made in Thai statistics for the recording of the country of origin of the raw materials from which those exports are derived.
(4) Imports of sapphires (natural, synthetic or reconstructed) into Australia, which would include cut sapphires, are not separately identified within the Australian Import Commodity Classification.

(5) The Department of Trade and Resources has assisted the efforts of the Australian gemstone industry-which includes the sapphire industry-in various ways, not the least being provision of advice, contacts, etc., by Australian Trade Commissioners. The Department has also facilitated participation by Australian gemstone exporters in appropriate exhibitions overseas (e.g., the Idar Oberstein gemstone exhibition; general Australian trade displays such as those in Vancouver and Honolulu, and the Australian gemstone display at the Spokane Expo, Washington, United States of America).

(6) The strength of this industry can be clearly seen in the improving value of exports over recent years, which have increased for instance from $A3.6m in 1976 -77 to $A14.6m in 1979-80. A downturn was experienced in 1980-81 which has continued into 1981-82. This experience is consistent with that of most other industries, particularly those which are resource based.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

(2) Will this edition of the Directory be withdrawn as a result of the ministerial changes.
(3) What will be the cost of reprinting the Directory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1982 edition of the Commonwealth Directory had not been printed prior to 6 May 1982.
(2) and (3). See answer to (1) above.
In substitution for the answer which appeared in the weekly Hansard of 27 May 1982, page 2618.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Do representatives of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association have contact with the Minister for Health, his staff, and officers of his Department and bodies under his control; if so, what has been the nature and frequency of that contact since January 1977.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I have had a request from the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association (AVCA) to open their conference. I had a discussion with Mr Brian Flower on the telephone asking him what the nature of the body was and details of the conference before agreeing to come. The conference is to be held in September. I have had no other dealings with the Association.
My personal secretary also spoke to Mr Flower about arrangements.

Departmental officers and AVCA representatives do meet from time to time at various national and international gatherings and at meetings held under the aegis of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC), a body under my control, and of the Standards Association of Australia. As well there are the normal contacts through correspondence and telephone and, occasionally, AVCA representatives call on my Department.

No composite record is kept by my Department of the frequency of all such meetings. However, in respect of the NH and MRC, its Poisons Schedule (Standing) Committee and Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals (Standing) Committee each meet four times a year and have done so for many years. AVCA representatives attend the opening sessions of these committee meetings and officers of my Department provide the secretariats.

Contacts that are made are in the nature of discussions about, and exchange of, information on matters of common, professional interest. Typically, discussions would cover such topics as the standard of submissions to committees, invitations and comment on issues before committees and the availability of and access to information. The meetings bestow no particular advantage on AVCA vis-a -vis other organisations. For example, at the (Standing) Committee meetings referred to above AVCA representatives depart at the conclusion of general discussions. Submissions to the committees about particular chemicals or on matters of special interest to companies and individuals are not discussed during AVCA's presence.
The principal area of contact in my Department is the Public Health Division.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the United Nations Economic and Social Council authorised the Sub- Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities to establish annually a Working Group on Indigenous Populations which shall meet for up to five working days before the annual sessions of the Sub-Commission in order to review developments pertaining to the promotion and protection of the human rights and fundamental freedom of indigenous populations;
(2) What steps have been taken to enable Aborigines to participate in the Working Group.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On 3 May 1982, the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC ) endorsed a decision of the 38th Session of the UN Commission on Human Rights to enable the UN Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities to set up a Working Group on Indigenous Peoples at its session in August-September 1982. The working group was charged with the task of drafting a set of standards to protect the rights of indigenous peoples. Australia supported this initiative both at the Commission on Human Rights and at ECOSOC.

(2) As Australia is not a member of the Sub-Commission, it is not eligible to seek membership of the Working Group. However, as an active observer to the Sub -Commission, the Australian Government will be seeking to play a constructive role in discussions aimed at clarifying and amplifying the Working Group's terms of reference. As part of this process, the Australian Government will be promoting the need for effective consultation with indigenous peoples themselves, including Australian Aboriginals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981 (Hansard, page 492) and 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1722) Senator Martyr asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, questions without notice concerning the medical use of pancreatic tissue.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of Press coverage given to this topic. However with the exception of the reference to use of Woden Valley Hospital as a storage bank for foetal tissue, the matters raised by the honourable senator relate to research work being undertaken by Dr Lafferty at the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the Australian National University (ANU). My colleague, the Minister for Education, within whose portfolio responsibilities this research work falls, has provided the following information.

No proposal for the establishment of a tissue bank using foetuses or foetal tissues has been approved within the Australian National University. Some work on cyro-preservation of pancreatic islet tissue is planned. If cyro- preservation can be achieved successfully, it would be feasible in the future to store deep-frozen tissue for potential clinical transplantation into seriously-ill diabetics.

There has been no funding allocated by the Government specifically for the project. A grant of $25,000 was made to Dr Lafferty in 1981 by the University under a 'new initiatives' scheme from its recurrent funds, which are largely derived from Government allocations.

The University research proposal is not concerned with aborted foetuses but with foetal pancreatic islet tissue which is supplied from the Royal Women's Hospital, Melbourne. In accordance with the guidelines of the British (Peel) Report and the New Zealand report on Contraception, Sterilisation, and Abortion in New Zealand, tissue will be accepted for research purposes in this feasibility study only from foetuses between 10 and 18 weeks' gestation. All procedures that the University follows in this matter meet proper ethical requirements.
The foetuses do not have to be born alive. As with other tissue and organ donation (e.g. for kidney transplants), the tissue is removed after death.

So far as my own portfolio responsibilities are involved, I can assure the honourable senator that no proposal for the storage of foetal pancreatic tissues at Woden Valley Hospital has been considered, or approved, by the Capital Territory Health Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a report in the Courier Mail of 17 June 1982 mention an assurance given by the Queensland Premier to Japanese businessmen and government officials that a deep water port should be operating in Queensland within three or four years, most probably at Port Clinton on the central coast.

(2) Has the Queensland Government sought permission from the Federal Government for access to Port Clinton through the Defence Department's Shoalwater Bay training area; if so, what is the Federal Government's response to this request.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Queensland has proposed an on-site inspection and feasibility study in the area and the Commonwealth has agreed to this. Any proposal for development of the Port Clinton area would have to take account of its value for defence training.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are counter staff of the Minister's Department permitted to smoke whilst interviewing clients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No formal policy has been issued by the central office of the Department prohibiting smoking by counter staff interviewing clients.
Directives, either oral or written, have been issued to staff by State branch offices that counter staff should not smoke in the presence of clients. Generally this practice is followed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What reaction has the Government taken to suggestions that changes to the licensing regulations requiring compulsory flight checks for private/business pilots will cause increased rates of attrition of private pilots because of financial and other restrictions.

(2) What response did the Government give to questions raised concerning the changes by the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia on behalf of private pilots in a letter to the Prime Minister dated 6 January 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has no reason to believe that the introduction of the flight review will cause increased rates of attrition of private pilots, however this aspect will be carefully monitored. Should there be any increase, the reasons will be investigated, and appropriate action taken. Any proposed action will need to be balanced against the anticipated improvement in air safety.

In the 1981 calendar year 3,363 new private pilot licences were issued. The net gain in current private licences between 31 December 1980 to 31 December 1981 was 1,718, an apparent lapse of 1,645 licences. However, in the same period 546 commercial licences were issued, almost all of which would have been graduations from private licences. The average apparent annual lapse of private licences for the five year period 1976-80 was 1,756. The apparent lapse for 1981 is therefore slightly less than the average for the preceding five years.

(2) In response to his letter of 6 January 1981 the Prime Minister informed the President of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association that the review was introduced to improve the level of safety in private and business flying where the rate of accidents is significantly higher than in other sectors of general aviation. The Prime Minister also said that there would be no resultant increase in staffing levels within the Department of Transport as it then was, nor in the costs of government. The Prime Minister also pointed out that it was his understanding that, at current prices, the cost of the review to the average licence holder would not exceed $90 in any two year period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what dates will Captain Alvin Young and other United States Air Force Personnel be in Australia in 1982.
(2) Who are the personnel accompanying Captain Young, and what are their ranks.
(3) What are their scientific and/or medical qualifications.

(4) Have any of these personnel appeared before United States congressional committees since January 1977, and given evidence on any matters arising out of United States and Allied military involvement in Vietnam; if so, on what dates, and before which committees did they appear.
(5) Is there any cost to Australia resulting from this visit; and if so, (a) what is that cost; and (b) against what department appropriations will it be charged.
(6) What is the itinerary for their visit, and with whom, and where, will they be having discussions.

(7) Did the Minister, his office, or his Department, or any authority under his control make arrangements for the United States delegation to appear before the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, and if so what are the details.
(8) What is the purpose of this visit.
(9) Who initiated the visit, when was it first discussed, and arrangements made .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A visit from a United States team of officials including Major Alvin Young was to take place in May 1982.

The proposal for a visit was a United States initiative. The purpose was to gain closer knowledge of the status of Australian studies relating to Vietnam veterans and to offer information on United States developments.

On 31 March 1982 I informed the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment that a visit was proposed and that United States representatives would welcome an opportunity to meet the Committee at a mutually convenient time.
On 21 May 1982 advice was received from the United States. Embassy in Canberra that the proposed visit had to be postponed.
It was the intention of the United States authorities to meet all expenses associated with the visit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 25 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Was a firm or firms of corporate image consultant experts engaged by Trans Australian Airlines during the last five years; if so-
(a) what is the name of the 'firm' or 'firms';
(b) what was the fee paid for the services rendered; and
(c) what was the nature of the services rendered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: During the last five years TAA has only once called for the services of a corporate image consultant.
(a) Pieter Huveneers, Sydney.

(b) A monthly retainer of $15,000 was paid from January 1980 until 1 May this year when that figure was halved because the majority of the required design work had been completed. TAA anticipates that the contract with Mr Huveneers will terminate, in its present form, on 31 July 1982.

(c) The consultant was engaged to update the airline's corporate identification . The airline's corporate identity program covers the organisation and management of TAA's communications resources. The applications of the new identification range from aircraft livery through to offices, terminals, stationery and forms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What financial assistance is provided for housing to Aboriginal people in Western Australia, either directly or via the State Government, by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
(2) How much has been allocated in 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Aboriginal Affairs does not provide direct housing assistance for Aboriginals. Direct grants for housing to Aboriginal housing associations are provided by the Aboriginal Development Commission, which also provides housing loans for individual Aboriginal borrowers. Grants to the States earmarked for Aboriginal housing are now administered by the Department of Social Security.

(2) The Aboriginal Development Commission provided $2.463m in direct grants to Western Australian Aboriginal housing associations in 1981-82. Housing loans are not allocated on a State basis, but are approved on an individual loan application basis. In 1981-82, $787,664 was provided to Aboriginal applicants resident in Western Australia.
The welfare housing program administered by the Department of Social Security provided $7.225m to Western Australia in grants earmarked for Aboriginals in need of rental housing assistance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a contract for the maintenance and upgrading of the airstrip at Mugarinya been awarded; if so, on what date, to whom, and for what amount.
(2) How much of the contract amount was for: (a) materials, (b) labour; (c) freight; (d) engineering and other consultants; and (e) other.
(3) What amount, if any, was paid either directly or indirectly to members of the local Aboriginal community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Mugarinya Aboriginal community is located within the Tandeearra Station, approximately 100 km south of Port Hedland in Western Australia. The only airstrip servicing that community is the Tandeearra authorised landing area and I assume that this airstrip is the subject of the honourable senator's query.
As the Tandeearra airstrip is an authorised landing area, it does not come under the control of the Department of Aviation. Any works of the airstrip are the direct responsibility of the owner.
Therefore, I am unable to provide the information sought by the honourable senator.
